PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence seen reports that damage suffered by HMS Sheffield following the Argentinian missile attack was exacerbated by the aluminium superstructure of Sheffield? Is the Minister aware that Australia's FFGs have an aluminium superstructure? Has the Royal Australian Navy considered the relatively vulnerable nature of such a material? If so, what steps have been taken to reinforce the superstructure with special damage control measures to minimise the effect of the vulnerability of the FFGs? If none has been taken, will the Minister review the follow-on destroyer program to ensure that light steel replaces aluminium in subsequent construction?

—I am sure that apart from the concern at the sinking of HMS Sheffield, there will be enormous interest in the circumstances in which it was sunk. I am not in a position at the moment to comment usefully on Senator Sibraa 's question but I am sure that our defence experts will be giving the matter very close attention. I will refer the question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide a considered reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question concerns immigration. Whilst Senator Durack will probably take it on board I think Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will remember the incident to which it relates. I refer to a statement made by Mr Menadue that in the light of the expanded family reunion program and all its complexities the Public Service Board had been asked to add considerably to the work force of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Melbourne and Sydney. Following the failure to do so by yesterday, can the Minister tell me whether the Public Service Board has at last responded to meet the tremendous demands that will be made on departmental staff in order to maintain adequate processing?

—As I represent the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs I will take the responsibility for following up Senator Mulvihill's question. I gather that the matter is now with the Public Service Board rather than directly with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, but I will take note of the question and see whether I can get an early answer.

—I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to talks recently held between the land councils in the Northern Territory, the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority, the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government on the question of protecting sacred sites in the Northern Territory. I refer particularly to claims concerning sacred sites over the new development area of the Sadadeen Valley in Alice Springs. Is the Minister in a position to advise the Senate of the outcome of those discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talks were recently held in the Northern Territory between the Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government, the Central Land Council, the Northern Land Council-which was included because of the principles involved-and the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority. That meeting was not designed to discuss the particular issue of the proposed subdivision of the Sadadeen Valley but it looked at a whole range of issues relating to the protection and identification of sacred sites and the means by which any disagreements could be resolved. I advise the Senate that at that meeting considerable agreement was reached between all parties-the Northern Territory Government, the Aboriginal groups and the Sacred Sites Authority-as to an appropriate way by which difficulties of this kind could be avoided and overcome . As a result, it is now up to the principals involved to see whether they can hammer the agreement into an appropriate form in case any legislation is needed or governments have to take decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the Sadadeen Valley subdivision, I understand that similarly constructive talks are going on between the parties involved but no action is imminent in the valley which would disadvantage the Aboriginal communities. The Northern Territory is quite sensitive to the concerns which the local people have about the sites which have been identified and which the Authority in the Northern Territory has at least registered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security to place himself, if he will, in the position of an unemployed 17-year-old male living away from home and not being assisted by his parents financially in any way. He may even have no parents. Out of the $36 per week unemployment benefit he would receive, could the Minister tell me how much per week he would spend on food, rent, clothing, and heating? How much would he be able to spare on fares in order to find a job?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp posed the question in a way which is difficult for any politician to answer. We are paid handsome salaries. The same question about how we would live on the old age pension or anything else would be similarly difficult to answer. The question he raised is serious. It concerned the situation of a 17-year-old receiving a rate of unemployment benefit which is fixed for those under the age of 18 years and who are not living at home. That rate of benefit is $36. It has been fixed for some time and not altered. I understand the point which the honourable senator made in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: I am happy to say that the group to whom the honourable senator referred is very much a minority of that age group. The most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that the great bulk of people under the age of 18 live at home and have parental support and assistance. That is one of the factors, of course, which influenced the Government in decisions which it has made in determining the level of that benefit. The level of the benefit was last considered last year. There was a general examination of the position of 16 and 17-year-olds by the Government initially by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, the Minister for Education and the Minister for Social Security and their respective departments. The matters which arise to be considered are the questions of the comparative position of a young man or woman who chooses to seek employment as against a young man or woman who chooses to stay in education . Quite difficult questions of balance have to be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I very rarely interrupt Ministers answering questions, but one of the few tests which a Minister must meet in answering a question, with great respect, is relevance. The Minister is giving a first class rationalisation of Government policy but he is not answering the simple, specific question I asked: How much would he spend on rent, food and fares out of $36 a week? That is all I want to know.

—There is no point of order. It has been the practice in this chamber that Ministers have the responsibility as well as the right to answer a question as they see fit. It may be necessary in the Minister's view to take time to give some reasons for the points he will make in answer to Senator Chipp 's question.

—I was endeavouring to give a reasonable answer to the honourable senator. Of course, his precise question does not admit of a specific answer in the form in which he has requested. What arrangements a 17-year-old might make with respect to living, whether in a group situation or otherwise, are infinitely variable. I am not capable of giving an answer on precisely how I would budget that amount if I were in that position at that age. I was trying to explain to the Senate the factors which have been taken into account with respect to the setting of levels of benefit. If that is not what the honourable senator requires, I can only say that it is not possible for me to present a budget which would apply to any social security beneficiary, bearing in mind the infinitely variable situations in which such people find themselves.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health and concerns quarantine arrangements. I refer to the Australian rice industry and to the necessity to maintain continuing vigilance of Australia's quarantine barriers. Has it been brought to the Minister's attention that in the past week Mr Davidge , the Chairman of the Rice Growers Co-Operative Mills Ltd, said that he was deeply concerned that tests carried out in Sydney had revealed that samples of imported rice had contained wheat seed, dead insects and unmilled rice grains? He said the samples of foreign rice had up to six grains of unmilled rice a kilogram and that this unmilled grain could carry diseases such as blast and viruses which could destroy the $150m New South Wales rice industry. Can the Minister assure the Senate that there has been no lowering of quarantine barriers with regard to rice and that these recent allegations have been fully investigated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although Mr Davidge's comments have not been drawn to my attention, a week or two ago I did meet with representatives of the industry, who expressed concerns about these matters. I take it that they are the same concerns. The importation into Australia of unmilled rice is not permitted because of the potential it has to introduce diseases as set out in Senator Teague's question. Milled rice is allowed in. Certain standards are applied to ensure that it is safe. These include the fact that there should be no unmilled paddy grains. Standards are set. Five grains a kilogram is the upper limit of what is permitted for paddy grains in imported milled rice. Some rice has been imported recently about which concern has been expressed, but my officers have investigated this. They assure me that there has been no relaxation of standards , that the rice which was imported was tested under normal conditions, that it passed the test and that no sample contained more than the permitted number of paddy grains.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand some tests may have been carried out subsequently by the rice growers. There could have been a sampling problem. They said one of their samples showed six paddy grains a kilogram. We are going back and investigating the matter again. I think another matter of even greater concern was associated with this imported rice; that is, that some of it was taken by wholesalers into retail outlets inside the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is serious.

—That is serious. Taking imported rice into a rice growing area is prohibited. That, however, is a matter for the State administration of New South Wales. The Commonwealth is responsible for the quarantine arrangements at the port of entry. The rice in question met all quarantine requirements and passed all requirements. That it then got into the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area is a matter which I understand the authorities in New South Wales have addressed themselves to. They have impounded the rice. The regulations have been tightened up and the retailers and wholesalers are now aware of the situation. I add that although I can say again that all quarantine requirements have been complied with, the local industry now says that it can achieve a much higher degree of milling so that there is almost no paddy rice present in milled rice. We are investigating now whether our quarantine standards should be re-examined and maybe redrawn.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It refers to a statement by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence that the media misunderstood explanations on rearrangements for defence spending and the Prime Minister's attempt to explain the same to the Returned Services League national executive at a luncheon on 4 May. In view of the fact that the RSL National President, Sir William Keys, said after his meeting with the Prime Minister that the RSL was not reassured, when will the Government explain its defence spending plans in such a way that the RSL, the Australian media and the people of Australian can comprehend them?

—I think it was very useful for the Prime Minister to have discussions with the executive of the RSL. Naturally, it would have a particularly close interest in details of the matter. I was not present at the luncheon so I do not know of the matters about which Sir William Keys said he wanted further reassurance. However, I will refer that part of the question to the Minister for Defence to see whether he wishes to add anything to the answer. The fact of the matter is, as the Prime Minister pointed out and as I pointed out in answer to a question asked yesterday by Senator Lewis, that in this financial year there will be a 19 per cent increase in overall expenditure on defence compared with the figure for the previous financial year. That is the fact of the matter. I do not think anything more can be said to highlight the commitment of this Government to defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the Government's recently announced intention to create a national crimes commission and I refer more particularly to the following comments by the Prime Minister:

QUESTION.PARA: I believe that if the Commonwealth were to wait until it had the total agreement of all States, through either the Premiers Conference or the Attorneys -General conference, the youngest members here might be grey with age before that would be achieved.
I do not really believe that as a nation we have time for that . . .

Is the Minister aware that very effective co-operative working arrangements have been developed between the States and the Commonwealth in the last two years through the Australian Police Ministers Council? Is he further aware that the Council has established the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and is close to finalising agreement on a national police research unit? Inasmuch as no discussion or consultation took place with the States before the Prime Minister made his statement, is it his intention to set up a national crimes commission in consultation and co-operation with the State governments, which have considerable constitutional power in this area? Does he concede that the effectiveness of such a commission would be considerably diluted without proper Commonwealth-State consul- tation and co-operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that the Prime Minister has had some discussions with me and, I think, other interested Ministers in regard to a proposal for the establishment of a national crimes commission. The matter is being studied and a detailed report on the proposal will be made to the Cabinet in the near future. In the matter of a crimes commission as a matter of principle, the Commonwealth would be perfectly free to establish and could usefully establish a commission on its own account because there is an enormous responsibility for the administration of criminal law at the Commonwealth level. We only have to consider the nature of the Customs laws to realise that the drug area of crime is an enormous one for which the Commonwealth has, under its laws, a major responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: However, that having been said, the fact of the matter is that, ideally, law enforcement and the administration of criminal justice are matters which deeply involve the States. They have traditionally had responsibility for criminal justice and police investigation. The matter will certainly be discussed with the States when there is a sufficiently detailed proposal to discuss with them. No discussion has taken place with the States at this stage because the matter is only an idea in principle. The Cabinet has yet to finally consider and decide the form that the matter will take. It is far too premature to discuss the question with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the report of the committee chaired by Mr Murray Sainsbury which last year inquired into the operations of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act. Who has had the benefit or otherwise of this committee's findings? Has the report been confined to the Minister himself or have the members of the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped, for instance, been allowed to view the report and the findings of the committee and consider their worth or otherwise?

—The review referred to by Senator Grimes is again an internal departmental review. It has been used by the Department of Social Security in the course of examining the operations of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act , a process which I think commenced under my predecessor, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. That paper has not gone to NACH or to any body outside the departmental process. The review is still under way. In fact I was to see officers this week to discuss the review further. One result has flowed from it so far, that is, the change to payment in advance of subsidies under that Act. That change was of benefit to organisations receiving subsidies and was not a matter which required wide consultation. I had received many representations suggesting that that would be helpful to the organisations concerned. However, should there be substantive changes in our approach to the handicapped persons assistance program I certainly would envisage exploring those proposals with NACH and indeed with the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled before coming to any final decision on them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to reports that I read recently-I think they came from the United Kingdom-that methane gas generated by the rotting of organic material in old rubbish tips is being tapped and utilised for domestic and commercial needs. Could the Minister advise whether any studies have been done in Australia? If not, could studies be done on the possibility of using organic waste for the production of methane? If any of our larger rubbish tips are suitable, would it be viable for them to be tapped for domestic and commercial needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The use of methane from various sources is under consideration in this country and in many other countries. For example, I am advised that outstanding evidence of its use is that in China up to 90 million people in various communities use methane gas from human, farm and community wastes. That process would be capable of adaptation not only in developing countries but also in developed countries. In Australia coal seams are tapped for what is called firedamp-methane gas. The Australian Gas Light Co. is looking towards augmenting its Sydney supplies from the coal mines close by. In Germany methane is produced from garbage dumps and sewage waste decomposition. In West Germany there is a major undertaking in Schleswig-Holstein. The United Kingdom's Greater London Council and the National Coal Board are investigating tapping a 70-acre land fill site in Essex.

ANSWER.PARA: In Australia we produce methane from sewerage plants in Adelaide, Carrum near Melbourne, and at Malabar and Bondi in Sydney. The production meets the sewerage plants' own power requirements. There is only a limited surplus for gas purposes . Considerable methane could also be produced as a fuel supplement from food waste produced by Australia's canning industry and from intensive cattle and piggery operations. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is doing some research in each of these areas. A project on methane digesters has been funded under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council program. The use of biomass in any form, the use of renewable sources of energy, has enormous significance for the long term future because we should not be complacent about the present apparent surplus of oil. The methane from renewables could be a very valuable addition for the decades ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. The equal employment opportunity guidelines prepared by the women's employment committee of the National Labour Consultative Council and produced by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs were distributed first in February 1981. These guidelines were designed to apply to both government and private employment. Has the Government, therefore, set in train any process by which to assess to what extent Federal Government departments are taking the guidelines seriously and are moving towards their implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not able to deal with the detail that is required by Senator Giles in her question. I will seek it from the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs or from the Public Service Board, as appropriate, and see that she is advised about the matter.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry inform the Senate of the latest stage in the negotiations with the United States of America in relation to Australia's sugar exports to that country? Is there any truth in the rumour that last year's exports, which totalled 811,000 tonnes and thereby made the United States Australia's most important sugar export market, are likely to be reduced to under one half that level? If reductions are introduced, when will they apply and will they take into account any tonnage shipped this calendar year? Finally, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will do everything it can to protect the interests of the Australian sugar industry?

—I can assure the Senate of the Government's great interest in the Australian sugar industry and its concern about obtaining satisfactory markets for it, which is no easy matter. I do not, however, have the most up to date information on the state of negotiations with the United States of America . I will seek the information that has been requested from the Minister for Primary Industry and get an early reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the Prime Minister's electorate talk of 12 March 1978 in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of the Government.
Without integrity-without the appearance and reality of integrity-no government can hope to have the confidence of the people, or the trust of the people.
In respect of gifts from overseas countries to Ministers visiting those countries, the Prime Minister in his electorate talk went on to say:

. . . Ministers who receive gifts . . . must declare them to me as Prime Minister on their return. If gifts are more than token in nature, they are valued and Ministers are then given an opportunity to purchase.

The Prime Minister has refused to reveal details of those individual gifts and their values. Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate say which Ministers have taken up the opportunity to purchase? Can he say what happens to the gifts if the Minister does not take up that opportunity to purchase? Can he say what is the total value of the gifts paid for by Ministers, to which department the payments are made and under which heading in the Government's accounts those payments appear?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a clear procedure regarding gifts to Ministers . Ministers from time to time receive gifts- most of them quite small in value, some of them large in value. The Government has put a ceiling on the value of a gift that can be retained by a Minister. It is true also that if the value of the gift is beyond that amount the Government takes a valuation of it and the Minister is able to pay the difference. The alternative is--
—What is the ceiling? What is the amount?

—From memory, there are two amounts; I think one is $ 200. But I was about to say that I would get the precise amounts. There have been a number of variations recently. I will get those amounts. Where a Minister has a gift that is valued at more than the amount and does not desire to pay the difference, he hands that gift to, I think, the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I understand that a considerable collection of such gifts is held by the Government. Indeed, I have passed on gifts given to me because they exceeded the value and I was unwilling to pay the difference on them. I am not aware of the total value of the gifts. This has gone on over many years. They would be very hard to value in any case. Sometimes some gifts cannot be given a specific value.
—I asked for the total of the gifts paid for.

—Yes; I am sorry if I did not register that point. What I need to do is to find out that amount and also where the amount goes into the revenue and under what heading. I am told-and this again I will recheck-that the ceiling is $250 for gifts from governments and $100 for gifts from other sources . What is outstanding is not only the need to check that--
—The $250 slings from Edwards for the Country Party don't matter.

—Mr President, the fact is that I am being asked by Senator Coates about the total value of the money paid in. I will find out the amount over the various years and the line item in the revenue which picks it up . But the procedure is clearly laid down; it was laid down by this Government. I am not aware whether previous governments laid down such things. My understanding is that it is observed.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When Senator Sir John Carrick is obtaining that information, will he also attempt to provide a justification for setting a ceiling of $250 for an item which is token?
—For an item which is--?
—Well, the honourable senator is saying that anything under $250 is a mere token. Surely that is difficult to justify.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I said that, it was not what I meant to imply. The fact is that a gift from a government to a Minister which has a value under $250 may be retained by the Minister.
—Because it is only of token value? Is that what you are saying?

—No. It may be worth $5, $10 or $20. It may range from $1 up to $250. Honourable senators will know that some countries, particularly Japan, have a habit of giving gifts as part of their cultural and social background. With many of those gifts the giving is what is important, and they may be of relatively minor value. I am not suggesting that $250 is token value. I am saying that that is the limit put on the matter. If the value of the gift is above $250 and the gift is from a government, the Minister has the choice of paying the difference or surrendering the item. If it is over $100 from other sources, the same applies.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to a previous question I asked concerning the Minister's statement of 6 April that the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme would be extended to include air freight during maritime disputes and that details would be announced as soon as possible. Is the Minister yet in a position to tell the people of Tasmania how that subsidy extension will operate and when it will commence?

—I am advised that the Minister for Transport hopes that before this day is out and before the House of Representatives rises he will be able to provide the Senate with a copy of the notice to claimants detailing provisions for the subsidy payable under the scheme when air freight services are used in the circumstances outlined by Senator Walters. I understand that the general principle the Minister is employing is that, when both the Australian National Line and the Union Steam Ship Company of New Zealand Ltd general shipping has ceased to operate due to industrial disputation and the consignor has met the general eligibility requirements of the scheme, the amount of subsidy payable to the consignor will be payable in respect of the air freight of those goods. The Minister is currently clearing with all the appropriate Ministers the terms of the notice to claimants.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Do I understand correctly from the Minister's reply that the employees of both companies have to be out on strike at the same time? Is it not sufficient for the employees of the company which is the usual freight transporter to be out on strike?

—I understand that the arrangement is to apply when all shipping has ceased. This implies that the employees of both companies are to be out on strike. In order to clarify the matter for Senator Walters I will refer that question to the Minister for Transport and will communicate the answer to her directly.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of a film produced by Film Australia called Images of Man which documents one of the last remaining collections of Aboriginal rock art? This particular collection is in Arnhem Land. Can the Minister say what steps have been taken to distribute this film by selling it to either the Australian Broadcasting Commission or commercial television, or whether any plans have been made to allow the film to be distributed to our overseas missions?

—Recently I have had some interest in some of the Film Australia productions. In fact, I have seen some of them. But I am not aware of the film Images of Man. I undertake to obtain for the honourable senator the answer to the--
—You ought to see it some time. You will learn something.
—I look forward to seeing it. I shall obtain from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment for the honourable senator the answer to the several parts of her question.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows a question asked by Senator Coates. Can the Minister inform the Senate what records were kept of gifts received by Ministers in the previous Labor Government? Was a system similar to that presently in use for recording gifts and payments made used in those days? If any record was kept, can the Minister supply the relevant figures to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no such information. When I seek supplementary information for Senator Coates I will obtain that information for the honourable senator. I should have added that, from time to time, Ministers get a series of gifts. For instance, when I was Minister for Education I received gifts of a decorative or ceremonial value, such as plaques and even ornamental glasses. It is customary to give such gifts to the department or to the ministerial office to adorn that office. One would find this to be the experience of any Minister. These gifts are not regarded as the personal property of the Minister; they are regarded as a gift to the Minister in his role as the Minister holding that portfolio. I will ascertain the additional information sought in Senator Thomas' s question.

—Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to comments made on Monday of this week by the political scientist Dr Katherine West? Did he note the criticism by Dr West of the Government for its false claims-that is her expression-at the last Federal election about the so-called resources boom? Is Dr West right in saying that the mining industry had an obligation at the time to challenge the wild statements about resources development being made by Fraser Government Ministers? Was there any agreement between the Fraser Government Ministry and the mining industry to promote talk of a resources boom which both sides knew to be incorrect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see Dr West's comments as they were reported. Of course, the fact is that there was and there remains very substantial evidence of a significant increase in resources development in Australia. I have repeatedly pointed out that if, indeed, Senator Button is claiming that the Federal Government has exaggerated the degree of the resources development in Australia--
—It is Dr West, a member of the Liberal Party.

—The Leader of the Opposition now knows the course my answer will take. I want to say that the figures claimed by the Premier of New South Wales and published by him for his State are of a magnitude of two-thirds to three-quarters of the total figure for the whole of Australia claimed by the Federal Government. If there were an inference that the Federal Government was overstating, one would have to say that the publications by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party and Labor Premier of New South Wales are a gross distortion. Therefore the physician should cure himself.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to the current inquiry being undertaken by the Trade Practices Commission into the operation of Australia's stock exchanges. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether, as part of its inquiry, the Commission is considering the introduction of negotiable brokerage rates based on turnover? Does the Minister recognise that if the Commission recommends in favour of this discount system many Australian stock exchanges, with the exception of those in Sydney and Melbourne, will close? Does the Minister appreciate that the closure of the Adelaide Stock Exchange would be detrimental to South Australia as it would make it harder for companies to establish head offices there? As South Australia is entering a period of resource activity and many interstate companies are showing an interest in these State assets, will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the Government will discourage any action which could result in a downturn in activity or possible closure of the Adelaide Stock Exchange?

—It is true that one of the matters which the Trade Practices Commission is investigating is the question of brokerage based on turnover in respect of stock exchanges. The Australian Associated Stock Exchanges is seeking from the Commission authorisation for a provision allowing stock brokers to undertake this activity. If the fixing of brokerage rates is not authorised by the Trade Practices Commission on appeal to the Trade Practices Tribunal, brokerage rates will become a matter for negotiation between stock brokers and clients. The viability of any stock exchange depends not only upon this factor, of course, but also on a number of other factors. Recognising that the Trade Practices Commission's decision may affect the structure of the whole industry, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, pursuant to section 29 of the Trade Practices Act, directed the Trade Practices Commission, when deciding the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges' application, to give special consideration to, amongst other things, the desirability of the continued existence of stock exchanges in cities other than Sydney and Melbourne-of course , including Adelaide. I think Senator Jessop makes a significant point in respect of the forthcoming resource development in South Australia. I will bring it to the attention of the Minister and the Trade Practices Commission. It is one that ought to be taken into account.
—My question is addressed, I think properly, to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, although it may also concern the Minister representing the Minister for Defence.
—Make up your mind.

—The Ministers can make up their minds. In view of Press reports this morning that New Zealand is considering sending a frigate and an Orion patrol aircraft to the South Atlantic to assist British forces in that area, I ask: Has Australia been approached by Britain with a request to provide any materiel support for British forces operating in the Falklands area? Has the Australian Government offered to support in any way British forces operating in the South Atlantic? Can the Minister, or Ministers, give an absolute assurance that Australian forces will not be sent to aid British forces in the South Atlantic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a response.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, by saying that having a telephonist with local knowledge is vital to country people when they ring their local telephone exchange in emergency and natural disaster situations. Is it a fact that the Tweed Heads telephone exchange is due to be closed on 3 November? Is this one of the 16 telephone exchanges in New South Wales due to be closed in the near future? Did the Prime Minister intervene to prevent the Hamilton exchange in his electorate in Victoria being closed? Will special consideration be given to the Tweed Heads exchange which is in the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister? Will the Minister give urgent consideration to providing special assistance to Telecom in order that 16 country exchanges in New South Wales will not be closed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week a question was asked about the same matter . At that stage I laid down the principles which are behind the Government's actions and considerations in this area. The honourable senator asked particular questions about the Tweed Heads manual exchange and the exchange at Hamilton in Victoria. I will seek information on those matters and the other consequential questions which he asked. I remind honourable senators that the Government's aim in this area is to improve the service available to telephone subscribers and that automatic exchanges provide subscribers with extra capacities which they have not had before.

ANSWER.PARA: When Telecom is at a stage of having automatic exchanges ready to be put in, and before any changes are made in staffing, discussions are opened up with the local community. These include discussions with staff members who are likely to be affected. This is what Telecom has been doing in recent times. It has been holding discussions with the organisations representing the telephonists. It is as a result of those kinds of discussions that the telephonists have decided that it is proper to take their case to the public, to make their side of the case known. There is no concern on the Government's part that they should do this, but I emphasise again that the resolution of these issues is one step along the way to providing a better telephone service. Having said that, I undertake to obtain the extra information sought in the honourable senator's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. When is the Federal Government to provide its grant of $120, 000 for a survey of deep water trawling grounds off Tasmania announced recently by the Minister for Primary Industry? For what period is this amount of finance budgeted to last? How large an area is expected to be surveyed?

—The Minister for Primary Industry announced on 20 April that the Commonwealth Government would be making $120,000 available from its Fisheries Development Trust Account for a survey of deep water trawling grounds off Tasmania. The present proposal is to carry out the survey in the period from May to August 1982. Arrangements are presently in hand to pay the grant to the Tasmanian Fisheries Development Authority, which has the responsibility for supervising and planning the project. The grant should be spent by the completion of the project, which should be by about the end of August. The survey will cover the continental slope between 450 and 550 fathoms south of latitude 41 degrees 31 minutes south off the west and south coasts of Tasmania. I think I have given all the detail that was requested. In any case I have given all the detail that my brief provides.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AWARD IN HONOUR OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE HELLENIC REPUBLIC

Does he agree that the Prime Minister's inactivity after the announcement confirms the suspicion of many in the community that the award was a further instance of prime ministerial grandstanding for political purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject entirely the latter part of the honourable senator's question. The Prime Minister made an announcement, before a foreign head of state, that a particular award would be made, and it will be made. I do not have the particular details with me but I will find them out and let Senator Bolkus know.

—Has the Minister for Finance noted an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed 'Surprises in National Accounts' which reports that last year Australia benefited from an economic boom which was far greater than previously thought? The figures show that during 1981 Australia had its best growth rate since 1973. The growth rate in the gross domestic product, excluding the farm sector, was 5.4 per cent while the average for the industrialised world was 1.25 per cent, which means that Australia's rate was more than three times higher than the average. Can the Minister confirm these figures? If they are correct, is this not another proof that the Fraser Government's economic policies are more than properly directed and also that so-called experts and their predictions are mostly inaccurate and totally misleading and, in this way, are damaging confidence in the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did not see the article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald but I am aware of a Press release made by the Treasurer yesterday which referred to the national account estimates from the Australian Statistician. In that report there was an indication that there was strong economic growth in the December quarter. It also confirmed that there was strong wage growth and a squeeze on company profits. The figures on the growth in production were set out in the statement and in the Treasurer's comments. They showed that the real gross non-farm product is presently estimated to have increased by one per cent in the December quarter and by 4 per cent over the course of 1981. As I said, other comments were made with regard to wages and salaries and other matters.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to say that community expectations of the immediate economic outlook appear to have deteriorated perceptibly under the influence of an acceleration in domestic wage cost pressures and the prospect of a more protracted recession in the world economy. Some public commentary has gone to extremes of gloom which the Government rejects. Clearly, such commentary could not be supported by the latest figures for 1981. However, there can be no doubt that the task of managing the economy in the period immediately ahead will be more difficult than it has been for some time. It ought to be said that the Statistician cautioned that all estimates for recent quarters are necessarily subject to uncertainties and some estimates may be substantially revised as firmer data come to hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the base had not been revised it would have been 3.6 per cent.

— I am glad to have the honourable senator's information. The question raised by Senator Lajovic related to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald. I will see whether the Treasurer has further information on this matter to provide to the honourable senator and perhaps other honourable senators who may have the same interest in the matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION: QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

—On 25 March Senator McIntosh asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Health at that time, a question without notice concerning trafficking in the tranquilliser diazepam, otherwise known as valium . I have now been advised as follows: The honourable senator may be interested to learn that the World Health Organisation recently presented to the United Nations Narcotics Commission a report concerning the possibility of dependence to a number of drugs of the benzodiazepine group, including valium. The Commission, after studying the report, has requested WHO to make further inquiries and to present another report next year. Should the proposals of WHO be accepted eventually by the Narcotics Commission, this would probably have the effect of requiring countries that have ratified the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances to collect and report details of production, export and import of these drugs. Australia is a signatory to that Convention. I hope that information is of help to Senator McIntosh.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday Senator Tate sought the opportunity to debate a report, stocks of which were not readily available, namely, the National Energy Advisory Committee annual report 1980-81. I seek leave for this report to be debated pursuant to sessional order. I suggest that that report be the first report considered.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) for enabling me to speak to the 1980-81 annual report of the National Energy Advisory Committee. I have only a few words to say. It was impossible to speak to the report last week because it was not available to honourable senators at that time. The report is one of a number which come to the Government, and specifically to Senator Sir John Carrick as Minister for National Development and Energy, from this Committee, which is one of a plethora of committees which advise the Government on energy matters. But it is regrettable that, even with the great range and number of committees and expertise available to the Government, as can be readily seen by perusing the membership of the Committee outlined in the report, the Government is unable to produce a comprehensive policy, as has been produced and will be published by the Australian Labor Party in the very near future. Even with our very meagre resources the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party has put together a most comprehensive paper on energy and resources development issues facing Australia.
National Energy Advisory Committee
National Energy Advisory Committee
National Energy Advisory Committee
National Energy Advisory Committee
National Energy Advisory Committee

It is not my remark only which leads to the conclusion that the Federal Government has failed Australia in not producing a comprehensive paper covering all aspects of resources development in Australia; it is also the opinion of the Bank of America which, in its Economic Report of the Asia Division, dated 8 July 1981, concerning the effectiveness of Australia's energy policy, states that it has had three positive impacts-I acknowledge this: Firstly, import parity pricing of oil and its subduing of the demand for petroleum products; secondly, the introduction of natural gas into Sydney; and, thirdly, the upsurge in investment, which was then tabulated by the Government, in alternatives to transport fuels in particular. Whilst it had those three benefits, certain weaknesses were identified. The conclusion was that all in all, therefore, the Government's energy policy is fragmented and not without inconsistencies. This suggests that there is a pressing need for the formulation of a national energy plan covering both near term as well as long term problems and aspects. I simply say that that is the opinion of the Bank of America's Asia Division.

I am pleased to see that the Committee has produced some four or five major reports in the period up to mid 1981. In the time available to me I think I will comment on some aspects of two or three of them. One report is on alternative liquid fuels. It identifies, as is well known in this chamber, that whereas Australia, generally speaking, is energy resource rich, in the area of transport fuels, we certainly need to make investment decisions that will allow us, when the Bass Strait oil fields become depleted, to rely on our own indigenous sources for transport fuels rather than being dependent on the vagaries of overseas suppliers. To that extent, I must say that the report of the Committee, entitled 'Alternative Liquid fuels', although I have not read it in detail, is to be welcomed. It states:
The Government should, as a fundamental responsibility, ensure an investment climate conducive to the commercial development of alternative liquid fuels by the private sector . . .

Generally speaking I support that policy. But the Government should not artificially create a market situation, should not overly subsidise an earlier introduction of alternative transport fuels into the Australian mix than would be occasioned by the operation of market forces. We have already seen how the great predictions relating to shale oil, for example, have been severely retarded by the changes in market conditions. It is my view that the Government and its committees ought to be looking more closely at the possibility of methanol coming into the Australian transport fuel mix as an extender of our transport fuel resources or, indeed, as a substitute entirely in some vehicles. The Volkswagen organisation, which gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources about this matter, indicated that a lot of the fears which have been held as to the use of methanol were unfounded. I am talking of such things as the water content inducing phase separation. If seems to me-I have no doubt that the National Energy Advisory Committee could verify this-that fears as to phase separation have proved not to be as great as was originally thought. It may well be that rather than an alcohol extender of fuels being produced from vegetable products-in other words via ethanol-we should use our great resources of natural gas to produce methanol as a transport fuel for the future.

I refer now to another report entitled 'Motor Spirit: Vehicle Emissions, Octane Ratings, and Lead Additives-Further Examination'. It seems to me-without, once again, having had an opportunity to read its report-that NEAC has reversed an earlier opinion it held and has now become more sensitive to the health and environmental aspects of the problem of lead emissions. As honourable senators know, lead compounds are added to petrol to increase the octane rating thus enabling engines to operate with higher compression ratios which is turn are said to give better fuel economy. This also provides upper cylinder lubrication. The report of the Senate Standing Committee recommended that by varying the excise rate applying to standard and 92 octane petrol to establish a 2c or 3c incentive to use standard fuel-in other words, a lower octane rating fuel-we would be going some way to reducing the problem of the emission of lead salts in both gaseous and particulate forms. We recommended that a research project be established to determine the relationship between lead additives, fuel economy and exhaust emissions under normal usage, and said that it ought to be a matter of urgency. But reading between the lines of the annual report it appears that an unleaded strategy is the conclusion. In the report it is stated:
An unleaded strategy would therefore be appropriate if emission standards were set to meet the National Health and Medical Research Council's recommended long term guidelines.
That seems to be an admission that, when determining how most efficiently to use our meagre transport fuels, perhaps health and environmental considerations have to be given some priority.

Finally, the report entitled 'Nuclear Power in Australia: Regulation and Control' concluded that legislation, regulation and inspection functions should be identified and responsibilities for these assigned before nuclear electricity generation proceeds in Australia. Whilst in no way wanting to indicate anything other than Australian Labor Party policy in this regard, it has been clearly stated by Labor Party spokesmen in this chamber over the last four years since I became a member of this chamber that it is imperative that the Government clearly separate for legislative attention the various aspects of the nuclear industry that might be undertaken in Australia. At the moment the legal framework within which the uranium industry in Australia operates is based on a 1950s piece of legislation which was designed when uranium was mined in Australia to fuel the nuclear weapons programs of our allies. Therefore, particularly in relation to civil liberties, for example, it has a quite different and contrary thrust to that which one would expect were uranium being mined, as it is claimed, for peaceful purposes for the production of electricity . Given that the goal is that Australia's uranium energy resources should be used in future for the generation of electrical energy for peaceful purposes, it is imperative that the Government-the Minister ought to be able to tell us when legislation will come into this place-provide that legal framework that is so necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate has referred to the report of the National Energy Advisory Committee and has made a number of comments about it. It would not be possible for Senator Tate to evaluate that report properly and indeed the whole work of the Government without his having studied each of the reports that NEAC has produced over the years and the work of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council and other bodies. I commend them to Senator Tate and honourable senators. Senator Tate referred also to some comments made by the Bank of America. He ought to look at the repeated comments of the International Energy Agency, which has more expertise in this matter, and which encompasses, for comparable values, the work of the other 20 member nations, being the key developed countries of the free world. He will find that the International Energy Agency has very substantially praised Australia for its overall policies.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested by Senator Tate that Australia does not have a comprehensive policy. I refute that entirely. I will put forward four tests of the long term balance of any energy policy. Firstly: That what we do is conserving the energy resources we have, particularly the petroleum ones; secondly, that there is created a stimulus to substitution to get off petroleum, particularly oil, and on to other sources; thirdly, that there should be exploration; and, fourthly, that there should be a use of synthetics, including renewables. On every single test of those principles our policies are working, and working very well indeed.

The International Energy Agency has said that the primary test for any energy policy of any country must be that it should charge its petroleum products at world scarcity prices-that is, import parity pricing. Australia has done this. Australia has been able to provide petroleum products at a price less than half that which is operating in most European countries and in Japan.

Senator Tate raised the matter concerning the conservation of fuel. Clearly there has been conservation. Anyone who tries to test these things should know, for example, that the arrangements with the automotive industry are working well . We have an arrangement whereby more fuel efficient vehicles will be produced; there will be a fuel savings of some 12 per cent by 1987. In 1979 an average vehicle consumed 11.2 litres of fuel every 100 kilometres. Its consumption will be reduced to 9 litres by 1983 and 8 litres by 1987. It is now 1982 and the average is below 10 litres and, therefore, well on the way to nine. We see a major movement in that direction.

Honourable senators would also be aware of this Government's liquefied petroleum gas policy and the conversion of vehicles and the huge potential conversion, particularly of commercial vehicles, if the necessity arises to LPG. Liquefied petroleum gas is provided at a rate very competitive with petrol. In Canberra, 90 per cent of taxis are using LPG; in Melbourne 80 per cent; in Sydney something like 70 per cent; and in Brisbane a growing percentage. It is possible, when there is not the complacency of the present temporary glut, for LPG to absorb some 14 per cent of the transport fuels. I say this against the fact that Senator Tate said that there was no real plan for the long term assurance of transport fuels. My Department has indicated in a variety of publications that, whereas in 1978-79 it was believed that there would be a considerable falling off over this decade and through to the end of the century in the supply of indigenous oil, now there is some quiet confidence that there could even be a levelling out during this decade.

Honourable senators will know that again there is some cautious optimism in oil exploration. In substitution, the development of gas pipelines throughout Australia has gone on apace. The linking of Young, Cootamundra and Wagga Wagga and subsequently, we hope, Albury; the extension of the Dalton pipeline to Canberra; the potential extension to Lithgow, Bathurst and Orange; the virtual completion of the Sydney-Newcastle pipeline; and the foreshadowing of the pipeline from the North West Shelf to Perth are all major substitutions. The drop in the consumption of fuel oil in Australia has been spectacular. Substitution has gone on apace in Australia. Exploration is at all time record levels. Whilst one can never be optimistic on a continent the size of Australia, the fact of the matter is that one in four wildcat wells being drilled at this moment are producing evidence of oil. There have been very significant discoveries of gas. Exploration has been at a very great level.

The International Energy Agency is recorded as saying that the incentives that Australia offers to exploration companies could scarcely be improved upon. Those were the words used by the IEA. Of course, policies can be improved but one should look at these matters in a broad way. Step by step it is true that it would be desirable for more progress to be made throughout the world in connection with synthetic crudes produced from coal, shale or biomass. The simple fact is that it is very difficult to persuade any commercial venture to take a project through to its commercial point at a time when the real price of natural oil in the world is falling. Nevertheless, by arrangement with the Americans, the Japanese and others, we in Australia are having the technology of synthetic crudes taken to a point at which the lead time for bringing on a commercial undertaking could be halved in the likelihood of the need to do so. For example, a shale plant that might take eight years to develop would involve a pilot plant and general feasibility studies for four years and another four years of actual construction before it came on stream. One hopes to halve this lead time with shale and coal.

A very considerable amount of development is going on into alternative fuels- the renewable fuels, such as ethanol and others. Senator Tate mentioned methanol . It is quite feasible to take natural gas-provided that one is assured that one has enough of it-and turn it into methanol. It is quite possible for automotive vehicles to run on methanol. Senator Tate raised one problem, that of methanol's water compatibility. That is one matter that is being looked at. Another problem is that methanol does not like plastic parts; in a vehicle there would be a need for substitution in that regard. There are no great difficulties. Senator Tate would be aware, I think, of the Maui gas process in New Zealand where Australia is looking over the shoulder of the New Zealand Government and the Mobil people in the development of a plant to take natural gas, convert it to methanol and then to gasolene. Indeed, a very great deal is being done at this moment. The subject is, of course, far too big for comment in a simple paper. I make these comments just to show that a great deal is being done. Finally, on the nuclear situation, I draw attention to my reply to a question yesterday. We are well advanced on work to bring in a new atomic energy Act to bring about the regulation of nuclear fuels.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
