SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to say just a few words on the report. For too long the fisheries subject has been treated in a very offhand way. Responsibility for fishing is divided up between the Federal and State governments-each has legislation to cover its various areas. It has been unfortunate in the past that much of the legislation has not interlocked.

The Australian fishing industry is not a very big industry. It is a worthwhile industry if safeguarded. If any area is over-fished the industry simply will be lost. Because of the nature of the country the Australian fishing industry could never be a major industry, as it is in overseas countries. We have not managed our fishing very well in the past, nor have we treated the fishermen with any respect. They should be on the same footing as people in other industries. Agricultural industry has been given a lot of help in the past but the fishing industry has received very little help. It receives very little help in getting finance to build the boats that are needed. We are now allowing foreigners to come in to fish in deep waters, in the blue water. I believe the fishing industry should be better supported by government than it is. Fishermen are paying a very high interest rate-something like 20 per cent-to build ships that will cost from $1m to $1.5m. We will not be able to encourage the fishermen to build the ships if they are not protected.

We allow foreigners to fish in our waters, especially for tuna and squid. There is not enough scrutiny to see that the foreign fishing vessels take only the large fish. They are taking the juvenile fish before those fish are allowed to reproduce. This will eventually destroy the whole of the fishing industry. I believe that it is in Australia's interest to encourage Australian fishermen. A 200-mile limit is now in effect off the Australian coast. The Australian fishermen should be the eyes of the Australian Government. If we encouraged more of our own people to fish in the deep waters off the continental shelf we would probably restrict the smuggling of drugs and other materials into this country. We are quite capable of building and maintaining a reasonable fishing fleet; in fact, we could probably build more than we would ever need.

I believe that it is important for the State and Federal governments to get together concerning many areas off the Australian coast. Because of differences in legislation areas have been fished out. In my own State of South Australia, because Federal legislation has allowed Commonwealth registered boats to fish for juvenile prawns, the number of prawns in St Vincent's Gulf is being depleted at a very fast rate. I think this is unforgivable. I think there has to be uniform legislation which contains some sense. Fish do not care whether waters are federally controlled or State controlled; it is the fishing industry that I am concerned about. It is the fishermen that we should protect. We need industries such as this. They operate in outports where work is not plentiful and they can generate a lot of work in those areas. I believe that if the industry operated on a more scientific basis, if long term help were provided for our fishermen, great benefits could be derived for this country. I will not close the debate as I know that some of my colleagues want to say something about this industry. I ask the Government to consider seriously in consultation with State governments, the enactment of sensible legislation that will protect this industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to speak to the resolutions of the eleventh meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council held in Adelaide, South Australia. I support my colleague Senator Elstob in what he has said about the problems that exist in the fishing industry, particularly in our own State of South Australia, which has a very big industry. It is a great dollar-making industry because of the exports, particularly of lobster, from that State. Our colleague Mr Wallis has in his electorate of Grey a very good fishing industry which operates from Ceduna to Port Lincoln, where there is a huge fishing fleet. The Australian Labor Party resources committee held a meeting in Port Lincoln some years ago and, learning of the problems associated with the fishing industry, had a discussion here and recommended to the Senate that an inquiry be held into the fishing industry. I am hopeful that when that inquiry is completed and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce is tabled in this Parliament there will be a better understanding of the problems of the fishing industry and that the government of the day will take heed of the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know how far along the track the Committee is with its inquiry. Sentor Elstob and I had the pleasure of being invited to the public hearings which were conducted last year in Port Lincoln and Adelaide. We participated in the inquiry , as honourable senators are allowed to do even though they are not elected members of the committee concerned. We took the opportunity of saying a few words at the inquiry. As I said, I am hopeful that when the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce tables its report in the Senate it will contain some very worthwhile recommendations to the Government. If the Government acts upon them we might be able to solve many of the problems that exist in the industry at present.

Looking at the States that were represented at the meeting on 25 September, I note that there have been some changes of Ministers since it took place. Mr Rodda, who was the South Australian Minister of Fisheries at that time, is no longer the Minister, having resigned his portfolio. I am not sure who is the South Australian Minister at present. Of course, because of the recent massive win by the Australian Labor Party in the Victorian election, Mr Houghton is no longer the Minister for Fisheries in that State. A Labor member now represents that State at these Council meetings. I am sure that the Victorian member will make a very worthwhile contribution in an endeavour to solve the problems which have existed in the fishing industry for quite a long time. As my colleague Senator Elstob pointed out, there needs to be some assistance in the building of fishing boats, which is very costly. If we are to compete with overseas people, particularly the Japanese and Taiwanese who came into our waters, sometimes with permits but most times without-particularly the Taiwanese-and take out only the best of the fish--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not too many without permits now.

—I am not aware of that, but now that the honourable senator has reminded me, I will have to look at the strictures that are imposed upon people who get permits to fish in our waters to see whether they are issued at the expense of our own local fishermen and whether they are suffering because permits are being offered to overseas companies. We know that the Australian taxpayer in the past has been put to very great expense because the naval ships have to apprehend the Taiwanese boats. I have asked many questions, both at Estimates committee hearings and in the Parliament, about whether we are fully compensated for the cost of the naval vessels having to apprehend these people and take them to court where they are fined. I have expressed the view in the past that the fines imposed are not heavy enough to deter people who do not have permits from raping our fishing grounds. This is to the detriment of the Australian fishermen. As a true Australian I have said at all times, and I say again, that we should be protecting our own people and our own industries. If there is anything left, let other countries have a slight serve of it; but until our own people are properly protected we should not allow these people to come into our fishing waters.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I look forward to the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce. I hope that some time before the end of this year Senator Archer, the Chairman of the Committee, will table the report and that people, particularly from South Australia such as Senator Elstob and I, who have always had a great interest in the industry, will have the opportunity to make some comments upon it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the same subject for a moment or two to highlight my concern with respect to the netting practices that are carried out in the northern Spencer Gulf area which, after all, is a spawning area for fish. A lot of local concern has been expressed over a long period that people come to this area with nets and take by that method all the fish that are available. It seems to me that it is important that governments take a serious interest in this matter. I realise that it is a matter that comes under State jurisdiction. Nevertheless, I think I ought to remind the Senate that these spawning areas are of vital significance to the areas that were referred to by my colleagues on the Opposition side.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently the State Government introduced measures that require limitation of netting in certain parts of the gulf. I do not think they go far enough. I believe that the idea is to have a trial period of 12 months to see whether it is a successful operation. I noticed the other day that the State Government is advertising for a helicopter to survey the area. I think that is a good thing. The area could be surveyed at night. The authorities would use the 'midnight sun ' spotlight device that has been perfected. This may discourage indiscriminate and illegal netting. Of course, fishermen generally net during the night or in the wee small hours of the morning when there are not many people about. I think it is important that those concerned about this matter act as surveillance people as it is in their own interests to preserve the fishery. If anyone is seen transgressing and netting in areas where netting is forbidden he ought to be reported. I look forward with great interest to seeing how this trial period goes. But I think, although it is a State matter, we quite properly should take an interest in it because it has far reaching effects on the South Australian fishing industry as a whole.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Government Response to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak briefly to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I will go through the recommendations and make some comments on them. The first recommendation is that an inquiry be made into the capability for expansion of the defence forces. This is a really crucial question. I am disappointed with the Government's response on this issue. The core force concept is the concept in vogue, quite strongly, with all three Services at present. One wonders what it does really mean. Basically, according to the Services, it is the capacity to retain certain skills that can be expanded in time of need. I wonder, in today's age, how much time one has. Obviously we cannot reject a core concept out of hand; it has to be severely qualified. But the requirement of this country is to have resources instantly at hand to cope with the needs as we see them. Inevitably, that means that there has to be some risk taking. We cannot cover all eventualities; it is a matter of judgment. we have to accept that we run some risk in defence. We have to live with that, but be flexible enough to change as the need arises and the environment changes.

The other thing about a core concept is that the same level of readiness is not applicable to all three Services. Quite obviously, in the case of the Royal Australian Air Force there has to be an instant capacity for air superiority because if we cannot guarantee air superiority we will not be able to move on the surface, whether it be on land or sea, in time of hostilities. We cannot wait to develop that capability. Probably the lowest requirement for a core force concept is in the Army, although there again we have to be able to put forces into any area of Australia's responsibility-whether it be Cocos Island, Broome or Weipa-in 24 hours. We cannot allow forces to come in and consolidate. We have to be able to put something in to dig them out and kill them off within a very short time. Obviously, in regard to the Army the numbers involved are beyond the maintenance of a standing force. The great need in Australia today is to reform the Army Reserve and to get the Reserve to a level of operational readiness at which it can move in about 10 to 14 days. That should not be a difficult goal for us at all if we address it properly. For that we have to have a complete rethink of how we run the Army Reserve. We have to assign tasks to it . We have to organise it on the basis of being a functional service.

The second recommendation of the Committee deals with more support for local industry in the face of overseas purchases. The only point I make about that is that it is time the Government abolished the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. That enormous scientific resource in this country is second only to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. It employs about 3,000 scientists and, quite simply, it is not a cost-effective organisation for use. What the Government needs is an advisory scientific body so that impartial, objective advice can be provided to the Department of Defence on weapons systems. But the business of research and development of the weapons systems should be taken entirely out of the hands of DSTO and put into two different areas. Firstly, basic research should be done by the universities. The universities research programs, as everyone knows, are underfunded at present. The hard core science and engineering faculties would benefit enormously if the money at present spent by DSTO on basic research was put into the Australian universities. The applied research, the development of weapons systems, should go to private industry which has the resources and the ability to cope in these high technology areas. We are wasting an enormous resource by persisting with the DSTO.

I say in passing in relation to the second recommendation that quite clearly we have come unstuck with the support programs for the Leopard tank and for the Invincible with regard to offsets. Krauss Maffei, the producer of the Leopard tank, is an assembler. It is not a prime producer. Support for the Leopard tank is very difficult because all the subcontractors who came and supported Krauss Maffei at the time simply do not want to know about Australia and they do not want to honour the obligations that they should have entered into with regard to offsets in that purchase. Recommendation 3 gets back somewhat to the core force concept and the nature of the forces themselves. One of the topical things at present is the anti-submarine warfare capacity of both the Air Force and the Navy. Quite frankly, I do not know what the answer is. I do not know whether we have the right balance in this country, whether we are putting too much resource into one area and what that priority should be. But these are areas that I think will benefit from further discussion.

Recommendations 4 and 5 deal with the acquisition times for equipment. The basic issue in this area is that weapons systems and defence capabilities are long term requirements. They last for much longer than the life of a parliament. In this parliamentary democracy we must find a way of looking at large capital expenditures and relating them to a need over a time cycle that is longer than the life of a parliament. Obviously we need some flexibility in that but the long term view has to be taken because the funding is now so enormous.

The reference to bipartisan, bilateral support from both sides of the chamber is most important. It is something I have unswervingly supported in all of the speeches on defence that I have made in this place. I have never scored political points off the Opposition on the matter of defence because I think it is far too important for that. It is a matter of the national security. The important point with the bilateral and bipartisan support is that discussion takes place. In the four years that I have been in this chamber there has been very little informed discussion on the two huge purchases we have made-the new tactical fighters and the Invincible. Debate has been quite minimal. I think one of the ways of addressing that is to reform and modify our committee system in the Senate because it is the only place, really, where informed debate can take place in any detail.

We should get rid of the present Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and hive off foreign affairs to one committee and have a Senate armed services committee in the way the United States does to look at specific defence matters. There are problems with that but I would see that committee being a valuable acquisition of the Parliament. It would allow us to call experts to put the cases both for and against equipment that was projected to be bought by the Executive Government of the day. Obviously we have problems when we get into highly technical areas and obviously, again, we have problems with confidential or secret information, but neither of those problems are insuperable. They are problems we have to tackle. Recommendation 7 deals with procurement. There is a general feeling that the procurement procedures of the Department of Defence are very involved and entail far too many committees and too long a period. I hope the Utz committee comes up with a recommendation which streamlines that process. I think the proposition that the purchasing of defence equipment be a function of the Department of Defence is common sense and long overdue.

The final recommendation deals with the procurement of weapons. I think there is a great case to be made for developing more Australian weapons systems. We live in a particular geographic environment with marked climatic and other environmental differences from northern Europe. Most weapons systems in both the Western and Soviet spheres of influence are optimised for the northern European climate. I believe that Australian industry has the capacity to devise and design weapons at a lower and more manageable research and development cost than that of the United States or Europe. I believe that in developing more Australian weapons our security would be enhanced because we would have better performance from those weapons systems and, most importantly, because they are Australian produced and because Australia will never be an offensive threat to any of the super powers, we would be guaranteed some protection from the development of electronic counter measures and all the counters automatically provided by Russia or the United States to existing weapons systems. Whatever the rights or wrongs of this report on the Government response, I welcome it because it is a most opportune time to look at our defence capacity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES BOARD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The matter of research and development has been worrying me for a considerable time. Recently I asked the relevant Minister a question which suggested that the Government become involved with greater interaction between industry and universities in the form of joint research grants. At the same time I suggested that it should provide additional funds for university projects. Senator MacGibbon pointed out a couple of underfinanced areas-science and engineering- in some of the universities. Funding of those areas could help with regard to research and development in this country. Of course, the Commonwealth provides recurrent funds to universities and colleges of advanced education in the form of block grants on the advice of the Tertiary Education Commission.

As autonomous bodies, established under State legislation, universities and colleges of advanced education make their own decisions as to the detailed allocation of funds amongst various activities. The level of funding for certain courses is, quite rightly therefore, a matter for the institution. But the Commonwealth does not provide funds for individual courses. I am not sure whether that policy should remain. There is a lot of room for development of Australia's maximum potential level of research and development. This should be done in support of the creation of new industries based on science and high technology because it is vital to our economic and social growth. I propose that this development could be accelerated by fostering a greater interaction between industry and tertiary institutions through the management and allocation of government grants for industrial research and development.

I do not always agree with Mr Hayden-in fact I very rarely do-but in a speech in the House of Representatives on 21 October last year he suggested that a national research development and innovation corporation should be set up to administer grants for industrial research and development, to co-ordinate government-supported research and development programs for manufacturing industry, to advise the Government of ways to improve Australian industry through technological innovation and to direct the Government's support to programs which increase the ability of Australian-owned firms to capitalise on new industrial technology. I am not sure whether we really need a corporation set up to do that, but if one were set up it could be responsible for the allocation of research and development grants to both tertiary institutions and industry. As such, it would be in a position to offer more efficient management of the funds which are to be allocated in the future. Firstly it could give special consideration to grant applications which foreshadow the involvement of staff and facilities of tertiary institutions in conducting individual industrial research and development grants; secondly, it could urge the business community to invest and participate in research perhaps by endowing chairs to universities and institutes of technology; thirdly, it could create a semi- competitive atmosphere in which educational institutions should be prepared to assess the quality of their performance at a research level; and, fourthly, it could encourage industry by means of incentive for grants to pursue a greater interaction with these tertiary research establishments.

At present tertiary institutions are not eligible for IR and D grants under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme, but they can take on, under contract, research work for companies that are eligible. I believe they should be encouraged to do just that. The business community should be encouraged also to contract out research work to these institutions through incentives for such grants and the management of the grants. In the magazine Search for February and March 1982 it was stated:

In 1979, as a result of discussions between the Australian Industry Research Group (AIRG) and the Inter-University Committee on Research (IUCR), two listings of research topics were distributed: Basic Research of Relevance to Australian Industry, which gave 106 research topics which could usefully be investigated in universities; and Industrial Research Projects Available in Australian Industry, which gave 27 potential special studies programs for academics willing to work for a time in industrial laboratories. It was hoped that, in addition to action on those particular subjects, the result would be improved interaction between universities and industry in general.
Referring to Professor Birt, who is the Chairman of the IUCR, it stated:
. . . the response to both documents was disappointing, writes Professor Michael Birt, Chairman of IUCR.

. . . the newspaper of the University of New South Wales (of which Professor Birt is Vice-Chancellor). Nevertheless, AIRG and IUCR have not abandoned hope of some progress in this frequently recommended direction. 'Accordingly, it is proposed to circulate within universities in the near future further information about basic research of interest to industry and special studies opportunities in industrial organisations . . .
That was said by Professor Birt. The article continued:

Professor Birt has no criticism of the University of New South Wales, which ' has an enviable record of effective interaction with Australian industry', although there he believes it might be possible to do better.

It is possible for industry to co-operate with universities. I believe that it is something that should be promoted by the Government. In view of the time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard page 31 of a report by the Australian Science and Technology Council to the Government. It is just a formal document. It makes some recommendations along the lines of which I have been speaking.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Performance of Fundamental Research Projects of Interest to Industry and Tertiary Education Institutions

5.29 Initiatives by the Australian Industrial Research Group (AIRG) to generate enthusiasm in universities and colleges for research projects of interest to industry have been only moderately successful to date (see Appendix A). One reason is that no financial incentive is provided. ASTEC supports the proposed AIRG program as a means of aligning a proportion of academic R&D activities with industry, but suggests that some incentive is needed for the individual academic . The Council has examined the Special Co-operative Research Grants program operated by the Science Research Council (SRC) in the UK (see Appendix B); this is an effective mechanism for encouraging closer links between industry and higher education. Not only would this increase interaction between universities and industry, but it would also be an appropriate program for encouraging interaction with colleges of advanced education where staff should have a greater involvement in applied R&D.

5.30 After examining the most appropriate means of introducing the scheme into Australia, ASTEC has concluded that such a program would best be implemented as a grants sub-program of the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives (AIRDI) program, with any necessary amendment of the Australian Industrial R&D Incentives Act. The awarding of such grants might subsequently lead to program grants rather than project grants and could eventually have the effect of establishing industrial co-operative research centres, not dissimilar from the UK's experience with the Marine Technology Directorate. ASTEC believes that such co-operative research grants should be made relatively more attractive than the usual AIRDI project grant, and this could be done either by allowing companies involved to receive more than the 50 per cent of total project costs currently met by the AIRDI scheme, or by setting aside a proportion of AIRDI funds for the co-operative grants. The Council believes that, following a study of the operation of the UK Science Research Council's Special Co-operative Research Grants program, a pilot program needs to be established under the AIRDI Act. In the first instance, an amount of approximately $0.5m per annum is suggested, sufficient to support 10 to 20 major projects.

ASTEC recommends: That a pilot program of co-operative research grants be established under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976 (amended as necessary), taking into account the operations of the UK Special Co-operative Research Grants program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, there is one matter I believe the Government should take note of. It is a final point about research and development which I think is important. It concerns the overall objectives of government and private industry. It seems that on the whole, while private industry is in business to make profits, governments should not necessarily be concerned with the overall well-being of the profit side of the matter; they should be more concerned with the overall well-being of the nation. In terms of research and development investments, these aims do not always coincide. A little later in the day I hope to be saying something about the amount of money that is being spent by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. In that area too I believe this country-not necessarily the Government-needs to be prepared to put up money to keep research going at a rate that is suitable for getting the best out of the technological advances that are so common now around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to make a few comments regarding the activities of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. In the Department's annual report it is stated that the tabling of the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions was an event of major importance for the Commonwealth Employment Service in 1980-81. I would like to consider two of the recommendations of the so called razor gang which I believe seriously reduce the quality of services and information provided by the Department. The first of these is the abolition of the CES statistics. It is quite obvious that the CES data series was discontinued simply because it was politically embarrassing to the Government. Time and again the CES figures showed a higher unemployment level than the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures and, as such, were closer to the real level of unemployment, which at present is around 800,000.

We all know that the Government has done everything possible to hide the true level of unemployment in this country. The abolition of the seasonally adjusted figures was the first step and now we have the complete abolition of the very useful CES data series. The CES figures, like the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, were not deadly accurate. Nevertheless, they were very useful for showing regional and occupational variations in the labour market. The CES figures were the only ones which gave in any detail the level of unemployment in particular regions and in particular occupations. They were regularly used by manpower planners to calculate the unemployment rate in specific occupations and over time provided very useful information for researchers. Now there is nothing available to measure the variations in occupational demand, information which is essential for effective manpower and economic planning. In Britain the Department of Employment regularly publishes very comprehensive figures on unemployment, both on a regional basis and on an occupational basis. Surely this can be done in Australia, especially with the advent of the job bank computer system in 1983-84.

Another recommendation of the razor gang on which I want to comment is the abolition of the professional employment offices. The professional employment offices, or PEOs as they were known, provided a very efficient and highly successful placement service for professional people. They were originally established because it was felt that the ordinary CES offices and their staff were not equipped to handle the more complex needs of unemployed professional people. As a result, staff were specifically trained to interview professional people and to provide a unique placement service for the employers of professionals at no cost to either the employer or the job seeker. The provision of this free service was in line with the recommendations of the International Labour Organisation.

In its last year of operations, the PEO had established such a high reputation with employers that it was taking a lot of business away from the private employment agencies. It is a well-known fact that these agencies put pressure on the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, to get rid of the PEO and that eventually the Minister succumbed to this pressure. There is no other reason why the razor gang would have abolished such a very efficient and successful operation.

No doubt business in the private employment agencies has been booming since the abolition of the PEO. At the same time, unemployed professional people have been forced to go to the CES district offices for assistance. I suspect that very few of them have been placed by the CES since May last year-certainly many fewer than were placed in the previous 12 months. In fact, I asked the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who represents the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown), a question on notice for figures on this but because compilation of CES statistics was abolished around the same time, he could not tell me how many professionals had been placed by the CES between May 1981 and May 1982. I think this is a national disgrace.

How can an organisation such as the CES function without these sorts of figures ? How does it know how many staff it needs to allocate to interview professional people if these sorts of figures are not available? It is pretty obvious that the razor gang's decision to abolish CES statistics and the PEO was nothing more than a cheap political manoeuvre. Those decisions must be reversed if this country is to develop an effective manpower planning system. How can this Government ever hope to solve the nation's worsening unemployment situation if it is not prepared to provide the basic tools for manpower planning?

All that this Government has done is provide an expensive array of training schemes, although it is interesting to note that expenditure on all manpower training and support programs has fallen by 50 per cent in real terms since the Fraser Government came to power. That shows about the extent of this Government' s concern for the unemployed.

Many of the programs administered by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs are very useful and provide the only means for many disadvantaged people to improve their job skills. Schemes such as the Community Youth Support Scheme, education programs for unemployed youth and other school to work transition programs all play a vital role and have assisted many young people throughout Australia. However, unless these people have jobs to go to, I am afraid that a lot of this money will be wasted. Between now and 1985, 650,000 jobs need to be created in Australia just to maintain the present unemployment rate, which of course is unacceptable anyway.

In view of the bust of the so-called resources boom and the slow-down in retail sales and in our manufacturing industries, it is hard to see exactly where these jobs will come from. Unless this Government changes its economic course and develops more effective long term manpower planning I am afraid our young people will be facing a very dim future. Even in West Germany, Chancellor Schmidt has recently announced a huge job creation program to try to stem the rising unemployment rate in that country. Perhaps Australia could develop a similar program or at least the Government could send some officials from the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs to examine the operation of the program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to comment briefly on three aspects of the report of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. The first matter to which I shall refer is community based schemes. The Australian Democrats reiterate that we were pleased to see that the Community Youth Support Scheme had survived. We commend the Government on its wisdom in relenting in this matter and authorising the retention of the scheme. We have doubts and concerns about whether the Government yet realises the scheme's importance and the necessity not of cutting it back but of extending it. I wish I could believe that the Government understood how deeply this program is supported in the community. I think that is one of the more important aspects of the scheme. I think probably the only reason why the Government kept the scheme was that it got some inkling of that support. I hope that the Government has taken the lesson seriously to heart. I believe that CYSS is a basis which could and should be built on much more extensively. Senator Foreman touched on that matter, of course, in his comments.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great need in Australia for a community-based organisation that takes into account the problems of those young people who have had no work experience, who apparently have no chance of ever getting a job because of that and whose confidence about even being able to get a work situation has disappeared. This is a semi-permanent problem. I suggest to the Government that it should look closely at some scheme which is based on the community, and which , indeed, could be based on CYSS, to try to cope with that problem and see that there is a training element and some sort of organised group activity in which these young people could work with their peers. This seems to me to be one of the most essential things that the country needs. While I am on this subject I point out that I find it very disturbing that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) seems to be the absolute arbiter as to whether any individual CYSS program has the right to continue to exist. It seems to us that it would be far more reasonable if there were some system of appeal in the case of any centre being refused funds and so closed down. At present, even if a CYSS centre feels that it can put up an excellent case for retention it is denied the right to put that case forward. I am looking at several cases now in New South Wales which are of this nature.
I refer now to the School to Work Transition Program. We were delighted to read in the report that the basis of the Department's school to work transition policy is:

. . . recognition that the vocational preparation received by the majority of school students can be substantially improved and that the education system needs to become better geared to the vocational needs of young people in the changing circumstances of the 1980s . . .

This, of course, is something which is to be applauded. The Australian Democrats wholeheartedly agree with it. It seems in that connection a pity that the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions was apparently unaware of this policy or did not take it into account when it abolished the Curriculum Development Centre and the Education Research and Development Committee, terminated special support for educational research and scaled down the research activities of the Department of Education. It makes one wonder what kind of governmental activity we have where pious utterances are made in one direction and then we find that when they are construed to a level of action something quite different is done.

I make a brief comment on a little publicised scheme-NESA, the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals. I feel that it is something with which we could do a lot more. I am specifically interested in this section of the report, as, indeed, other senators would be, since I have had two NESA trainees employed in my office. Both were found to be keen, hard workers who went on to excellent jobs which they held after they left my office. I must say that this is very much to the credit of those people. Once they were given their heads and given confidence and work that they could do we found that they went from strength to strength. This scheme is obviously going well. I believe it should be expanded and more widely advertised and publicised among employers many of whom, we found , have heard about it only by chance. One particular concern to me is that although my first NESA trainee was allowed to travel to Canberra to see how Parliament functions and to see how my office here is set up-this is a necessary part of learning something-this travel was denied to my second NESA trainee although I felt is was a necessary part of her training. For some reason the Government has done some mad economy thing which, as is always the case with these minor economies, tends to destroy completely or to harm seriously the total value of the program. Finally, I urge the Minister to reconsider this arrangement and to restore this travel allowance to NESA trainees in parliamentary offices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the Community Youth Support Scheme I very much endorse Senator Mason's remarks and draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that there is still no national award for project officers employed under the scheme and who, according to a previous report-I believe it was in the guidelines-must possess communication skills and the capacity to deal with a multitude of social and psychological problems. Where no State award exists-they exist only in Victoria and New South Wales- wages and conditions for project officers have been described as appalling. In many cases they are paid less than junior social work cadets while accepting heavy responsibility and heavy work loads. The figure of $9,000 per annum has been given to me as a typical wage for these people who are trained and qualified. Recent attempts by the social workers union to obtain a Federal award were initially successful but Deputy President Isaac's decision was overturned on appeal. The Commonwealth Government played a major part in that appeal, in which the final determination was that this was not an industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The level of funding for this scheme must surely allow for proper payments and other award provisions for these workers. Management committees on the whole need direction from the Government on this matter but the Government, having acknowledged the value of the scheme and having ensured its continuation, must accept the ultimate responsibility. The local committees often lack continuity and a capacity to understand their role as employers. Meanwhile, another essential service to the community is being heavily subsidised by poorly paid workers whose commitment and dedication is being exploited.

The technical and further education scheme in its updated form is described in a section of the annual report of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs , starting on page 19. The introduction of a transition allowance is a very welcome innovation, providing as it does a means of filling the gap in the range of allowances available to young people. Prior to the introduction of this allowance young people were dissuaded from returning to training as those receiving unemployment benefit were required to give it up upon commencing full time school to work transition courses conducted by TAFE institutions. I suggest that it is not just young people in the age bracket of 15 years to 24 years who should be eligible for this allowance.

Over the past few months I have become acutely aware of a significant group of women in the community, some of whom have been out of the work force for 20 to 25 years, who have never been able to acquire very much in the way of formal education and training and who, in their 40s, having been on widows' pensions, now find that because their children have reached the age of 16 years, their entitlements are reduced to the unemployment benefit. This seems to me to be a group of women who certainly should not be thrown on the scrap heap. They should be given the opportunity to rejoin the work force, to take up their education where it left off, which in some cases was decades ago. They should be encouraged to do this by undertaking appropriate courses within the TAFE system and by the provision of a similar sort of transition allowance. That would make up to them for the loss of the extra entitlements they had been receiving as widows and it would demonstrate to them that society recognises the fact that they have done what they believed to be the right thing by staying out of the work force for all those years to bring up their children.

I refer also to the section dealing with the Women's Bureau. There is a reference to the equal employment opportunity guidelines which were launched on 4 February 1981 by the Honourable Andrew Peacock in his capacity at that time as Chairman of the National Labour Consultative Council. I note that the distribution of these guidelines is being monitored by the Women's Bureau. I suggest that a check be made on whether these guidelines are to apply, for example, to educational institutions, particularly universities, TAFE institutions and colleges, which employ a considerable number of people. There seems to have been very little recognition in the past of the inequities in these institutions' recruiting and employment practices which have resulted in the fact that women are very poorly represented in the better paid and more secure positions.

The report makes a brief reference to the Open Doors Campaign which is being conducted by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. This campaign aims to break down job segregation by encouraging young women to consider apprenticeship and trade training as alternatives to traditional female jobs. Currently there are about 140,000 apprentices in training in Australia but less than 2 per cent of them are women if hairdressing is excluded. Open Doors is designed to help change that situation. It consists of a package which features a booklet containing information from all States and Territories, a poster and an 18-minute videotape which features women in various apprenticeships throughout Australia.

The promotional material for the campaign was developed specifically for young women. I suggest that it is very important that this campaign should reach not just young women but all young people, the younger the better. The material should be distributed not only in secondary schools but also in primary schools. It should be made available for the information and edification of boys as well as girls. It seems to me to be very important for males in this community to get used to the idea that women can do anything. After all, even in the best of all possible worlds, males will still make 50 per cent of the decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like very briefly to make a comment on a matter raised by Senator Giles. She mentioned women who have stayed at home and devoted themselves to bringing up children and their subsequent employment difficulties, particularly those women whose children leave home or grow up prior to the women being entitled to continuous widows' pensions. I know the problem which was raised by the honourable senator and note her interest in it. I rise simply to invite her to let me have her considered view on the appropriate remedy to that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I make that suggestion in light of the fact that there is a range of possibilities. One could, for example, extend the entitlement to the Class B widow's pension, which is one suggestion which has been put forward. This would entitle all women who have ever had children to a lifetime pension if they were widowed or divorced. Alternatively, in a society in which the differential between men and women as people who enter paid employment is tending to diminish , for at least a part of the population, ought one to be more concerned with the long term employment problems of both men and women who, for a variety of reasons, might have difficulty in re-entering the work force? In other words, there are a variety of approaches. I certainly have some concern about endlessly extending the automatic category of people who are entitled to income support. I wonder whether the honourable senator has given thought to that point. She might like to raise it with me at some later time. I am sorry to have taken up the time of the Senate but it is a matter in which I am interested and on which I would welcome the honourable senator's views.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report: 'The National Estate in 1981'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Heritage Commission was established following the recommendation of the Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate which reported to Federal Parliament in 1974. The report before us today entitled 'The National Estate in 1981' is the first report that has come before the Parliament and hence the first report that has come before the public of Australia since then. I find this a remarkable occurrence, given that the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 defines the National Estate as:

. . . those places, being components of the natural environment of Australia or the cultural environment of Australia, that have aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance or other special value for future generations as well as for the present community.

It seems to be that, given that definition, it is encumbent on the Government to engineer that reports of this kind be presented to the Parliament and to the public at somewhat less than eight-yearly intervals. I emphasise that this is no criticism of the Commission or of its Chairman, David Yencken. I believe that the financial resources available to the Commission have declined considerably in the last five or six years, that the work load is absolutely incredible and that the Commission is doing the very best it can under some extremely difficult circumstances. This means, of course, that we can seriously question the attitude of the present Government to Australia's heritage and its commitment to cultural and environmental heritage preservation and development at all. That fact is probably best indicated by a remark in the report which states that the museum commission which the inquiry recommended in 1974 has not yet been established. I would have thought that that would have been an integral part of conserving Australia's heritage. Clearly, there is much to be done. This report emphasises that in its final chapter.

I believe that the Commission and its Chairman have a lot to be complimented for-the work it has done, its plans for the future and, most importantly, the results it has had so far in getting community support for, appreciation of and approval for heritage work and cultural preservation. In chapter 2 of the report , entitled 'Perceptions of the National Estate', these words appear:
One of the most valuable contributions made by the Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate was to give formal expression to an emerging consciousness of our natural and man-made heritage.

This has led indisputably to increased community support for environmental and heritage issues. An indication of that is the increasing numbers of members in voluntary conservation organisations. As I understand it, there are now something like 370,000 members of various organisations. Clearly, the public attitude is strongly supportive of what is being done by organisations such as the Commission. I had first hand experience of that last month when I took a fairly detailed tour of one of the council regions in South Australia, namely region 8, which begins around Owen and extends up as far as Clare and Burra. I discovered, for instance, that the Kapunda council has made tremendous efforts to develop one of the most extensive museums of the region that I have ever run into. Despite some mild community objections, such as bomb threats to certain councillors and attempts to ring-bark trees around the place, the Owen council nevertheless purchased the old Owen post office which is now turning into quite a profitable concern. At Burra, in the heart of South Australia's mid-north, the council is planning on spending $200,000 in the next few years to develop one side of Paxton Square which, for those people who are not South Australians and are not familiar with the area, consists of a series of miners' homes. It is a very important part of the heritage of that section of South Australia.

So community interest and action are very evident through the efforts of local governments. This, in turn, is having an additional effect on the attitudes of community groups such as Apex and of individual people in the area. I was delighted to note, while I was up there, that individual farmers are setting themselves targets for tree plantings on their properties in an attempt to replace the old Australian adage: 'If it stands still, chop it down; if it moves , shoot it'. Apexians are spending a lot of money on developing areas that are rather unattractive, such as around railway stations and so on, in those places. So clearly the actions of the Australian Heritage Commission have had quite an important part to play in what is happening with community groups in South Australia and other parts of the country. I refer again to some more points that are raised in chapter 2 which is one of the most important sections in the report. That chapter relates to the preservation of Australia's national heritage. Five arguments are outlined on page 18 of the report which are probably best summarised as arguing for the need for biological, cultural and intellectual continuity of Australia's heritage. The report refers to some comments made by Norman Myers, Senior Associate of the World Wildlife Fund, who said:

The welfare of humankind is served by the species that share the earth. Not only do they supply natural products such as rubber but they also provide germ plasm-living tissue that harbours hereditary codes in the form of genes.

He pursued that line of thought for some time. I do not have time to read all his remarks now. The report has a caption underneath a photograph of one of Australia's more magnificent rainforests which states:

Rainforests are among the world's richest gene banks and their economic potentiality has yet to be fully explored. Australian rainforests have been destroyed to the extent that only one-quarter of the original pre-European distribution now remains.

I believe it is essential-certainly the compilers of this report believe that it is essential-that State and Federal government politicians respond to the sort of evidence that is brought forward in chapter 2 of this report and act to correct the damage done in the past by ignorant members of the community and by careless members of the community, to say nothing of venal members of the community. One attempt to do this has recently been undertaken by my colleague, Senator Mason, who yesterday indicated to the Senate his intention to introduce a private member's Bill on rainforest preservation agreements. The purpose of this Bill is to encourage the States to preserve all existing rainforests in a variety of ways, into which I do not have time to go now, with financial assistance from the Federal Government.

Public acceptance of the need to preserve our national heritage must be matched by government action of the kind Senator Mason suggests in his Bill which the Senate will hear more about later today. In addition, reports of this nature are an essential part of the educative process of both politicians and members of the community. I reiterate what I said at the beginning of this speech; that it is essential that we get, at intervals smaller than eight years, reports on the cultural needs and the cultural heritage of Australia. I will end my remarks by quoting the final sentence of this report's summary and conclusions chapter which reads:
Respect for an understanding of the past is a pre-requisite for a fully rounded culture of the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I want to make some brief remarks. With your co-operation and the co-operation of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) I will seek the incorporation of a document in Hansard. The report is fairly comprehensive. I think it is significant that only one protected area-the Port Arthur complex-seems to have been given substantial funds. I shall use this occasion to make a number of short statements, within the very limited time I have, concerning the retention, the protection and the preservation of a very historic building in Townsville. We have now approached the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) seeking funds in the hope that some money will be made available. I seek leave for the incorporation in Hansard of the document I mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CITATION
Present name: Hollis Hopkins Building and Group
Former name(s):
Address: Sturt and Walker Streets, Townsville
Present use:
Previous use(s): Warehouse
Local Authority: Townsville City
Owner:
Name:
Address:
The group consists of the warehouse and offices (on Allot. 15, Sec. 5) and two old houses on Walker Street, (Allot 2, Sec. 5). Parish of Elphinstone, County of Coonabulla.
The Warehouse Building was erected in 1887 for the firm of Hollis Hopkins and Co. Ltd., warehousemen. The name of the architect is unknown.

Hollis Hopkins started in business in Townsville in 1881, purchasing the wholesale drapery departments of Aplin, Brown & Co., and Burns Philp & Co. Hopkins arrived in Australia from England in 1864. He lived in Sydney for 17 years before coming to Townsville.

He became very well known locally as one of the leaders of the Separation Movement, even settling in London for some years in order to further the cause of that movement there. The business passed to his son, Spencer Hopkins, and then to his grandson Harry Hopkins, who is also well known in the city's life, having served on the City Council and been involved in the foundation of James Cook University.

The present building, approx. 66 feet x 100 feet deep, consists of four floors including a basement lit by large windows recessed in the pavement. As constructed in 1887 it had two floors and basement, the top storey being added in 1890.

The building is a cement brick warehouse with attractive Victorian neo classical detail. The facade attempts a symmetrical composition slightly compromised by the high opening on the left side of the ground floor which serves a waggon laneway and which is furnished with iron gates with company insignia. A central entrance with triangular pediment stands slightly proud of the general facade, this emphasis being carried upwards as a central feature by means of flanking pilasters on each side of a large semi-circular headed window on each floor. The semi-circular theme is continued into the parapet in the form of a lunette containing a heraldic bas relief portraying a lamb being weighed. This central parapet section is surmounted by decorative finials and is raised above the level of a balustered parapet which extends the full width of the facade. The other windows on the second and third storeys all have decorative keystones featuring classical female heads.

The facade is a good example of moderately ornate provincial Victorian neo classical, visually important because of its rich play of solid and void and sunlight and shadow appropriate to Townsville's climate; and also because of its location adjoining the proposed civic square. It has architectural and historical affinity with the Commonwealth offices almost opposite in Sturt Street; and makes an important contribution to the streetscape as a part of this sequence of old buildings which also includes Buchanan's Hotel.

The interior of the building is believed to be largely intact and includes a foyer with fine timber panelling and counter, timber stairs and decorative structured iron columns supporting the top floor; and a lift (1889) said to be the first to be installed in a warehouse outside a capital city anywhere in Australia and the only hydraulic lift then operating in a manchester warehouse in the colony of Queensland. This lift is apparently still in working order.

Two Identical Cottages in Walker Street, contemporary with the Hollis Hopkins building (1890), were erected by T. Hollis Hopkins. There are small vernacular timber and tin cottages remaining from a period when this was the main residential area of Townsville. The grounds include significant large mango trees. This group is excellently preserved and important as an intact relic of the residential history of the area.
Listed for architectural and townscape significance, and links with the history of Townsville's commercial development.
Author/s of Citation: I. Sinnamon, D. Gibson-Wilde and P. Bell.
Approval of Listings Committee: 21.7.80; 8.12.80
Ratified by Executive Committee: 25.8.80

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. There are a number of other points to which I would like to refer briefly. I will quote from the beginning of chapter 6 on page 115 because I think it is significant. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Of the 6,700 places in the Register of the National Estate by far the largest number of individual entries are those which reflect European or European related exploration and settlement. Of these historic listings, individual buildings constitute the largest single category with some 5,000 listings. There are an estimated five million buildings in Australia, so the Register listings of individual buildings still constitute no more than 0.1 per cent of the total building.

This is the part that disturbs me. Apparently a listing does not necessarily preserve a building from demolition. The Hopkins building in Townsville has been bought by the State Government Insurance Office, which proposes to demolish the building and, I understand, build a 12-storey office block on the site. The appeal made by the Hollis Hopkins Concerned Citizens Committee and me is that some small amount of finance ought to be obtained-I hope from Federal sources-to preserve this edifice. If that is forthcoming perhaps there can be some spirit of co-operation on the part of the developers so that the major part of the old building can be retained. The new building could probably go to the rear of the site. In other words, it would be an incorporation. This has already happened with Buchanan's Hotel, a famous establishment on the other side of the street. The new owner proposes to incorporate the whole of the old building in a high rise building that is being constructed on the same site. I seek leave to continue my remarks on another date.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In view of the time available, I want just to congratulate the Australian Heritage Commission on its report and work and to say that I am proud to have been part of the Australian Labor Party Government that set up this institution-the Heritage Commission-and that developed the concept of the National Estate. I want to refer very briefly to two aspects of the report. The report, on page 38, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 30 of the Commission's Act requires Commonwealth Ministers and authorities to take no action which might adversely affect a listed place unless they are satisfied that there is no feasible and prudent alternative and that all measures that can be taken to minimise the adverse effect will be taken.
Later in that section, on page 40, the report states:

Whether the actions of Commonwealth Ministers at Loan Council meetings fall under the purview of section 30 has also been questioned. The legal opinions received by the Commission have not answered this question definitively.

In view of the fact that this is a key question which will face the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania I ask that those legal opinions be made public or be provided to the Committee. The other matter to which I wanted to refer very briefly was referred to on page 140 of the report and is in respect of the built environment and actions by agencies of the Government which affect the appearance of certain buildings which are the property of the Government. The report states:

There are past errors which need rectification e.g. the Post Offices of Oatlands, Campbell Town, and Longford all in historic towns in Tasmania, and all mutilated by insensitive facade rebuilding some fifteen or so years ago.

Just how much these Post Offices might contribute to the historic landscapes of their towns can be seen in nearby Ross, where a similar Post Office was only saved by spirited local resistance led by the Von Bibra family. During the 1973- 74 Committee of Inquiry investigations a promise was given that the Post Offices would be restored. The Inquiry Report documented this undertaking with a caption to a photo: 'Gracious apology for an error-Oatlands Post Office in Tasmania mistakenly robbed of its charming facade, is being restored to the original sandstone'. Today no one will acknowledge the undertaking despite strong local support for restoration; it is conveniently buried in the old Postmaster General 's Department. Whilst these Post Offices remain in their present state every visitor to Tasmania is reminded of this unrequited Commonwealth promise. Let us hope that at the very least the Post Offices will be restored in time for the Bicentenary in 1988.
I appeal to the Government and to Australia Post to reaffirm that promise made by the old Postmaster-General's Department to restore the facades of those three important parts of the National Estate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the features section on page 9 of the Australian newspaper this morning there is an article written by John Webb headed 'Chipp, McMahon intervene over prohibited import'. The article deals with an event that occurred around about November 1972 when I received representations from the then Prime Minister, Mr William McMahon, as member for Lowe, concerning one of his constituents who was having a problem with the Bureau of Customs. I was then the Minister for Customs and Excise. The article in the Australian, as one would expect from such a reputable newspaper, is accurate and fair in its account of the way in which I, as the then Minister, treated the matter. The facts are briefly as follows: One of Mr McMahon's constituents, I believe a Lebanese gentleman, imported a still into the country that had been used to make that loathsome liquid, arak--
—You used to like it once.

—I used to like it, yes, but tastes change. The still's marketable value or real use or threat to the Australian liquor industry was negligible but because there was a regulation that prohibited the import of stills to produce alcohol it was a prohibited import. But this Lebanese gentleman, as I recall-it was 10 years ago and memory is dim-wanted to put it in some historical room as an ornament. To get around this dilemma, in discussions with my Department we agreed that if we made the still incapable of producing alcoholic liquor the gentleman could have it for whatever the value was. As I recall, we bashed some holes in the bottom of the still so that it could not contain any liquor, made the gentleman pay $10 and the still went through.

SPEECH.PARA: I, as Minister, authorised that sort of procedure countless times in answer to representations from back benchers, Ministers, and representatives from the Senate. It is a Minister's function to accommodate a citizen after representations from a member of parliament to overcome what the bureaucracy does in administering the strict law. The Minister does not break the law but I think he applies a common-sense application. Another clear case is when many people bring back guns as souvenirs from overseas. They find them in some curio shop and buy them. They bring them into Australia for their artistic or historical value. Clearly, they are not brought in for the purpose of shooting anybody but technically I suppose they could be repaired to such a stage at which they could, if one achieved a miracle and found a bullet to fit them, be resurrected to shoot. In those cases quite often we would say that if the gun were rendered incapable of ever shooting another bullet we would allow the gun in, although in its natural form it was a prohibited import. That is a practice I followed when I was Minister for Customs. I hope subsequent Ministers for Customs have followed this same procedure when asked to apply common sense to the administration of their portfolios. The Australian article describes that event properly and fairly, as honourable senators would expect it to, but this fellow, John Webb-whoever he is-in the course of the article stated:
Accordingly, the then Minister for Customs and Excise, Mr Don Chipp, wrote to ' my dear Prime Minister'--
Mr McMahon, that is, and made representations to him. The article further states :

TALK.START.PARA: —now Senator Don Chipp and famous for his 'keep the bastards honest' threat as Leader of the Australian Democrats-advised how Mr X--

SPEECH.PARA: The newspaper goes out of its way not to name the person-
could complete the necessary formalities to regain the still.
That article contains no allegation of any impropriety on my part, but that sneaky little smear is there, and I resent it. I sent a telegram today to the editor of the Australian which states:
The Editor
The Australian
Disappointed that a paper of your high reputation and good record for ethical conduct should publish such a cheap smear as you did today, May 6, page nine, lines twenty-eight to thirty-one.

The body of the article describes fairly my actions as reasonable, entirely proper and the sort of common sense decision any Customs Minister should take in ensuring that justice is done when bonafide citizens are confronted by bureaucracy.
I request that you publish an apology in tomorrow's edition.
Would be happy to discuss the matter in detail with a member of your staff.
Don Chipp

I hope that the newspaper maintains its high record of balanced and fair reporting and takes actions to correct what could be read by some, particularly in light of the present focus on the Bureau of Customs, as a smear against me.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment I present a report on the Committee's examination of annual reports, dated May 1982, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is the fourth report from the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment dealing with annual reports. An examination of the annual reports of departments and statutory authorities is an important aspect of Parliament's oversight of the activities of those departments and statutory authorities. Unfortunately, it is an aspect that has not been fully exploited by Senate committees, largely due to a lack of staff resources.

A number of Senate committees have tabled annual reports. Most, however, have only briefly examined each annual report and the committees' reports to the Senate have concentrated on the style, format and contents of the annual reports under review. A summary of the problems raised by the reporting bodies may also be included. The three previous reports by this Committee are examples of this approach. However this method can rightly be criticised for being shallow and superficial. Such an examination is valueless and contributes nothing to the oversight by the Parliament of the operations of the Executive. The Committee believes that what is now required is a detailed appraisal of the content of annual reports. This would extend to a critical examination of the information provided, including the identification of omissions or deficiencies.

Whilst the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment believes it desirable to examine every annual report referred to it, the lack of resources ensures that it is not possible to do this at a level that makes the examination worthwhile. Nevertheless the Committee was keen to make an effective examination of at least some of the 45 annual reports referred to it in 1981. The Committee chose to examine in detail two annual reports; those of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation for 1979-80 and the Department of Science and the Environment, also for 1979-80. Within each report the Committee concentrated on particular areas of activity, choosing those in which it had a particular interest and with which it was most familiar. They are: from the Department of Science and the Environment annual report for 1979-80, areas which dealt with the Baseline Air Pollution Station and the Australian Balloon Launching Station; and, from the CSIRO annual report for 1979-80, areas which dealt with the effects of the recent reorganisation, particularly on the research effort, the effects of staff and financial restraints on the CSIRO's capacity to perform its statutory functions and high priority areas for expansion and new initiatives. The Committee has made recommendations on the reporting to Parliament of the activities of the Baseline Air Pollution Station, the continued operation of an Australian scientific balloon launching facility, an increase in the CSIRO operating appropriation and the prompt referral of annual reports to committees. These are very important matters and I refer honourable senators to the report for further details.

In this statement, I wish to highlight the Committee's conclusions regarding the conduct of this inquiry. The Commitee invited the department and authority concerned to make written submissions on the areas selected by the Committee for investigation. Representatives were then questioned at a public hearing. Subsequently, the Committee invited comment, on some aspects of the evidence, from interested persons and organisations. The approach adopted by the Committee proved deficient in two respects. First, the examination of some issues was incomplete because the Committee heard evidence only from representatives of the department or authority whose annual report was under investigation. The Committee believes that it is most important that the examination of annual reports should be at a public hearing. Evidence should also be taken from representatives of other interested parties, such as unions or staff associations, advisory councils, consumers or users of the particular services, as well as governments, community groups or businesses affected by that aspect of the operations which is under investigation. In the future the Committee intends to hear evidence from all relevant parties.

Secondly, the inquiry was delayed and some of the issues were out of date or overtaken by later events. The Committee believes that it must take into account developments after the end of the reporting period. Unless this is done, distorted, or at the worst valueless, conclusions will result. Nevertheless, every effort should be made to consider matters raised in the annual report as soon as possible after its tabling, so that comments of the Committee are more relevant to the current situation. The Committee intends to reduce the time taken in its inquiries and also recommends that the annual reports be referred to committees within one week of tabling.

As far as future examinations of annual reports are concerned, the Committee believes it desirable that all annual reports referred to it should be examined. However the lack of Committee resources would limit such a program initially to three or four reports a year. From these the Committee will select two or three aspects of the reporting authority's operations for examination. The report of such an examination should be brief and will, if necessary, contain recommendations for future action. It is the intention of this Committee to institute an inquiry into annual reports, as soon as possible after being referred to the committee, and to conduct a short public hearing within two months of the reference. As a general principle, the Committeee would report to the Senate on the annual report within two months of the public hearing, or four months after the reference to the Committee. In this way the matters examined in the inquiry would be much more relevant.

In drawing attention to the delays in the referral of annual reports to this Committee which have occurred on occasions in the past, it was intended to highlight the desirability of prompt referral of annual reports rather than to reflect critically upon the President, his predecessor or any members of the Senate staff, in particular the records office. This has been brought forward in a constructively critical way in the interests of the development of the committee system and with the objective of making an examination of annual reports more effective than it has been in the past. I have written to the President on this matter and have made those views clear to him.
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.
