DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present the Committee's report entitled The Gulf and Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Because of the Joint Committee's continuing interest in the Middle East, on 15 November 1979 Sub-committee B was given a reference to monitor the situation there and in peripheral countries. This report covers the countries of Bahrain, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. This report arises from evidence that the Sub-committee has been taking since February 1980. In preparing this report the Sub-committee has had to keep abreast of developments in a region of rapidly changing political circumstances and of uncertainty. This afternoon I wish to deal briefly with some of the issues of great importance to Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: As would be expected in a report of this nature, the Sub-committee devoted considerable attention to identifying Australia's interests in the Gulf, and also how events there are likely to affect us. Australian trade with the region has increased dramatically in the last few years. Australia's exports to the Gulf rose from $87.2m in 1972-73 to $915.6m in 1980-81, an increase of 950 per cent. This compares with an increase in total Australian exports to all markets in the same period of 209 per cent. On the other hand imports from the Gulf, principally crude oil and petroleum products, stood at $1,808m in 1980-81, an increase of 1,297 per cent over 1972-73.

The size of increased exports might seem satisfactory, but perhaps we could be doing a lot better. Although several Trade Commission personnel have undertaken a 'three months survival course' in Arabic, the Sub-committee was told in evidence as recently as 25 March 1982 that there is only one member in the Department of Trade and Resources who can read and write Arabic adequately. Although in past years some officers had undertaken 12-month courses in Arabic before taking up appointments at one of our nine posts in the Middle East, this is no longer done due to staff resources, budgeting constraints, et cetera. This is only one area of a number where the Committee makes recommendations in respect of our trade effort.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: The Relevance of the Arab-Israeli Dispute and the Palestinian Issue

PROCTEXT.PARA: This report is different from the previous reports because it focuses on the Gulf, rather than on the Arab-Israeli dispute and the Palestinian question or the difficulties in Lebanon. In spite of that, the Arab-Israeli dispute and the Palestinian question are a topic which has had to be addressed in the report as it is a significant feature of the internal Gulf politics. Palestinians are dispersed throughout the Gulf and are important elements in the labour force. Their presence allows them to exert a continuing pressure on host Gulf countries in respect of the Palestine issue. Most Gulf governments publicly say that settlement of the dispute is the region's first priority.

The economic interests of the industrialised Western countries in the Gulf means that the United States is keen to secure what it sees as Western vital interests in the region. The Revolution in Iran which overthrew the Shah, the Iraq-Iran war, reports of instability in the Gulf monarchies, and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan have seen the United States becoming increasingly concerned about the safety of oil supplies from the region.

Since President Carter's January 1980 State of the Union Address to Congress, there have been many developments in United States military and strategic policy which will involve Australia. These include the establishment of a rapid deployment force, and a general increase in the ability of the United States to project power into the Gulf from the Indian Ocean. The upgrading of air and port facilities at Diego Garcia, the estabishment of transit rights at Darwin Airport for B52 bombers en route to Diego Garcia, the stationing of marines aboard ship in the Indian Ocean, and so on are all matters which affect Australia and Australia's region. The report therefore analyses the developments in United States strategic and military policy in considerable detail.

Because of the importance of the strategic situation in the Gulf region, the report devotes considerable attention to developments in United States policy since January 1980. From a reading of the basic source documents and evidence presented by United States armed forces personnel to Congress it is evident that United States policy towards the Gulf is not well understood in Australia, and it is hoped that detailed information in the report will help correct this. For instance, it is clear that the upper echelons of the United States armed forces are continuing to come around to the view that getting forces to the Gulf and other areas of the Middle East in times of crisis rapidly could best be done in a westerly rather than an easterly direction from the United States. This may have important implications for Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Indian Ocean as a Zone of Peace

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Committee concluded that there was little likelihood of the Indian Ocean being proclaimed as a zone of peace despite the majority wish of the 46 member states of the United Nations who are members of the discussion group on the topic. The Committee felt that given the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan and its troop strength in the hinterland along the Iranian border, with land access to the Gulf and south and south-west Asia, the United States is unlikely to agree to withdraw its substantial naval presence in the Ocean.
The Sub-committee sought to identify how the strategic situation in the Gulf might affect Australia. It is clear, as the report states, that:

Australia has no direct strategic interest in the Gulf. It does however have a common concern with other Western industrialised countries to secure a continued supply of oil and protect its economic viability to enable the continued export of goods and services.
The report also states:

Since United States encouragement of Australia to participate in a peacekeeping force in the Sinai, and heightened military activity in the Gulf region, the Middle East in general and the Gulf in particular, have during 1980-81 become more important elements in United States-Australian strategic relations.

It is not possible to list all the areas in the report on which the Committee has made recommendations and conclusions. The Committee has made a number of observations on such matters as the adequacy of our trade promotion, on other aspects of economic relations, including petro-dollar investment in Australia, on super-power involvement in the Gulf, and on Australia's policy towards the Arab-Israeli dispute and the Palestinian question. The Committee hopes that the Government will respond to them in a statement to the Parliament in the not too distant future, perhaps in the Budget sittings. The Committee hopes that the report will be a useful background for all those interested in our relations with the Middle East.

I should place on record on behalf of the Committee the outstanding efforts and assistance that we received from Mr Ron Wiber, the secretary; Maureen Weeks, the research officer; and Anne-Mari Poirrier, the steno-secretary. There are a number of issues that I did not raise this afternoon because of time constraints . They are issues such as the stability of the current regime that rules Saudi Arabia; the possibility of the Straits of Hormuz being blocked by the sinking of super-tankers-an issue which members of the Committee felt it was not possible to cover but which many Press and newspaper reports continually put forward as a possibility in time of war; and the Iran-Iraq war. We hope that this report, along with the issues I have just mentioned, will be brought back by the Government for a full debate in the Budget session. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to make a few comments concerning the proposed upgrading of Adelaide Airport for international services . Although I have not opposed these works, I believe certain conditions need to be met. These are largely the same as those I outlined regarding the upgrading for domestic wide-bodied aircraft. I would like to reiterate these conditions. Firstly, I believe that tangible and positive steps must be taken now by the Commonwealth and State governments for the construction of a new airport, preferably in a sparsely populated outer area. Secondly, I believe the construction of an international terminal should be deferred at least pending the issue of a provisional master plan and draft environmental impact statement for public comment and the completion of a final impact statement and master plan. It is also vital that the present curfew be maintained and more rigorously enforced to ensure that nearby residents do not suffer any further discomfort.
—What about the new airplanes?

—That remains to be seen. The possibility of excessive noise pollution was the reason the Committee proposed that the international terminal be relocated closer to the domestic terminal, further away from the housing estates.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make concerns the actions of the Tonkin Liberal Government. With an election due in South Australia later this year or early in 1983, the State Liberal Government is desperate to complete the international facilities at Adelaide Airport. That Government sees this as an easy way of winning votes and wants to use it to turn people's attention away from its own miserable performance. I repeat that these works should not go ahead until the completion of a final environmental impact statement and master plan. Furthermore, international air services should not go ahead until the facilities have been completed. It is imperative that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) not succumb to any pressure exerted by Mr Tonkin or any of his cronies.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Mason) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to agreements between the Commonwealth and the States in connection with the preservation of rainforest.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In order to reduce the time stricture on the Senate and, I think, with the agreement of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), who has seen the second reading speech, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to bring about the preservation of all existing rainforest in Australia. To achieve this, the bill provides for the Commonwealth to give financial assistance to the States, subject to the compliance of each State with the provisions of the agreement, equal to one half of the cost of preservation incurred by the State. That is, the Commonwealth would supply a grant of one dollar for every dollar provided by each State to implement the preservation of its rainforests.

In return for this grant, the State would be obliged to cease the granting of all licences and permits to log rainforest; to repurchase existing licences and permits; to include rainforests in national parks; to encourage the re-equipment of timber mills to handle timbers other than rainforest timbers; to undertake re -afforestation of cleared lands to provide alternative timber supplies; and to assist in the transportation of alternative timbers to timber mills.
The period allowed for implementation of this agreement is two years. I feel that this is the minimum practical period for such a large undertaking.

I am earnestly hoping that this bill will be a matter of consensus between all political parties. Everyone agrees that our surviving rainforest, only one- quarter of that which was here at the time of European settlement, is an essential part of the National Estate.

Although rainforest covers less than 10 per cent of the earth's surface, it provides habitat for nearly half the world's plants and animal species. As the Australian Heritage Commission points out, rainforests are among the world's richest gene banks and their economic potentiality has yet to be fully explored. Rainforests may well be the source of new drugs, resins, fibres and foods, as they have been in the past. Rainforests are also, undoubtedly, one of the most beautiful natural environments. As an aesthetic resource, they are invaluable.
One of my main aims when deciding on the wording of this Bill, was to ensure that no unemployment of timber workers would result from its implementation.

Over the last decade, there has been a decline of 18 per cent in the number of people employed in forestry and forest-based industries-a total of over 19,600 positions. Under existing contracts almost all rainforest in New South Wales alone will have disappeared by 1992. The industry will be thrown into utter chaos, and thousands more jobs will be lost, without a reasonable scheme to change over to other timbers. This Bill would provide that scheme in time to preserve those jobs as well as the rainforest.

If our descendants are to be able to enjoy and utilise this most beautiful and useful environment, we must act now. Regeneration of rainforest takes thousands of years. If we log any more of our rainforest we are virtually wiping out the result of sixty million years of evolution; converting it to school desks, timber veneers and paper packaging.

World-wide, rainforest is currently being logged at the rate of 30 hectares per minute. In 85 years there will be no accessible rainforest left anywhere in the world except in tiny pockets of national parks which may or may not be ecologically viable as autonomic environments.

The preservation of rainforests is considered to be an international priority by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) and the Worlds Wildlife Fund (WWF). I sincerely trust that it will also be a priority for Australia and that honourable senators of all political persuasions will support this bill.
Mr President, I commend this bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
HOME DEPOSITS ASSISTANCE BILL 1982
The Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 gives effect to the Government's promise, announced by the Treasurer on 18 March 1982, to introduce an improved deposit assistance scheme.

This Bill provides for replacement of the Home Savings Grant Scheme, which since its inception in 1964 has given valuable assistance to first home buyers. In all, approximately $450m has been made available to more than 600,000 first home buyers under the Scheme. I will be introducing concurrently separate legislation to provide for the winding up of that Scheme.

The Bill recognises the valuable assistance the Home Savings Grant Scheme has given to people over the years in that it draws on many of the provisions of that Scheme. However, to increase the effectiveness of this form of deposit assistance, the Bill will provide for a new, means-tested Home Deposit Assistance Scheme to help low and middle income earners, married or single, when they buy or build their first home.
In adopting features of the old Scheme, we have recognised that some anomalies existed and the Bill now before the Senate has been designed to remove those anomalies.

The Home Deposit Assistance Scheme is a major element in the government's new housing package. The package also includes measures to enable banks to make an additional $400m available for housing loans, a tax rebate on home loan interest , and a Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme. Negotiations with the States on the Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme are underway and the Minister for Housing and Construction expects to introduce legislation for that Scheme in the Budget Sittings.

The Bill before the Senate provides for the Commonwealth to pay grants to people buying or building their first home on or after 18 March 1982, who have saved towards their home in certain specified forms-basically those which form the pool of long term housing finance-and who satisfy the specified eligibility criteria.
There will be no waiting period for the payment of these grants.
The Scheme, with its income-based means test, will direct grants to people, especially single income families with dependent children, who have the greatest difficulty in acquiring a home.

That maximum basic grant will be $2,500, an increase of $500 on the old scheme. Grants of $1 will be paid for each $1 of eligible savings, rather than $1 for each $3. There will no longer be any limit on the value of homes which qualify.

The new Home Deposit Assistance Scheme is designed to ensure that Government assistance to overcome the deposit gap is better directed to low and middle income earners and is available at the time of purchase. Mr President, this new Scheme is an honest attempt to help people into home ownership. I hope that its benefits are not whittled away by increases in housing and land costs, especially increases associated with unreasonable wage demands.
I would like now to summarise for honourable senators the main features of the new Scheme.

The Home Deposit Assistance Scheme will operate with effect from 18 March 1982 to provide assistance to people buying or building their first home by contract made on or after that date. Owner-builders commencing to build on or after that date will also be included.

Eligible applicants will be able to qualify for a tax free grant of up to $3, 500, made up of a savings based grant of up to $2,500 and a Family Bonus of $500 for one dependent child and $1,000 for two or more dependent children.

Previously the Family Bonus has been available only in respect of dependent children in the custody, care and control of applicants at the date of the contract for the home. An anomalous position has resulted in that a family whose child is born one day before the contract date receives the Bonus yet a family whose child is born one day after does not receive this assistance. Further, the Government recognises that many people take steps to acquire a home of their home as soon as they learn that they are expecting a child.

Accordingly, under the new Scheme the Family Bonus will be paid to applicants where a child is born or otherwise comes into their custody, care and control within ten months after the home contract date. Reference in the Bill to a period of eleven months reflects that under the Social Services Act family allowance may not be payable in the month of birth. As entitlement to a Family Bonus is linked in the Bill to receipt of family allowance, it is necessary to specify a period of eleven months.
Qualifying homes may be new or established and will not be subject to any value limit.

Applicants for these grants will be expected to reside in the home as their principal place of residence within a reasonable time after its acquisition. It is not intended to assist with the acquisition of a home used solely for investment purposes or as a holiday home.

However, I am aware that people in transient occupations, for example teachers, ministers of religion, policemen and defence personnel, do not always have the opportunity to acquire their own homes and take up residence straight away.

The Bill will enable regard to be had to circumstance such as location or nature of employment preventing immediate occupancy of the home. In this way people in transient jobs will not be disadvantaged.

Applicants under the new Home Deposit Assistance Scheme may be married or single, young or old. There will be no upper age limit but eligible applicants must be at least 16 years of age, or married or engaged, at the date of entering into the home contract. Under the Scheme it replaces there was a minimum age limit of 18 years. In practice that limit has led to the exclusion of some people deserving assistance.
An applicant's spouse, legal or de facto, and any other person who has joined in the home acquisition, must join in the application for a grant.

The scheme is intended to assist people buying their first home. Accordingly, where one partner has previously owned a home, but remarried and purchased again the couple will not be eligible for assistance. However there is provision for previous ownership to be disregarded in cases where the dwelling was not the person's principal place of residence.

The means test will apply to the combined taxable income of all applicants for the financial year preceding home purchase and will be related to the Statistician's figure for Average Weekly Earnings for that year. A full grant, subject to qualifying savings, will be payable where the weekly average of the taxable income or combined taxable income for that year does not exceed a figure which is approximately 135 per cent of A.W.E. No grant will be payable where combined taxable income exceeds a figure approximately 155 per cent of A.W.E. These limits are expressed in the legislation as annual income rounded up to the nearest $100.

For people buying a home during the current financial year, the combined taxable income of husband and wife or other joint applicants, for the financial year 1980-81-which is the income year against which they will generally be tested-will be assessed against limits of $18,900 and $21,700. That is to say, subject to qualifying savings, a full grant will be payable where the combined taxable income is $18,000 or less. Where it falls between $18,900 and $21,700 the amount of the grant otherwise payable will be reduced proportionately.
No grant will be made where the combined taxable income exceeds the upper limit .

The Bill provides for the income limits for subsequent financial years to be provided in the regulations. This will allow the rounding of the income limit amounts, and will also allow for appropriate adjustment to be made in the event of any change in the basis of measuring the A.W.E. Series. It is the Government' s intention to introduce an appropriate regulation each year prior to 1 July which will set the limits in respect of the income year drawing to a close. Those limits will be approximately 135 per cent and 155 per cent of Average Weekly Earnings based on information published to that date by the Statistician.
The amount of the Family Bonus payable will not be subject to this means test taper. If applications are entitled to only a minimum basic grant they will still be eligible for the full Family Bonus.

Where there has been a significant change in family circumstances since the previous financial year, the Bill provides the power to have regard to those changed circumstances for the purposes of the means test.

Where an applicant has withdrawn from the workforce in the period between the end of the last financial year and the date of home acquisition, and where there is no current intention or immediate prospect of rejoining the workforce, only a proportion of the taxable income will be tested. For example, if one partner stops work 6 months before home purchase, only half of that person's income for the previous financial year will be considered.

This arrangement would apply to cases such as women ceasing work to have children, or people leaving the workforce because of invalidity, or some other circumstance where the duration of the period out of the workforce can be established with some precision.

In respect of other circumstances of reduced income, subsequent to the financial year being means-tested, and which are beyond the control of the applicant, a provisional grant of 80 per cent, plus 100 per cent of the Family Bonus where applicable, will be paid, based on the applicant's expected taxable income for the current year. An adjustment will be made later on the basis of the actual taxable income for the current year.
Only cases of genuine decline in the financial fortunes of applicants will be considered, such as unemployment, injury leading to a change in employment, impact of a natural disaster, and the like.

The necessary amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act to permit the Commissioner of Taxation or a person authorised by him to communicate information to the Secretary to the Department of Housing and Construction for the purposes of the administration of this legislation, are contained in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982.
In relation to the savings requirements, applicants must have held savings in one or more of the approved forms for at least one year immediately before the date of the home contract.

The grant will be paid on the basis of one dollar for every dollar held in an acceptable form. The maximum basic grant of $2,500, subject to the means test, will be paid where there have been two or more complete years of saving; a grant of up to $1,250 will be payable where there has been only one complete year of saving. I would like to stress that savings carried over from previous years will be taken into account. If an eligible person has saved say an average of $ 500 over each of the past 5 years and has total savings of $2,500 by the date of home purchase, a full grant would be payable.

However, only an increase of up to $1,500 in savings held in the year preceding home acquisition will count towards a grant. This is to ensure that a person will not benefit from a deposit of moneys that would not be regarded as normal savings within the intention of the Scheme.
The amount of the Family Bonus will not be dependent on the amount of acceptable savings held. Even if only a minimum grant is payable, a full Family Bonus will be paid.

The principal forms of saving acceptable under the new Scheme include deposits with savings banks, building societies and credit unions, fixed deposits with trading banks, Australian Savings Bonds purchased as Inscribed Stock or for safe custody with a bank, and payments in connection with the home acquisition, made on or before the contract date, such as for the land, for building materials or for legal fees.

A number of savings banks now offer facilities whereby depositors may draw cheques on their savings accounts. The Bill recognises this development and accepts such accounts as savings for the purposes of the Scheme.

Moneys held in trust on behalf of an applicant which are held or expended by the trustee in an acceptable form, and which are clearly identifiable as moneys held on behalf of the applicant, will be accepted as savings.

The previous scheme required all parties to an application to be Australian citizens or to have permanent resident status at the date of entering into the contract for the home. This requirement has led to anomalous situations in a number of cases. Take the example of a migrant husband who has set up a home in anticipation of his family's arrival. If his wife had not reached Australia and attained citizenship or resident status before the contract date, she would not be eligible and the family would not be entitled to a grant. This Bill provides for a grant to be payable once the applicant, or at least one of the joint applicants, becomes an Australian citizen or a permanent resident, irrespective of whether this occurs before or after the contract date.

The Bill includes a 'sunset' clause which means that the scheme will cease after three years unless new legislation is enacted. This will allow the Government to reassess the effectiveness of the Scheme in the light of prevailing circumstances.
Printed explanatory material and application forms are being produced for early and widespread distribution.

Co-operation of savings institutions and industry groups which have direct contact with home seekers has been requested to ensure that there is the widest possible awareness of the benefits of the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme.
Mr President, this Bill enables the Government to continue to encourage and assist people into home ownership. It will provide a more equitable and effective distribution of assistance.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
HOMES SAVINGS GRANT ACTS AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill provides for the termination of the Homes Savings Grant Scheme, to be replaced by the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme for which I have just introduced the enabling legislation, that is, the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982.

The Homes Savings Grant Scheme was established in 1964 under a Liberal-Country Party Government, by the Homes Savings Grant Act 1964. We reintroduced it in a much widened form, to apply from 1 January 1977, by the Homes Savings Grant Act 1976.

Mr President, since the Homes Savings Grant Scheme first came into operation more than 600,000 grants valued at some $450m have been approved for payment to people buying or building their first homes. However, following a recent review of our housing policies, the Government has decided to increase the Scheme's effectiveness with revised arrangements which are more in tune with current needs.

The Homes Savings Grant Act 1975, introduced by the Whitlam Government, sought to phase out the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. Accordingly, eligibility under the 1964 Act ceased in respect of homes acquired after 31 December 1976. Only a handful of outstanding applications under that Act have been received during the past 12 months.
This Bill provides that applications for assistance under the 1964 Act will not be accepted beyond the date the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 receives Royal Assent.

Eligibility under the 1976 Act relates to homes acquired by contract dated 1 January 1977 or later. This Bill terminates eligibility where the contract to buy or build a home is made after the date on which the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 receives Royal Assent.

Applications will be accepted for one month after the date eligibility is terminated. However, the Government recognises the difficulty people living in remote areas might experience in obtaining the necessary application documents. Accordingly the Bill provides that a written notification within that month of an intention to apply will be accepted provided a formal application is lodged within one further month.

The new Home Deposit Assistance Scheme arrangements apply from 18 March 1982. From that date, until the new Scheme receives Royal Assent, the two schemes will operate side by side. People who enter into a contract before the new scheme receives Royal Assent and who, as a result of the operation of the means test, may not be eligible under the new scheme, will have an opportunity to apply under the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. They should lodge their application as promptly as possible and certainly within one month of the date of Royal Assent to the new scheme.
The Government will publicise the cut-off date widely and I strongly urge people who have bought their first home and who have not yet lodged an application to do so promptly.

The Homes Savings Grant Scheme has served Australian home buyers well. It is being repealed to make way for a replacement scheme which draws on many of the provisions of the existing Scheme but will increase the effectiveness of this form of deposit assistance.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Durack) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 to strengthen the Corporation's control over Australia's export meat trade. The Bill will also enable the Corporation, in certain circumstances, to adopt the role of a sole trader or to limit the number of licensees that may trade with particular overseas markets.

Honourable senators will recall that last year penalties for the contravention of licence conditions were significantly increased. In this Bill further penalties have been included and other existing penalties raised to realistic levels.

In proposing these amendments to the Act, the Minister for Primary Industry has uppermost in his mind the need to maintain and uphold the reputation and integrity of our meat export industry. Recent events, especially cases of meat substitution and some incidents involving complaints about the quality of Australian meat have highlighted the need for the changes.

If Australia is to remain competitive on world meat and livestock markets, it is absolutely vital that our industry meet the requirements of overseas buyers. Australia's product must conform precisely to contract specifications. It must be labelled properly and be free from contamination.

This Bill seeks to achieve these objectives by extending the powers of the AMLC so that it is properly equipped to carry out its major functions-the protection, development and promotion of our overseas meat trade.

The changes contained in this Bill have been recommended by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, which represents the producing, processing and exporting sectors of the meat and livestock industry, and have also been sought, actively, by producer organisations.

The vast majority of Australian meat processors and exporters are beyond reproach in their business dealings. However there is a small minority which has engaged in unacceptable practices and in the process has brought the reputation of our industry into question. This legislation is designed to ensure that this minority can no longer bring the industry into disrepute.
It is hoped that this legislation will also serve to remind all exporters of the responsibilities they have to the industry as a whole.

Separate legislation-the Export Control Bill-is being introduced to cover matters associated with the preparation, grading and trade description of exports of food for human consumption. That legislation, and its regulations concerning the preparation of meat for export, will complement the provisions proposed in this Bill.

The main instrument available to the Corporation in controlling exports is the export licence. All existing licenses will be withdrawn when the Bill is proclaimed. People, including existing licensees, seeking a licence to export meat or livestock will have to apply to the Corporation and will have to meet the new criteria set out in the Bill. The objective is to ensure that only people of integrity, competence and sound financial standing are in possession of export licences.

Following the meat substitution issue last year the Minister for Primary Industry received requests from the industry that people and firms preparing meat for export should be licensed by the Corporation. The industry's concern arose because of limitations in the Act which prevented the AMLC taking action against the packer in cases where the packer did not export himself but sold to a licensee who bought 'sight unseen'. Under the AMLC Act the offending party was the exporter.

However, an examination of their proposal has shown up some practical difficulties in implementing such an arrangement in the AMLC's legislation. An alternative approach has therefore been adopted. The Export Control Bill requires all premises in which meat is prepared for export to be registered by the Department of Primary Industry. Under that Bill regulations may be made which will require the holder of the registration to be a fit and proper person. The criteria for a fit and proper person under that Bill will be similar to that which must be met by an applicant for a licence under this Bill.

This Bill will enable the corporation to ensure that meat and livestock for export are prepared in accordance with the buyer, quality and other specifications. Under the Export Control Bill the packer of meat will be required to conform with conditions concerning the health of the product, its grading and trade descriptions. The provision contained in each Bill will complement each other and ensure that neither the packer nor the exporter will be able to escape his responsibilities in regard to the preparation of the meat or in meeting buyer specifications.
The linking of the two Bills will enable the Department of Primary Industry and the AMLC to co-operate to ensure adequate control of all matters from the preparation to the export of the meat.

The Bill also clarifies the powers of the AMLC to suspend or cancel a licence and strengthens the Corporation's powers to obtain the information needed to assess whether the licensee is conforming to the conditions of his licence.

The Bill before the Senate provides appropriate penalties for breaches of the export control provisions. These penalties are consistent with those in the Export Control Bill. Mr President there is a range of penalties involved which are summarised for the information of honourable Senators in the attachment to this Speech.

A further major amendment proposed in this Bill is to give the ALMC power to engage in sole trading subject to the approval of the Minister. On several occasions recently, private exporters and ultimately producers have been disadvantaged in dealing with countries with single purchasing authorities. The monopoly power of these single buying organisations can be used to distort the operations of the market place and in some circumstances can have a depressing effect on prices received by exporters and producers.

As an example of the problems that can occur, late last year, a licensee tendered to a single import agency at 11-13 cents per kilogram below the then current equivalent U.S. price at which other licensees quoted. The licensee was awarded approximately 80 per cent of the tender, even though at the time of his offer he had no firm contracts for supply of beef from Australia meat processors . About the time the licensee sought supplies of beef, livestock prices fell. This is one example of practices which have led the Corporation and producers to request that the AMLC be empowered to sole trade or restrict the number of licensees that may quote to a market.

To implement the industry's request the Bill permits the AMLC to be the sole trader or restrict the number of licensees where there is a single buyer which controls all or substantially all of the imports into a country and where there is a need to ensure a fair return to producers.

The Corporation's existing trading powers allow it to trade but do not permit it to exclude licensees from quoting or selling to the same market. Under these current provisions the Corporation could find itself in competition with private Australian exporters unless they voluntarily withdrew from the market or unless the foreign buyer chose to deal only with the Corporation.

The proposal for the Corporation to limit the number of licensees who may export to a particular market is simply another means of offsetting the monopoly power available to some buyers. Other Australian licensees or meat processors will be able to supply meat to the licensee or licensees trading with the market concerned. However, once the arrangement is implemented only the designated licensee or licensees will be permitted to export to the market.

It is emphasised that the exercise of these new trading powers by the Corporation will be limited to circumstances where it is confronted by a monopoly buyer which the Corporation judges is distorting normal market forces and the use of the power will be subject to Ministerial approval.

The current system of meat trading, based on free market principles and involving some 260 private operators licensed to export meat and livestock, operates reasonably well in normal trading circumstances. However, logic and common sense demand that we do not let a situation continue where the Australian industry, both producers and exporters, could sustain losses in the face of the market-distorting effects of sole buying authorities.

The Bill proposes that the AMLC be given the power to engage in futures trading for livestock or meat, subject to Ministerial approval. Futures trading is a normal commercial technique which should be available to the Corporation if it decides to trade. The intention is to enable the AMLC to hedge price risks through trading on Australian or overseas futures markets. The power has been made subject to Ministerial approval in order to ensure that the approach the Corporation takes, if and when it decides to use the futures market, is consistent with its position as a statutory authority.

In his statement to the Parliament on 8 September 1981 on the meat substitution issue, the Minister clearly stated the Government's resolve to close loopholes which had enabled such fraudulent activities to occur and to implement a system which would ensure that the reputation of the Australian meat and livestock industry was restored to the high level it had previously enjoyed.
The amendments proposed in the Bill and the associated Export Control Bill are clear evidence of the Government's determination in this regard.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

EXPORT CONTROL BILL 1982
The purpose of this Bill is to establish a new and comprehensive legislative base for the export inspection and control responsibilities within the portfolio of the Minister for Primary Industry.

Under existing arrangements, export inspection powers are drawn from the Customs Act 1901 and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905. This has created a number of administrative and legal weaknesses.

Although these could be overcome by amending the existing legislation, the Government has taken the view that the most appropriate long term response is to develop new and separate export inspection legislation which ensures a more efficient and flexible legal framework.

The Bill provides for the application of export controls to goods specified in regulations; spells out inspection responsibilities and the authority of inspection staff to carry out these responsibilities; and sets penalties to apply in the case of fraud or deliberate malpractice.

While the inspection powers under the Bill are to be exercised by officers of the Department of Primary Industry, the Bill also provides for the Secretary of the Department to authorize carriage of such powers as are appropriate by other people. This is to cover the situation where officers of other Commonwealth and State instrumentalities, and in certain instances people under contract, carry out specific or specialised inspection functions on behalf of the Department of Primary Industry.

Powers provided include all those necessary to ensure compliance with the relevant conditions and restrictions. These include appropriate powers of entry and search; powers to detail vehicles, ships or aircraft for this purpose; and powers to seize products within the scope of the controls.

Side by side with these powers are a range of safeguards to avoid abuses by inspection staff. Entry into premises, other than registered premises, can take place only with the consent of the occupier, or in pursuance of a warrant issued by a Justice of the Peace, who must be convinced of the need for entry. A time limit is to be placed on the currency of warrants. Powers of search of vehicles, ships or aircraft are tied to a requirement that authorised officers produce their identity cards. Similarly, people are not required to assist authorised officers in their duties unless such proof of identity is produced. Provisions are also included imposing a limit on the time seized goods can be held unless proceedings are instituted and also for the release, as appropriate, of such goods.

Strict penalties are provided for breaches of the conditions of the Bill and associated regulations. Major penalties of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both apply to the exportation of prescribed goods in contravention of specified requirements; for the use of false trade descriptions; and for unlawful interference with, or forgery of, official marks. Where appropriate, however, it will be possible to proceed against such offences by summary jurisdiction with lesser maximum penalties of $5,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both.

The maximum penalty of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both is the same as that which was approved by Parliament in the 1981 Budget Session following the meat substitution issue. Its inclusion in this Bill will ensure that such a penalty applies to all export inspection and control activities under the Minister for Primary Industry's responsibility.

In addition, this Bill widens the coverage of the penalty by making it an offence for false trade descriptions to be applied to documentation, and for registered establishments to have in their possession an official inspection stamp without authorisation.

The Bill also increases the size of the penalty for a range of other offences, such as failure to submit a notice of intention to export (up from $40 to $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment, or both), and failure to provide assistance to, or the obstruction of, inspection staff (up from $100 to $1000 or 6 months imprisonment, or both).

In the 1981 Budget Session a penalty of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both was introduced for false and misleading statements in declarations furnished in respect of meat. This was to ensure that the maximum penalty applied to offences relating to matters such as the exporter, species, age and slaughter dates which were not covered by existing trade description provisions. These are, however, descriptive matters which are more appropriately located under the trade description requirements. The Bill broadens the definition of trade description to encompass such matters and, as mentioned previously, the application of a false trade description has been extended to documentation. Offences against these matters still, therefore, attract a penalty of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both.

The false declarations provision in the Bill will cover minor breaches only and the penalty has been set at a level appropriate to this offence. The penalty of $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both is the level of penalty generally established in Commonwealth legislation for offences of this kind.

There are two new penalty provisions in the Bill. First a fine of up to $50,000 for breaches of licencing provisions, such as those that exist for woodchips. It will, however, be possible to proceed against such an offence by summary jurisdiction with a maximum penalty of $5,000. Second a penalty of up to $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both for providing any authorised officer, including officers of the Department of Primary Industry, with goods prepared or treated at a registered establishment unless the person in whose name the establishment is registered has the written approval of the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry.

The issue of authorised officers receiving produce either free or at prices below those available to the general public has been raised several times in evidence before the Royal Commission into the Meat Industry. It is a practice which the Minister for Primary Industry has decided must be stopped.

Concurrent with the penalties set out in Clause 24 of the Bill, which apply to those who offer cheap products, the full force of the provisions of the Public Service Act will apply to Commonwealth staff who accept such products.

This change in policy will be notified to all Establishments and authorised officers. The only conditions under which the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry will approve Establishments to sell products to authorised officers is where they have a discrete and separate facility for selling to the public, where the price to those officers is the same as that available to the general public and where the transaction is backed by a receipt which describes the product, price and the purchase date. This approval will be tied to the annual re-registration process with which all establishments must comply and will be strictly enforced by the Compliance Unit now being established in the Department of Primary Industry's new Export Inspection Service.

This Bill is the first fundamental step in providing an appropriate legal basis for export inspection in the 80's and will be backed by new regulations and a system of Ministerial Orders which will allow changing requirements and conditions to be responded to quickly. These regulations and orders are now being drafted.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
EXPORT CONTROL (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982
This Bill sets out amendments to other legislation which are consequential to the passage and proclamation of the Export Control Bill 1982.

Its main features are that it cuts the link between the Minister for Primary Industry's export inspection responsibilities and the Customs Act 1901 and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905. It also repeals the Meat Export ( Penalties) Act 1981 and the higher penalties for all foods which were incorporated in the Customs and Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Acts following the meat substitution issue. These higher penalties are now covered by the Export Control Bill. This Bill is to come into operation on the same day as the Export Control Bill 1982.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

Mr President, this Bill provides for an increase in the salary of the next Governor-General after he is sworn in July. By section 3 of the Constitution it is provided that the salary of the Governor-General shall not be altered during his continuance in office. Thus the salary fixed at the commencement of a Governor-General's appointment must remain unaltered during the period of his office. It means that the salary of the Governor-General cannot be indexed or otherwise changed during his term of office, even if his appointment is extended . It is necessary then for the salary for a new Governor-General to be set at a level which will be commensurate with his office and on a fair and reasonable basis, on the understanding that it will continue at that level during his incumbency of the position and over a period of years.

The Governor-General Act 1974 was introduced by the Labor Government and provided for a salary of $30,000. It was amended in 1977 to increase the salary to $37,000. It is now proposed that the Governor-General's salary be $70,000-a salary that will remain unchanged through the period of the next Governor- General's appointment.

The salary set for the Governor-General by the Labor Government in 1974 put the salary of the Governor-General considerably ahead of the salary of the Chief Justice of the High Court on a tax free basis. The Government is now proposing a salary of $70,000 for the new Governor-General bearing in mind the relationships and movements in the salary of the Chief Justice and CPI increases since 1974, and the need to establish a salary which must, by the terms of the Constitution, remain fixed for some years ahead. The salary of the Chief Justice is also the yardstick referred to in section 4 of the Governor-General Act 1974 for determining the pension payable to a former Governor-General or his spouse. The current gross salary for the Chief Justice is $87,000.

In 1974 the then Prime Minister put forward some important principles as applying to consideration by the Parliament of the Governor-General's remuneration. They were that the Governor-General's salary should be dealt with in a non-party way; that the salary should recognise the importance and place of his high office; and that the appointment of a Governor-General should not depend on personal wealth or the availability of other income.

The Government Parties, then in opposition, strongly supported these principles and still do. They were restated by this Government on introduction of the 1977 Bill. I would now like to commend those principles, first enunciated by Mr Whitlam, again as a basis for the current proposals.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to speak to the first reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82 on a matter which has caused me grave concern since the debate in this chamber on Thursday of last week on General Business Notice of Motion No. 15 standing in my name and dealing with cheap home loans to Ministers. SPEECH.PARA: Another matter causes me grave concern. On 18 November last year I placed the following question on notice. I asked a question of the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. That Minister happens to be Senator Messner, who took part in the debate last Thursday night. I asked:
(1) How many people in the Australian Capital Territory are in receipt of long term Commonwealth Home Loans at interest rates fixed at 6.25 per cent per annum, or lower.
(2) What income brackets are these people in and what are the terms and interest rates applicable to each income bracket.
(3) Are any of the recipients Cabinet Ministers, if so what are their names and the terms and interest rates applicable to their respective loans.
(4) How many persons, if any, in each of the States were able to obtain the same generous long term low-interest provisions of the Commonwealth Home Loans.

It is just six months, nearly to the day, since I put that question on notice. I am still waiting for an answer. Yet in the debate on 29 April in the Senate, which I have just spoken about, on my notice of motion concerning these cheap home loans, Senator Messner, in rebuttal of some of the remarks that I made, said:

I know that Senator McLaren mentioned one or two people who had low interest loans in the Australian Capital Territory but I note that there were many others . In fact, 5,900 people in the Australian Capital Territory--
My interjection was:
Not Ministers.
Senator Messner went on to say:
I will come to that in a moment. In the Australian Capital Territory 5,900 people have benefited from this concession.

The question I pose today is: Why is it that the Minister can use those figures in a debate when I have had that question on the Notice Paper for six months now and I have not yet received an answer? I think it is a gross abuse of the forms of this House that he has not provided me with that answer, yet he must have it because he used it in that debate. I am now requesting that I be provided with the complete answer to question No. 1600 before we enter into the debate in the Committee of the Whole dealing with the appropriations for the Australian Capital Territory. If I have not got that answer I will do as I have done on previous occasions: I will persist in this chamber until I get the answer, as I had to persist in the Committee stage of the Budget Bill last year. It was a long, drawn-out procedure before the Minister-the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-who was in charge of the Bill saw fit to provide me with a document which, in fact, made public the fact that Mr Nixon and Mr Anthony were in receipt of those home loans. Of course, Senator Messner mentioned some others in the debate the other night. I have the relevant document. I have another document, too, which I will not use now; I will use it when that debate resumes. I am asking the Minister now that I be provided with the answer that I am seeking before we go into the Committee of the Whole to consider the appropriations for the Australian Capital Territory when we resume in the week after next.

There is one other thing that I want to refer to. Despite the fact that the Senate, by vote, agreed to the change of sitting hours, I have been told in the corridors that some agreement was entered into that no quorums or divisions would be called on Thursdays. I have no jurisdiction over divisions but I am not bound by any agreement entered into on the calling of quorums. It is now almost 1.30 p.m.; we have been in the chamber since 10 o'clock. Some honourable senators had to attend committee meetings earlier today, as we did yesterday; some of us were here at 7.30 a.m. to attend committee hearings. We did not get away until midnight last night. If honourable senators look at the Government benches they will see that there are two honourable senators there. They are the ones who in the main supported the new sitting times; my party did, too. Some of the Ministers opposed it. I am happy to say that Senator Tate and I stuck up for good trade union principles that we do not take away hard-won gains and the lunch hours of workers. I claim that we in this place are workers. We find now that all of those people who voted for the change are away enjoying their lunches. Those of us who wanted to speak on reports or papers being tabled who had our names down to speak in the first reading debate and who have our names down to speak in the debate on another Bill do not know just when the debates will come on. So we have to sit here. Once again we have to go without our lunch .

Today the sitting hours of the Senate are 10 a.m. until 7 o'clock tonight. If honourable senators are interested in a Bill they cannot leave the place because they never know when it will come on. I say here and now, as I said during the debate on the recommendations of the Senate Standing Orders Committee to change the sitting hours, that I am not bound by any agreement not to call quorums. Conventions have been broken in this place quite a few times since I first came to it. I well recall the conventions, which are far more important than some agreement about the calling of quorums, which were broken in 1975. So honourable senators who are sitting in the dining room enjoying their lunch while I have to stay in this chamber in case the Roads Grants Amendment Bill comes on should not be disappointed if they have to leave their steaks half eaten and their meals are cold when they return. As I have said, I am free to call a quorum at any time I may see fit. I advise the Government and members of my own party that I will not be bound by the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I must make one point perfectly clear to you and to this chamber. You mentioned that you were advising the Government. I think that your advice should be directed to the Senate chamber. The decision relating to sitting hours was a Senate decision made as a result of a recommendation from the Senate Standing Orders Committee. I think that should be on the record so that it is clearly understood.
