—I accept what you have said, Mr President. I was remiss in saying that I was warning the Government. I take note of what you have said. I just give notice to the Senate of my intentions. Whilst that recommendation came from the Standing Orders Committee, as you said, Mr President, a vote was taken- a free vote I might add-of all members of the Senate and the great majority of them voted for the changed sitting hours. I am saying that those honourable senators who voted to take away a person's rights to have an hour's meal break should have no objection, if they are enjoying their meal break and some of us cannot enjoy it, to being interrupted and called back here because a quorum has been called. I take note of what you have said to me, Mr President. As I have said, I was remiss in criticising the Government but if you look at the Hansard record you will see that I criticised some members of my own party also.
—I did not comment on that basis; my remarks were purely for qualification. The sitting hours are a Senate responsibility, and the decision was the Senate's.

—I understand that, Mr President. I again sound the warning that I did not vote for the new hours and neither did my colleague Senator Tate. Some of the Ministers did not vote for them either. We were the oddballs out but I still maintain my right to call a quorum if I wish to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity in the first reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82 to draw to the attention of the Senate a problem which has concerned me increasingly for a number of years. I am getting increasingly bad reports about the treatment and limited service that Australian nationals receive from Australian embassies around the world. I imagine that just about everybody who has been overseas or who knows somebody overseas has some kind of anecdote to tell about the problems that they have faced in a country that they have visited or that they have heard that others have faced overseas. Clearly, not all of these situations are reprehensible or require looking into, but what is bothering me at the moment is that far too many people are saying to me in passing at social functions or when visiting me in my office that they are unhappy about the treatment that they have received at the hands of staff in Australian embassies overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: The specific case that I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate today is that of a young couple whom I know personally and whose reports I would not question. I refer specifically to a series of incidents that they have reported because they went to the trouble of writing to me and I therefore do not have to rely on notes that I took in my office or simply on memory. With the indulgence of the Senate I will read the major part of the letter that was sent to me. It begins by asking me to ask the Federal Government to examine critically the attitudes and purpose of Australian embassies. The letter states:
Dear Senator Haines,
I request that the attitudes and purpose of Australian embassies be critically examined with the intention of at least bringing them in line with other foreign embassies overseas.

One of the major complaints I received came from people who have been travelling in groups and have met up with people of other nationalities who have had similar problems and have received better service from their embassies than Australian nationals are receiving from their own Embassy. The letter goes on:

My experience with Australian embassies in overseas countries has been unsatisfactory to say the least. In order to indicate my point more clearly, I will recount some of the more recent encounters with Australian embassies.

One of the incidents was entirely the fault of the writer of this letter; the other one was not. Notwithstanding that, I feel that the assistance he received from the Embassy was somewhat lacking. The letter continues:

In 1980-81 I spent six months in Indonesia, four and a half months of which were without official sanction from the Indonesian authorities, that is to say, for 4 1/2 months, I did not have an official visa.
Clearly, the man concerned went to Indonesia on a tourist visa and overstayed it . His letter continues:
Some five days before my departure from Indonesia--
That is, his eventual departure-

I decided to ''give myself up'' to the Indonesian Immigration Authorities, but before doing so I thought it wise to approach the Australian Embassy in Jalan Thamrin Jakarta, to inform them of my status and to seek advice. I was not seeking assistance in terms of finance at the expense of the Australian taxpayer , rather advice as to what, in the opinion of the Australian Embassy, I should do, and what they thought would happen to me as a result. Instead of receiving any real assistance, I had to suffer an incourteously delivered lecture indicating that I should not have done what I already had; a fact of which I was already quite aware. I asked as to what course of action might be best, and instead of receiving an answer to the question, was told that I would most certainly be sent to jail in addition to which I would have to pay a substantial fine. On enquiring whether or not the Australian Embassy could lend me the money to cover the fine I discovered that the monies which Australian Embassies are authorised to lend is $40, a sum which had not changed since I was in Spain seven years previously.

After leaving the Australian Embassy without any of my questions answered, I presented myself to the Indonesian Immigration Office in Jalan Cikini, Jakarta. The events which ensued indicated to me that the Australian Embassy knew nothing of the procedures adopted by the Indonesian Authorities and they could not be bothered finding out; both the former and the latter being their duty to Nationals. The Immigration Office did not fine me anything nor did they put me in jail as the Australian Embassy had said they would. This incident took place at the end of January 1981.

A second unscheduled encounter with the Australian Embassy took place on or about the 29th of December 1981, also in Jakarta. A friend and I had been travelling by train from Jakarta to Surakarta in Central Java when my friend had her handbag stolen. Included in the contents of her bag were both our passports, our travellers cheques and most of our cash monies.
I am prepared to accept at this point that that was a rather dumb thing to do. The letter goes on:
We reported the incident to the Indonesian police in Yogyakarta and returned to Jakarta two days later after borrowing money from a friend in Surakarta.

I have photocopies of the report that this couple filed with the Indonesian police in Yogyakarta. They are not of much use to the Senate since they are written entirely in Indonesian, but I do have them. The letter continues:

We entered the Australian Embassy in Jalan Thamrin and were met with what seems to be the employees customary rudeness to Australians. Apart from the renewal of our passports, we were in need of other information, one piece being the address of a bank in Jakarta which had connections with the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia Pty Ltd.
As the writer pointed out in an earlier sentence, the couple's travellers cheques had been stolen. The letter goes on:

We were instantly and confidently informed that there were no banks in Jakarta which had such a relationship; a piece of information which I found hard to believe; since I had in the past sent monies to Indonesia through the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia Pty Ltd. The Embassy proved efficient only in renewing our passports. That is to say that they were only efficient in renewing our passports, not in giving the passports to us. We politely informed them that we had only limited money which we needed for food. They responded by asking whether the hotel in which we were staying in Jakarta required us to pay on a daily basis. We replied that due to my personal contact with the proprietor in the past, it was not necessary for us to pay on a daily basis. This seemed to provide them with sufficient information to determine that we were not destitute -(their word) and therefore could not receive our passports until we had paid the full thirty dollars each for them. 'Them' being passports valid only for 3 months. We told them that we needed the passports in order to collect and cash our renewed travellers cheques when they arrived.
a fact which ought to have been patently apparent to the Embassy people, even if the catch-22 situation was not-
For this, one passport was released under sufferance. As it happened, the passport which they released was not compatible with the first lot of travellers cheques to be renewed.
They released the woman's passport and it was the man whose travellers cheques arrived first-
Consequently more of our limited money was used because of the illinformed, intolerant stupidity of the Australian Embassy.

I accept that those intemperate words are probably more due to frustration than anything else. Nevertheless, the preceding events seem to indicate that the staff member or members to whom this couple went were slightly less than well informed. The letter continues:

No thanks to the inefficiency and indifferent attitude of the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, we managed to survive. The fact that we had to pay $30 for passports that required us to provide birth certificates and evidence of our identities in order to extend them for five years, is unjust. Surely the issuing office has records of the people to whom they issue passports, but then perhaps that is too intelligently simple for the bureaucrats involved in such activities to conceive of. It seems to me that Australian Embassies are not interested in Australians overseas and nor do they seem to have competent people on their staff. From my experience with this type of Public Service staff, people are employed because of their . . .
It goes on to note some inconsequential fury about Public Service staff which I do not intend to repeat to the Senate. The letter continues:

When will Australians overseas be able to speak and feel towards their Embassies with the same degree of pride that one hears from travellers of other countries? The only factors Australian Embassies have which cause Australians to feel that the Embassy represents a piece of Australia, is the fact that they are closed on days which are public holidays in Australia, albeit that such days bear no significance to the country of placement of the Embassy.

I will accept, of course, the obvious rejoinder that the man concerned got himself into the first difficulty by illegally extending his stay in Indonesia and that the couple got themselves into the second predicament because they put all their belongings into one handbag. Of course, any tourist ought to know that that is not a particularly intelligent manoeuvre in a country such as Indonesia where handbag snatching seems to be a national pastime. I was later told that the couple was travelling on a train when this occurred and that they reported it to the guard on the train-not that it made any difference because the train did not stop. Somebody-I do not know whether it was the person concerned or somebody else-on the train chased the thief across the top of the train until he fell off. I know this is beginning to sound like something out of a B grade movie but I am assured it actually happened. Then, as the letter points out, they reported the theft to the Indonesian police as soon as they arrived at a station.

Bearing in mind that the vote for salaries and payments in the nature of salaries for overseas service personnel employed by the Department of Foreign Affairs was allocated in the vicinity of $60m of taxpayers' money in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82, and a further $700,000 in additional appropriations in the Supplementary Estimates, one would be led to expect that the service provided to Australian nationals by those staff would be exemplary. The couple involved in this incident told me that some German travellers had bags which were tied to their beings removed. Somebody cut through the thongs. They received quite different attention from their Embassy than the lack of assistance that this couple received from the Australian Embassy. I understand that there are 82 staff members of the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs in embassies in Indonesia. Of course, there are vast numbers-in excess of 2,000- in other countries around the world. I would have thought that among the first things that the staff would be educated in would be local laws and ground rules, the problems that are likely to face travellers in the country concerned and the red tape involved. For instance, the German Embassy provided a letter to the German nationals who had had their bag containing their passports and so on stolen so that they could go to the Indonesian authorities and not be arrested for selling their passports or encouraging people wanting to run drugs. That seems to be a fairly sensible measure to take in countries not noted for their democratic police methods. Surely, staff members of these embassies ought to be coached in the legal system operating within the country and be able to answer the questions that Australian nationals are likely to raise with them, leaving aside completely whether the Australian national was responsible for the mess he got himself into.

Finally, I would have thought that staff members would be expected, indeed encouraged, to be courteous and helpful to Australian nationals who go to them with their problems, which may be petty, which may have been heard a million times before but which are of great moment to the nationals concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to utilise the time available to me this afternoon to raise a question relating to the situation within Telecom Australia. We are all very much aware that Telecom in recent years has been fighting with one hand tied behind its back. It has suffered restrictions both financially and by way of staff ceilings. Most of us are aware that within Telecom there is a quite substantial cross-subsidisation from profitable to non- profitable areas. In that arena there is a cross-subsidisation of around $300m from profitable areas to rural areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I also mention at this juncture the announcement made by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) in relation to the setting up of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia. I was surprised to find that what appeared to me to be the only method of communication and the only method of announcement was by way of a Press release by the Minister last spring. On inquiry in my own State at Christmas time, I became very much aware that rural local government bodies in Victoria were completely unaware that this Inquiry had been set up. As I interpret the guidelines which the Minister set down for the Davidson Inquiry, one of its most drastic effects could be upon the telecommunications system in rural areas. I then found that the closing date for submissions, if I remember correctly, was 26 February. Many local government bodies found it extremely difficult because of the dates of their meetings to be able to get submissions to that Inquiry in time. Be that as it may, the Davidson Inquiry is now under way.

The matter I particularly wish to raise is the proposal within Telecom to close down rural manual exchanges. Proposals are afoot to close down some 23 rural manual exchanges in Australia including five in Victoria, namely those at Dromana, Frankston, Hamilton, Horsham and Swan Hill, leaving only two manual exchanges in the metropolitan area and one provincial manual exchange, at Bendigo. Any of us who live in country areas have become extremely aware of the effect that Access 80 had on the time it takes to dial a trunk number, that is, any number outside the local areas, on subscriber trunk dialling.

Between 6 p.m. and 9 p.m. in particular one can quite easily dial for an hour and get the busy signal. So one has to sit and wait. I have had a lot of complaints made to me about this problem from elderly people who try to ring their sons and daughters and from sons and daughters who try to ring their parents over distances of 200 or 300 miles. They find that they cannot get through during this period, the fault being that there are insufficient lines to cope with the innovation of Access 80. However, by and large, I think people accept it. They say that if the matter is not urgent they will try to ring again the next night and hope that they will get through. Behind that there is also a realisation that while there is a manual exchange in the area they can dial that exchange and know full well that the operators, mainly ladies, on the switch will move both hell and high water in order to get them through. I have had the experience in an emergency of having a call from my home town of Warrnambool to Bendigo rerouted via Darwin and Alice Springs. I got through-that is the important thing-and in a very short space of time. Up until about five or six years ago, in my area anyhow, those switch girls had lines available to them only which could be utilised in an emergency. Five years ago those lines were taken out of the system. Now the switch girls have to vie with everybody else on the normal trunk route system except in the case of dire emergencies, when they may, by using codes known only to themselves, be able to break into another exchange and thus to reroute a call via that exchange and get a person through.

Let us consider the sort of thing that is happening. I know for a fact that it is happening in my area; I suggest it is happening also in other areas. The phone number of the office of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria in the city of Warrnambool is 62 1177. That number is operated manually from 8 a.m. until 4.50 in the afternoon. After that one gets a recorded message advising one to ring such and such a number in Geelong. That means that after 4.50 in the afternoon, in the event of a blackout, a pole fire or whatever, one must try to ring Geelong and vie with the rest of the traffic on the trunk lines. Perhaps one would have to queue up for up to an hour to get through. If the emergency reached a certain peak, staff would be put on to the local switchboard and that number would be operated manually. But regardless of how the situation develops in that case, the original caller or complainant must ring Geelong, which is a distance of 120 miles away and vie with the rest of the traffic on the line in the hope of getting through with his message.

As I mentioned earlier, one can always get on to the manual operators in a dire emergency and get them to utilise the methods that they have by way of codes or whatever to break through the system. These manual exchanges are now to be closed. As I said earlier, in Victoria only two manual exchanges in the metropolitan area and one provincial exchange, that at Bendigo, will continue to operate. In the case of an emergency, such as a death in the family, the telephone lines might be clagged up particularly in those hours that I mention, between 6 p.m. and 9 p.m., and the only way through the system would be to vie with the rest of the trade on the trunk line system between any area of Victoria and the metropolitan area or any area of Victoria and the manual exchange in Bendigo. That will become almost an impossibility.

Another consideration is the employment that the manual exchanges have provided over generations, for young and mature-aged females, in particular. I know that Telecom will say: 'Yes, we will provide a job for you somewhere else'. Somewhere else may be two hours drive or two days drive away. Many of these people have financial obligations in the towns in which they live and there is no way that they could pick up their roots and travel with the job.

One of the most important assets of the people who operate the manual exchanges is their specific and local knowledge. In many cases they were born and bred in the area where they work. They know where Brown's Hill, Smith's Knoll, William's Corner and other local places are. In the event of being contacted about a disaster such as a car accident, a fire or a flood they are able to contact all the emergency services with specific knowledge of just where that accident or crisis is. If we do away with these people, no one will really know where the closest doctor is, the name of the doctor who is open at that moment, the names of the personnel at the fire station or whatever. Whilst the emergency service system in rural areas may not break down, it will become an extremely tardy arrangement.

Telecom figures show that an average of 6.7 per cent of trunk telephone calls failed to get through because of the overload on Telecom switching equipment in 1981. Congestion on the system, about which I have spoken, results when the demand for calls exceeds the ability of the equipment to carry them. For example , when the cheaper STD rates apply after 6 p.m., more people try to make trunk calls, but the number of lines is the same. When all the lines are busy and there are still people trying to dial STD numbers they get a busy signal. According to Telecom, in some areas, including Orange, Griffith and Tamworth in New South Wales, over 12 per cent of STD calls were ineffective. In the Orange dialling area, a staggering 59.7 per cent of STD calls failed to get through after 9 p.m. because of overloading of the switching network. That is a fairly disastrous situation for the residents in that dialling area, particularly in an emergency. I know that it costs money to keep people in rural areas. But really, if Telecom is to play the role which the Australian Labor Party wants it to play and not be hidebound by the restrictions placed on it, I believe that it should be providing a service across Australia and should not be forced into the financial stringencies that it has been forced into and the curtailment of services everywhere in order to try to balance its books.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take a great deal of time in the debate on this Bill but I think it is important that I raise a couple of matters in relation to the lack of planning, particularly in Western Australia. We have lately found that, with fairly rapid development, it is becoming quite impossible for people in certain areas to plan what their immediate future holds for them and, particularly, for their children. On Monday of this week, prior to leaving for Canberra, I had the opportunity to go to the Orange Grove Primary School to present a flag. I was rather disturbed at what I saw.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, it took me much longer to find the school than I anticipated it would. Whilst the school is clearly marked on a map-it is a very new map compiled by the Main Roads Department-a number of roads have been closed and these were not indicated. This has been occasioned by the construction of a freeway which, in fact, goes through the grounds of the school. To be exact the freeway uses half of the school oval. The effect this has had on the school is rather traumatic, particularly for the teachers and children who are involved, not only because of the noise that now emanates from the freeway. Prior to the construction of that roadway there were 130 students at this small primary school. I do not think it was ever envisaged by the Education Department that it would be anything more than a small primary school. In the telephone book the Department lists the school as being on a road that has not existed for some years. If one looks at the back of the road map one will find that it is still shown as being on Bickley Road but, of course, it is not on Bickley Road at all. It is at the end of a very small laneway.

It is in an ideal setting for a small primary school and, as I have said, it was never envisaged by the Department that it would be anything more than a small primary school. Prior to the construction of the freeway the school accommodated 130 children and it had seven classrooms and a principal. When the freeway was constructed, taking up half the oval, the school complained, saying that it needed some playing areas. It was decided then that the oval would be reconstructed above the school but still in the grounds. The school now has a magnificent, fully reticulated, full-sized oval. The problem is that the population at the school has decreased to 33 children, 10 of whom will be leaving at the end of this year. It is now a two-teacher school. One teacher is the principal, who is employed on a full time basis, plus one other and there is a teacher who comes in on a part time basis. The spread of the two classes is grades 1 to 4 and grades 5 to 7, which means that none of the children who attend get the proper attention that they should from the teacher, and the teacher is, of course, distracted by the variety of classes she or he has to teach.

The main problem appears to be that the major part of the population of the school came from across the freeway. Of course, parents are a little apprehensive about letting their children go across the freeway. The Main Roads Department was approached with a view to putting in a walkover. The Department advised the school that it should have the population before the walkover was constructed. The school, of course, cannot provide the population until the overpass has been constructed. So there has been a total lack of planning right the way through.

For instance, the Main Roads Department did not know that it would take up a portion of the oval. One presumes that it did not know in the initial stages. But, having determined that that was where the road had to go, one would have anticipated that someone would have said: 'We have to provide access for the children who would normally be accommodated at this school'. That did not eventuate and, as I have said, the school is now down to a total of 33 students. They have a magnificently constructed, fully reticulated oval and they do not even have enough boy students to have a full sized Australian Rules football team. The only school with which they can play any sport on a competitive basis is many miles away because, apparently, under the education system they have to compete with schools of a similar size. So the whole thing is rather ludicrous.

With the closure of the roads it has become necessary for some of those students who are still attending the Orange Grove Primary School to now travel 5 1/2 kilometres by car. I find this a little hard to believe, but I have spoken to the mother of one of the children who attended the school until the freeway went through. She assures me that because they are a one-car family and because her husband needs the car for work she has had to change the school that her child attends. This is just because she cannot get the child from point A to point B. I think that is rather a tragic situation. I envisage that, because there is only a possible intake of one child next year and because 10 children will be leaving the school, the Education Department in Western Australia may well see fit actually to close the school. I think that would be a tragedy.

It is rather nice, I suppose, to have the amount of room that is available at the moment. Having seven classrooms with only two of them being fully utilised means that the children have an indoor gymnasium where they can have physical education instruction. They have a room which has been set aside for arts so that each one has his or her particular place in the room and does not have to take away the art materials all the time. The Parents and Citizens Association decided that it would like to accept responsibility for some portion of the school but, of course, the Association has diminished as well, as only 33 children are attending the school. This means that the P and C would be responsible for a certain section but that it would never own it as it is a school building. So the P and C took down a partition between two of the rooms intending that it would become a fairly large area which could be used for entertainment.

Recently, one of the local young ladies who was getting married approached the P and C about hiring this area at the school grounds because the surroundings are so very pleasant. She approached those people in relation to holding her wedding reception there. While plans were under way they were advised that whilst the P and C actually administers that section of the school, because it is on school grounds and, therefore, is under the control of the Education Department, that area nevertheless was not allowed to be used for social functions where liquor would be available. I thought that that was rather a tragedy because it means that the school virtually has no income, if it is reliant on the parents of the 33 students attending the school, some of whom come from the same family. I have to question whether there is enough consultation in the planning for this type of operation.

That leads me straight on to the next subject which I want to raise. I am sure that we have all had the opportunity over the last few days to meet with the telephonists from Telecom Australia. Once again I am led to believe that there has been a lack of consultation. I am extremely disturbed about a situation that has been outlined in relation to my State of Western Australia. It would appear that, on paper, the service will improve and I would be very grateful for that, particularly because of those people who are rather isolated. In areas where there might be 50 miles or 60 miles between farmhouses it is necessary to have some means of communication. However, the outline that has been provided to me would indicate that everything is going to be centralised to the point where everybody would be competing for the use of the same lines.

If, for instance, I was in Broome and I wished to contact someone in the south- west at, say, Albany or Bunbury, my call would be directed through the central exchange in Perth which would take up that one line. It would then be transmitted further through to Bunbury, thence taking up another line. The Bunbury member would be contacted. The call would then go back to the Perth central exchange and come back to me in Derby or wherever I happened to be, thus creating congestion on those lines. I would be very interested if someone from Telecom or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), who represents the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), could tell me that my assessment of the figures that have been put before me is incorrect.

My second concern in relation to the same matter is the employment of people in small towns. I cite a country town such as Northam which has some 7,000 inhabitants and which possibly employs eight to ten telephonists; I do not know the full strength. If we look at the wage component circulated throughout the town with the provision of goods and services, we have to accept that in a town of that size it would be of considerable benefit to have those people employed. I have not had from Telecom in relation to the question I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the other day any satisfactory comment or response that would lead me to believe that those people will be either engaged in employment of an advisory nature, such as on the 0175 service, or even available, for instance, to manage the 000 emergency service.

That brings me to point three of this subject that I wish to debate; that is, the provision of the emergency service. I think we are all fairly well aware of how the service operates at the moment, but we have to express some concern if the information we are given is correct; that once computerisation of the country exchanges goes forward the 000 emergency calls will compete for the same lines used by people who wish to make a telephone call to another point. I would be very grateful if the Minister could provide me with a response that I could pass back to the phonogram operators' association.

I point out that the concern is not only in relation to emergencies but also the role of a telephonist in a country centre. His or her role in an emergency is very important. I cite the instance of the Meckering earthquake in Western Australia a few years ago. Telephone calls were interrupted because of the earthquake. Calls were very speedily rerouted through other areas-through the south-west and thence into the city. The phonogram operators who were on duty at that time apparently decided that they would use an outward line through the south-west and an inward line through those areas just north of Meckering so that there was no jamming of the lines because of over use.

I would like someone to explain to me what will happen in the event that this system becomes fully computerised. I have expressed concern here on a number of occasions for those people who live in the isolated areas of the Pilbara and the Kimberleys for instance as to whether their needs will be serviced in a much more efficient way with the development of a computerised system, whether it will be an integrated system, how long it will take before it is fully operational and what the effect will be if there is a major disaster across the Nullarbor plains. On a number of occasions the lines of communication have been interfered with and completely disrupted between the west and east coasts of this nation because of the distance involved. One has to take all these matters into account.

I want to be assured, before I would allow this system to be introduced-I am sure the Minister would want to be assured-that an alternative system would be available in the event of any interference in one of those major areas. I raised this question the other day, and my colleague Senator Gietzelt raised the matter following my question. The Minister advised us that he would provide us with an answer. I hope that, because Telecom will be at the stage of implementation of the computerised system in the very near future, the responses to those questions will soon be provided by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to utilise the first reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) to raise a matter which was canvassed me a week ago. I had hoped to have an opportunity to raise this matter during Question Time, but on Tuesday I interviewed a constituent who was here with a deputation regarding the problems facing country telephonists and the general services provided in country areas by Telecom Australia. That matter received priority. As I said, I had hoped to have an opportunity to ask this question today, but because of the unsatisfactory way in which the order of questions is determined in this place I was not able to do that. I now refer to the question I had hoped to ask of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack).

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in a substantive sense to the role of a Mr Sankey who, the Senate might recall, was involved in an infamous court case which suggested impropriety in respect of the Prime Minister of Australia during the 1972-75 period and a number of Ministers in that Government, particularly Dr Cairns, Mr Rex Connor and former Senator Murphy. It might be useful to remind the Senate that in that court case the Government played a role that finally resulted in judgment being entered against Mr Sankey to the extent of some $75,000 in costs. The questions that need to be asked are these: Has the Government been able to collect those costs awarded against Mr Sankey? Who was behind Mr Sankey's efforts in those proceedings which were designed to affect considerably the character and standing of eminent citizens of the Australian community and prominent members of my party? The senior counsel in that case was none other than David Rofe, Q.C . Of course, a substantial portion of the costs would have been required to pay that gentleman. One would concede that Mr Rope was heavily involved financially in the prosecution of that case which, allegedly, was a citizen's initiative concerning alleged happenings during the 1972-75 period.

I raise this matter because of the rather remarkable role that the same Mr David Rofe is playing on behalf of this Government in what is commonly described as the Greek conspiracy case. As the evidence presented to a Senate Estimates committee indicates, the same David Rofe has been paid approximately $500,000 in respect of the Greek conspiracy case. One is entitled to question, therefore, whether there has been some arrangement in respect of the Sankey affair and the costs awarded therein, and the role that the Government and/or Mr Rofe played in respect of the Greek conspiracy case. I remind the Senate that the Greek conspiracy case has now assumed proportions unknown anywhere else in the Western world so far as judicial proceedings are concerned.

The Senate will recall that a number of us, particularly Senator Grimes, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place, have from time to time raised the question of the charges laid against members of the Greek community. One can describe that case only as a legal fiasco and a great embarrassment to the Fraser Government. At about 5.30 a.m. on Saturday 31 March 1978 Detective Inspector Don Thomas of the Australian Federal Police, together with a number of other members of the force, visited a considerable number of homes in the Marrickville areas of Sydney. Some 178 people out of the 183 arrested on that morning were charged with conspiring to defraud the Department of Social Security.

This reminds us of the way in which Liberal and conservative governments operate. Honourable senators and those of us who were here during the Vietnam war days will recall the way in which the Attorney-General's Department operated particularly with the young lads who lived in the city areas. Raids were carried out at 4 o'clock and 5 o'clock on Saturday and Sunday mornings. That sort of behaviour was defended by the late Senator Greenwood with a great deal of relish and enthusiasm. I find it particularly repugnant and unacceptable in a democratic society. Honourable senators may recall in the debates that subsequently took place that people who had migrated to this country and settled down in an ordinary Australian environment were panic stricken by the attempts of the police, of the establishment, on those occasions. A great deal of panic, distress, anger and embarrassment was caused to the families of those persons who were arrested. The most incredible thing about that particular raid is that Detective Inspector Thomas, with great flourish and fanfare in the Sunday newspapers, talked about it being virtually the greatest case in Australian legal history. The subsequent four years have shown that the actual case has gone on for 368 days and is costing this Government $20,000 a day. A total of 250 witnesses have been called, there have been 12,000 court exhibits and 30,500 pages of transcript have been compiled, which is about 6 million words. Lo and behold, that only represents the prosecution case.

We can see the melodrama which accompanied the activities of the Federal Police on that case. Only a handful of people have now been charged. The Government has , on the basis of the evidence, withdrawn the overwhelming majority of the charges against the members of the Greek community. Fewer than 20 are waiting for their cases to be heard. I remind the Senate that it is costing us $20,000 a day to defend almost an indefensible position. Of the persons who were arrested, some 736 had their pensions cut on the spot in a very arbitrary, unsatisfactory and heartless fashion. The Government ought to be ashamed of the way in which that incident was organised. One cannot help but see some relationship between the original Sankey case and the role of certain legal persons in the Greek conspiracy case. It can be said that the Government has been advised by Mr David Rofe on these matters. I am not in a position to say whether that advice has been wholly or partly accepted. It is an unsatisfactory state of affairs to have a person who is involved in a clear case of conspiracy against the leaders of the Government in the 1972-75 period also involved in this sort of case and briefed by the Australian Government. The case is still proceeding at the costs I have suggested of approximately $20,000 a day. I wonder how much money the case is costing the Australian taxpayers? It has been suggested that the total cost will exceed $7m. If one were to relate that to the amount of pension that would be paid to those 178 charged persons, I think we would find that we would come out on the right side of the ledger if we had not even commenced the operation.

Clearly, this Government has a lot to account for in the Greek conspiracy case. Mr Sankey is a very unusual person. In dealing with matters affecting my own party in the State of New South Wales he is now appearing for a group of persons who were involved in wholesale corruption of a party branch. That flows from the bashing of Mr Baldwin, M.L.C. some 20 months ago. The same Mr Sankey has turned up in defence of these persons who have been charged by the New South Wales police in a similar case of conspiracy. In my view Mr Sankey's record leaves much to be desired. I know it will be argued and defended that a person is entitled to defend anyone who briefs him. It is somewhat strange that this person was able to launch a citizen's prosecution in an attempt to embarrass and maybe even impeach four leading members of the Labor Administration in 1972-75, and then have costs of $75,000 awarded against him with no explanation as to where that sort of money came from.

A recent program on Nationwide featured a psychiatrist who was asked her opinion in respect of the sufferings of these members of our Greek community and how they had been affected by the heavy-handed attitude of this Government and the melodramatic way in which the Australian Federal Police had operated. One is entitled to draw the conclusions that in both cases-I believe there is a relationship-the role of David Rofe is also open to a great deal of examination.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PETER BAUME
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I present Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82 which, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1981-82 which I shall introduce shortly, comprises the Additional Estimates for 1981-82. In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made under Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1981-82.

One of the principal reasons for Additional Estimates is that, although the original Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary rate increases in the Public Service (including Defence Forces), under long- standing arrangements, that amount was not then appropriated. Those allowances, as well as amounts for wage and salary increases in excess of the allowances, now need to be appropriated. As well, funding is required for new government initiatives undertaken and cost and price increases arising since the Budget was prepared.
The additional appropriations total $811.8m: of this, $740.4m is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and $71.4m in Appropriation Bill (No. 4).

The additional appropriations sought in the Bills are offset in part by savings in appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1981-82, resulting partly from the Government's determined efforts to achieve savings in expenditure wherever possible. These savings, amounting to $361.3m, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document, 'Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations', which has been distributed to honourable senators.

Notwithstanding the additional appropriations now sought, on current information, total outlays in 1981-82, including provisions in annual appropriations and those outlays financed from special appropriations, would be about one and a half per cent above the budget Estimates. While this increase over the Budget estimates is higher than that experienced last year, the Government considers the increase is unavoidable in view of the need to maintain essential services and programs. The Government was faced this year with substantial wage and salary increases and other strong pressures which indicated a significant overrun on outlays. In keeping with its expenditure restraint policies, it has conducted a rigorous review of spending in order to reduce net additional requirements by offsetting unavoidable increases with reductions elsewhere wherever possible.
I now outline some of the main areas where the Government has found it necessary to seek additional appropriations in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981- 82.

Included in the amount Parliament is now being asked to appropriate is an estimated $409.1m to meet increases in award rates and other wage and salary costs since the Budget, consisting of $177.2m (civil) and $231.9m (Defence Forces). These amounts do not include the wage and salary component of additional funds being provided to statutory authorities funded under one line appropriations. This compares with an allowance of $160m included in the overall Budget figuring.

An amount of $14.1m is included under the Department of Communications to enable the Australian Broadcasting Commission to maintain its services without major cutbacks in 1981-82, in the face of salary increases.

Under Department of Defence, provision of $35.1m is made for initial payments on a mine counter-measure vessel, the aircraft carrier 'Invincible' and modernisation of guided missile destroyers, after taking into account slippage against other projects.
An additional amount of $4.9m under Department of Education covers expenses for the Australian National University.

A provision of $10.1m is sought under the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs for existing community-based youth support scheme projects following the Government's decision to continue the scheme under revised guidelines.
An amount of $9.0m is sought under Department of Foreign Affairs for the provision of additional food aid for Afghan refugees in Pakistan and to meet food shortages in Bangladesh and Madagascar.
Included under Department of Health is an amount of $6.6m for the continuing essential operations of the Capital Territory Health Commission.
On significant amounts for which provision is sought in the Bill include:
$63.0m under the Department of Housing and Construction to discharge existing commitments under the Home Savings Grants Scheme;
$4.7m under the Department of Science and Technology for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, mainly for wage and salary cost increases;
$11.0m for the Department of Trade and Resources to meet calls of contributions to buffer stocks established under the International Tin Agreement and the International Natural Rubber Agreement;

$22.8m under the Department of Transport to meet the anticipated operating losses of the Australian National Railways Commission; this comprises $13.9m to meet the projected increase in the Commission's 1981-82 operating loss and, following legal advice, the re-appropriation of an amount of $8.9m which was originally appropriated in the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1981-82; and

$6.8m for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to allow for increased fees and higher than anticipated demand for the services of specialists, medical officers , physiotherapists and other allied health professions.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to conclude the debate on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill, which has been dealt with over the last two or three days in this chamber. It has been a very wide ranging and interesting debate on several aspects of the income tax law, but in particular the focus has been on six subjects which, of course, are elements of this Bill. The first one I mention is zone allowances. This provision results from the recent inquiry into zone allowances in Australia and the Government's having taken the decision to increase them. Senator Kilgariff and Senator Crichton-Browne in particular spoke on these subjects, emphasising the very great need and indeed the contribution of people who live in the outback areas of Australia and the support that the Government should endeavour to thrust their way to ensure that they have lives at least somewhat comparable to the lives of those living in more comfortable circumstances. During the debate several points were made. I do not intend to canvass those, but they are on the record and they certainly emphasise the Government's concern for these people and their problems which, of course, the Government continually takes into account when considering policies, be they of a tax nature or of another kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson, in debating the issue of the incorporation of medical practices , raised the famous Peate's case, which involved medical practices of some 15 years ago. The fact is that that case focused on the issue of the incorporation of medical practices for the purposes of tax avoidance. Those kinds of principles are now being enshrined in the operation of medical practices as they have been condoned by the medical registration boards and other legal authorities within the States. Of course, they are at variance with the circumstances of the cases in the time before Peate's case, and consequently a different set of circumstances applies these days. The Government has moved to recognise that and, indeed, has provided for such practices to receive taxation treatment similar to that provided for persons who practice alone.

Senator Button mentioned several matters ranging widely over various elements of the report of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee including areas that the Government considers from time to time in assessing its taxation policy. Those matters, of course, receive consideration from time to time. The theme, I think, that he was stressing was that simplicity is required in the tax law. I think the Government agrees with that. The difficulties, of course, are that these days taxation avoidance schemes and other means of defeating and circumventing the law have become so sophisticated and involved that the law required to regulate them has become correspondingly complex. Consequently, the Income Tax Assessment Act has grown enormously in recent years. It is an unfortunate fact of life that that will probably continue while we have the degree of taxation avoidance that is attempted in this community.

On the general issue of tax avoidance, there is no doubt that the actions taken by the Government in recent years to legislate against particular schemes that have been sold within the community have, on the whole, been very successful. It is interesting to note that many professional advisers are recognising that there has been a change of attitude in the community to blatant paper-type artificial tax avoidance devices. The incidence of such devices is correspondingly reducing in the community. It is certainly a welcome trend. I hope that it is confirmed by later evidence on these matter. Clearly it is a result of the Government's determination to defeat, when it possibly can, artifical tax schemes of the sort that we have seen peddled around this community over the last three or four years.

I turn to the partiuclar points which are the subject of the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion and of the already foreshadowed amendments to the Bill to be moved at the Committee stage. It is clear that there is a fundamental difference in attitude and philosophy, when dealing with the issue of tax avoidance, between the Government and the Opposition. That has been discussed on many occasions, but it is not fair-as Senator Walsh asserted during his speech-to claim that the Government is soft on tax avoidance and takes no action at all. In fact, it has been demonstrated, as I have just pointed out, that there has been considerable progress against schemes of the blatant sort. One has only to check with the tax community, particularly the professional people involved in this area, to understand that they realise that a great deal has occurred over the last few years.

The Opposition's proposal is to legislate retrospectively in respect of each individual scheme as soon as the scheme becomes known; that is, to go back to the first point at which such a scheme becomes identifiable. That is a solution which the Government has not accepted because clearly it offends those general principles of the law relating to retrospectivity and, indeed, is not consistent with the general principles which have been enunciated many times in this place and throughout the history of parliaments of British colour.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I think the Labor Party wants to go further than that. It wants to go back to the date from which the scheme operated.

—Indeed. I am sorry that I did not articulate that clearly enough, because that is what I had in mind. It is a very significant amendment which has been moved. The Government's approach to this question is to legislate automatically upon becoming aware that a scheme is in action. Legislation, of course, may not be prepared and ready to go into the Parliament right at that moment, but the Government, by Press statements, publicity in various ways and statements in the Parliament, will put on notice those people who are involved in those schemes that they can be legislated against. Indeed, people who continue to adopt those practices will find themselves in a difficult situation when appropriate legislation is finally introduced into the Parliament. That is the Government's approach. It is a fair approach. It employs the principle, if you like, of caveat emptor-people do things at their own risk once they have been put on notice by the Government. Those are the fundamental differences between the Opposition and the Government on the matter. Clearly, the Opposition 's first five amendments to the second reading motion will not be accepted by the Government when they are put to a vote. That is our general attitude also to the amendments to clauses concerning retrospectivity which I understand the Opposition will be moving during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to one or two matters that were raised during the debate. First of all I acknowledge the very significant speech made by Senator Hill in respect of depreciation on industrial machinery and equipment. His general proposition was that these rates of depreciation which are allowable for taxation purposes are too low by today's standards and that they do not properly take account of obsolescence and the degree of change which is occurring in the industrial sphere these days. Naturally enough, this has been an area of great concern to the Government in discussions with industry leaders over the last five years or so. Recognition of this point is made in the fact that this Bill incorporates special rates of depreciation for the iron and steel industry. In that context there is an argument for support for industry emanating from the kind of support which Senator Hill has in mind. I believe that the best approach to those problems is a general review of government policies in respect of industries. That of course is a matter for advice from the Industries Assistance Commission to the Government. It is a matter which is constantly before the Government and constantly under review. Nevertheless, I acknowledge that there are significant difficulties in particular industries in this regard. The Government will be monitoring those issues from time to time.

Senator Evans spoke at length on the matter of retrospectivity in general but he focused on section 26AAA and its application to certain transactions conducted by the Bell group of companies last year. The amendment which is to be moved by the Opposition in the Committee stage seeks to include those transactions in the general provisions contemplated by this Bill. The Government will not be accepting that amendment because of the general argument which I outlined earlier. The Commissioner of Taxation, in normal circumstances, in addition to taking action under section 26AAA in this kind of situation, would consider the possible application of section 25 and section 26A of the Income Tax Assessment Act in any case where property is acquired and disposed of by a taxpayer within 12 months. However, the secrecy provisions of that Act preclude the Commissioner from disclosing the outcome of such consideration in individual cases. That is a matter which will need to be left to the Commissioner. The Government will not be supporting that amendment. We hope that we will have sufficient support to reject it.

I turn now to the general provision on profit shifting, as it has become known in this place, about which there has been a great deal of debate over the last few days. First of all, a great deal of concern was evinced by Senator Tate when he made several references to the revised Division 13. As he rightly pointed out , transfer pricing practices are merely one means of international profit shifting but the phrase has become a convenient shorthand reference to describe a broader problem. As the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) pointed out in her second reading speech, the growth of international investment , the relative ease with which money, goods or technology cross international boundaries, improved communications and the development of the network of tax havens have all served to facilitate profit shifting arrangements by transnational enterprises both Australian and foreign based.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the more reason why you should impose meaningful penalties.

—I will come to that in a moment. The Minister for Finance also made it clear that revised Division 13 will deal comprehensively with all aspects of the shifting of profits out of Australia, whether by transfer pricing or by any other means. The new Division will also complement similar provisions for substituting arm's length prices already embodied in Australia's double taxation agreements. The new legislation will, in short, ensure Australia's ability to combat profit shifting arrangements wherever and whenever they occur.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the point just raised by Senator Walsh-that is, the rate of penalty applicable when the Commissioner seeks to apply penalties. The Opposition, by way of amendments moved at the second reading stage and, indeed, foreshadowed for the Committee stage, proposes to increase the penalty in cases to which the revised Division is to apply from the proposed 10 per cent to a tax increase by virtue of the application of the Division of an amount equal to double the amount of the tax increase-that is, a 200 per cent penalty. Such a penalty would not, in the Government's view, be appropriate in the cases to which Division 13 will apply. The Government therefore will oppose these amendments. The income tax law presently provides for the imposition of a 200 per cent penalty only where a taxpayer engages in arrangements of a blatant, artificial or contrived kind to which Part IVA applies or in cases where a taxpayer deliberately omits income from his return or claims deductions or rebates for expenditure in excess of the amount actually incurred. The profit shifting arrangements to which the revised Division 13 will apply are not blatant, artificial or contrived like those to which Part IVA applies.

Senator Evans acknowledged, when supporting the discretions proposed in Division 13, and again when putting the Opposition's case for retrospectivity of tax avoidance measures, that a distinction can be drawn between the blatant, artificial or contrived scheme and what he describes as the 'twilight zone' tax avoidance where arrangements may have a redeeming commercial justification. The Government was mindful of that distinction in submitting to the Parliament the penalty provision that is now proposed in this Bill. Another very important consideration was that, in contrast to the proposal that the penalties in Division 13 cases should be higher, there has been criticism that provision is made for penalties in those cases since they could apply even where a taxpayer, who is a party to a transaction, has no tax avoiding intent; for example, in a case where the application of the Division achieves no more than a reallocation of profits and revenue from another country to Australia. In the Government's view the penalty in that sort of case is more akin to a late payment penalty, which under section 207 of the Income Tax Assessment Act is also imposed at the rate of 10 per cent per annum.

Against that background the Government considered that the level of penalty proposed for Division 13 purposes was appropriate to and consistent with the general penalty levels in the Act. I hasten to add that the Government is not unmindful of the concern that has been expressed by the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and others about the proposed Division 13 penalty and about the level of penalties generally imposed under the Act. In that regard I inform honourable senators that the Government has already put in hand a review of the levels of all of the penalties provided for in the Act. The review is being conducted as a matter of urgency with a view to the introduction of necessary amending legislation in the Budget sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we regard that as a commitment?

—Indeed. That review will encompass the penalty now proposed for Division 13 purposes. In that regard I assure honourable senators opposite that the concern and views which they have expressed on this penalty issue in the course of the debate will be fully considered in that general penalties review. For these reasons, but particularly because the Division 13 penalty now proposed will again be subject to parliamentary scrutiny in the near future, the Government opposes any move to increase the level of penalty at this stage. I think what I have said touches most of the contentious issues that have been raised during the debate. There may be other points which need amplification. No doubt they will emerge during the Committee stage of this debate. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
