SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, clause 4, sub-clause (1), paragraph (c), proposed sub-sub-paragraph 26AAA (2A) (c) (i) (A), lines 9 and 10, leave out '10 September 1981', insert '1 July 1979'.
(2) Page 4, clause 4, sub-clause (1), paragraph (c), proposed sub-sub-paragraph 26AAA (2A) (c) (ii) (A), line 22, leave out '10 September 1981', insert '1 July 1979'.
(3) Page 6, clause 4, sub-clause (1), paragraph (g), proposed sub-paragraph 26AAA (8) (b) (i), lines 16 and 17, leave out '10 September 1981', insert '1 July 1979'.
(4) Page 8, clause 4, sub-clause (2), line 13, leave out '10 September 1981', insert '1 July 1979'.
(5) Page 8, clause 4, sub-clause (3), line 19, leave out '10 September 1981', insert '1 July 1979'.

I explain for the record that I have moved amendments 1 to 5 in one motion because the purpose of each of those amendments is identical. It is to give clause 4 of the Bill effect as from 1 July 1979 instead of 10 September 1981, the date set out in the Bill in its current form. Clause 4, as printed, closes from 10 September last year a loophole under which tax on short term profits from the purchase and sale of shares may be avoided if the company which nominally purchased the shares is sold rather than the shares being sold directly. It was detected following some transactions of that type undertaken by the Bell group and the Bond Corporation in Perth on the shares of Ansett Transport Industries, Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort and White Industries. The Government's proposal will substantially-I repeat, substantially-preclude the use of such contrived arrangements to avoid tax on short term gains from share sales.

The Opposition's amendments, if accepted, will ensure that the Bell group and the Bond Corporation pay the tax which they ought to have paid on those transactions. Of course, that will apply to any other companies which may have made similar arrangements in the period between 1 July 1979 and 10 September 1981. The amendments are explicitly designed to make those two groups, and any others in the same situation, pay the tax they ought to have paid, and they will be a warning to others. If this chamber shows that it has the courage required to let tax avoiders know that their anti-social activities will no longer be profitable no matter when they indulge in them, their anti-social activities will cease.

The Opposition regards this group of amendments as something of a test case. There is, in my view, a case for extending the application of amendments of this type to those tax avoidance schemes covered by clauses 12 and 18 of the Bill, but we decided to move the amendments to clause 4 because clause 4 is relevant to three very well-known and highly profitable cases of tax avoidance through the use of intermediary companies to mask the profits on short term sales of shares. I gather from the actions of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine in voting to remove the retrospectivity clause from the Opposition's second reading amendment that they will not be voting for the amendments which I have now moved to clause 4. It does not particularly surprise me that that is the case; both the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine have an established record of voting in this chamber for tax dodgers. I will refer to that shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I try to treat most of the things Senator Walsh says with the utter contempt that they deserve. However, when he states that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine have an established record of protecting tax dodgers--
—I will back it up in a moment. Just be patient.
—I can speak very well without the assistance of creatures like you.
—Order! Senator Chipp, I ask you to address the Chair.
—It is just that Senator Walsh has a peculiar effect on me every time he opens his mouth.
—I cannot help your hangups, mate; they are your problem.
—Order, Senator Walsh!
—It would be a massive relief to most people in this chamber if he kept continuously quiet.
—It would be an even greater relief if you did, you humbug.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw it, Mr Chairman.
—I simply make the point that although Senator Walsh did not name an honourable senator-he lacks the intestinal fortitude to do that--
—He named me.

—I am sorry. Senator Walsh did say that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine have a proven record of protecting tax dodgers. That is a lie; it is a deliberate lie; a lie that can be proven; and it is a reflection on honourable senators. I ask that the remark be withdrawn. I also ask--
—Senator Chipp, I suggest that you not use the type of language that you have used in your remarks about another honourable senator. The term is unparliamentary.
—I do not mind, Mr Chairman. I do not take any notice of scum without any principles.
—It does not matter whether you mind or not, Senator Walsh; it is a parliamentary matter.

—I withdraw the word 'lie' and substitute 'deliberate untruth'. I ask not only that the remarks be withdrawn but also that on the next such occasion, after a warning, the Chair name Senator Walsh for his continued abuse of the Standing Orders of this chamber. If he is named, Mr Chairman, notwithstanding the loss of voting power of one on this side of the chamber, the Democrats will support you or the President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, Senator Chipp has taken a point of order under Standing Order 418, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House, or of any House of a State Parliament, or against any Statute, unless for the purpose of moving for its repeal, and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.
I suggest that the remarks you have made fall within Standing Order 418. I ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept your ruling, Mr Chairman. I will detail the facts of the case which prompted the remarks. Honourable senators and the public can make their own judgments about the record of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine. With respect to retrospectivity, only two days ago Senator Siddons stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are absolutely opposed to retrospectivity in any shape or form, irrespective of whether it relates to our tax laws or the laws of the land generally. I am anxious to make our position abundantly clear as it seems to have caused some confusion in the Australian Labor Party.

Later that day, with respect to the alleged confusion within the Labor Party- there is confusion for very good reasons because there is so much confusion within the Australian Democrats-Senator Evans quoted from a notice of motion that Senator Chipp had given. There must be, he said:
. . . a systematic attack on tax avoidance schemes including retrospective application of new legislative measures . . .
The notice of motion went on to state something about identification and warning .

TALK.START.PARA: —You should quote that, Senator.
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman--
—Oh, come on, you humbug. I am quite happy to quote the lot. I was only trying to save time.
—No, you weren't; you were trying to be a sneak, as usual.
—The man who discovered principles when Fraser sacked him from the Ministry is getting agitated.
—I take a point of order. I suggest the honourable senator should be asked to withdraw that statement.
—There is no point of order. I am listening carefully to the debate .
—I was replying to an interjection, anyway. The motion continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . following specific identification and warning of the types of schemes to be affected by the legislation.

That is the entire quotation that Senator Evans made. Senator Chipp did not object then so I trust that he will not object now. The point I wanted to make-I did not leave out the last half for any malign reason-is that if the qualifications are held to be important, all that the Democrats are saying is that what the Government has already been doing for about two years ought to be done, in which case one wonders why Senator Chipp would bother to put forward the motion. By way of interjection when Senator Evans said that he did not read that quotation as going any further than what the Government is already doing, Senator Chipp said:
At this stage, but I may be persuaded to your point of view in the next Parliament if these provisions do not work.

On the one hand Senator Siddons said that under no circumstances whatever will the Democrats consider retrospective legislation. Not two hours later Senator Chipp said that he may be persuaded to Senator Evans's point of view-that is, for retrospectivity-in the next Parliament if these provisions do not work. If there is confusion in the Labor Party about precisely where the Democrats stand on this issue, I suggest that the origin of the confusion is within the Democrats own ranks rather than in any chronic inability of the Labor Party to understand simple English.

Let us be perfectly clear. By not voting for these amendments, the Democrats and Senator Harradine are ensuring that the Bond Corporation and the Bell group will avoid paying $27m in tax that they ought to have paid. Other companies, as yet unknown, may also be given a tax remission. Let us also be perfectly clear that as a result of the votes about to be recorded by those six honourable senators the Government must either increase the taxation paid by everybody else to the extent of at least $27m or reduce benefits which would otherwise have been payable, including family allowances, a matter in which some of the people concerned purport to take a special interest. The Government will have $27m less to spend on worthy schemes such as increased family allowances. Let it be perfectly clear that that is what these people are voting for. They are voting to allow the Bond Corporation and the Bell group to retain $27m which ought to have been paid in tax, thereby ensuring that some or all other taxpayers will pay $27m more, or the Government will have $27m less to spend on worthy programs such as family allowances.

As I said, I am not surprised that the Democrats have adopted this position. On 18 November the same honourable senators, aided and abetted by Government senators, voted to preserve a taxation rort associated with some equalisation deposits under which it is possible to borrow $15,000 by way of tax not paid for a period of two years and lend $10,000 for a period of one year, in addition to which a $4,609 cash bonus is picked up, half of which is not taxable because it is tax permanently evaded. Their excuse for doing that was that the National Farmers Federation had said that IEDs were not used to destabilise income in that way. If that is so, every one of the 12,000 farmers who use income equalisation deposits is paying more in income tax than he would have paid if he had not used the income equalisation deposits. The Democrats were told about that before they voted. They were told that the scheme could be manipulated in a way that enabled the taxpayer to borrow $15,000 for two years and lend $10,000 for one year. I seek leave to move amendments (6) to (8) together.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we know what Senator Walsh is talking about. He is categorising the Australian Democrats and me as being tax dodgers for one reason alone-that is, because we refused to support his motion for disallowance in respect of income equalisation deposits. In so refusing, the Democrats and I supported the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin. If Senator Walsh calls us friends of tax dodgers, he calls one of his own front bench colleagues, Mr John Kerin, the friend of a tax dodger. I will read from the media release of the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, on 22 October 1981 dealing with income equalisation deposits. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision by the Government to raise the interest rate on Income Equalisation Deposits from 7 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent was predictable given the rise in market interest rates and will be welcomed by primary producers and their organisations.
Ironically, damning with faint praise, he went on to say:

My colleague, Senator Walsh, has pointed to a situation where the effective interest rate is 23.75 per cent. To calculate the effective rate of return is complex as it depends on the size of the deposit, the marginal tax rate and average income.
I will not read all the media release. I will table the document shortly. He then stated:

The manipulations required to gain a tax benefit by destabilising taxable income are possible, but are more hypothetical than real as it would be necessary to make I.E.D.'s when income is low and withdraw them when taxable income is high.

So, in effect, I pay regard to what Mr Kerin said then rather than to what Senator Walsh has said. Senator Walsh accused us of having a track record of being friends of tax dodgers. Yet the only thing that has emerged has been the IED issue. If he accuses us he has to accuse the Labor Party and its spokesman, the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin. I am sure that many members of the Labor Party are embarrassed by the type of activity that Senator Walsh gets up to. I deliberately voted for Senator Siddons's amendment to Senator Walsh's amendment and deliberately voted against Senator Walsh's amendment.

Senator Walsh knows as well as I do that if any amendment is made to this piece of legislation now, because the House of Representatives plans to rise tonight, this legislation will not go through the Parliament this session. Senator Walsh is a friend of the tax dodgers under those circumstances. There is no guarantee that the amendments that he seeks to have adopted will be adopted by the House of Representatives. There is no guarantee whatsoever that consideration in that chamber will not be delayed until late August, at the earliest. He is trying to throw this Bill to the wolves. Many people are making substantial contributions to the Help Poland Live Appeal. Under this legislation they will be entitled to a taxation reduction in the financial year 1981-82 for that contribution. If we accept Senator Walsh's proposal that will go out the window as well. I have a list of the proposals contained in this legislation, but I do not have time to deal with them all. But every honourable senator knows that if we accept what Senator Walsh has put forward all of these other desirable measures will be delayed and might even be put on the long finger.

Finally, I commend the Government for its attempts to overcome the manipulations of the tax dodgers. It has, at least, addressed itself to this problem. I know that it has had problems within its ranks, but I have been advised by Senator Siddons who is leading for the Australian Democrats on this matter, that he has the assurance-indeed, Senator Messner, the Minister sitting at the table, has given the assurance-that the Government will have a good look at this matter of penalties. I am prepared to vote in accordance with those undertakings and to vote also to ensure that we have this legislation in place, without the delays which would result from the type of activities that Senator Walsh is engaging in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose the Opposition's amendments Nos 1 to 5 to the Income Tax Assessment Bill, as we previously indicated. We propose also to oppose amendments 6, 7 and 8 and to accept the Minister's assurance that the Government intends to do something about the clauses. I want to reply, nevertheless, to Senator Walsh. He claimed that we had not made clear our position on retrospectivity. I repeat what we said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we cannot agree that the tax law should be made retrospective under any circumstances.
Senator Walsh quoted that part only. He did not go on to quote:

We believe that it is fair that the law should be made to operate from the time the Treasurer (Mr Howard) first announces that he intends to move against a certain tax avoidance scheme that has come to his notice. From the day he makes that announcement we believe that people will be warned that the Government intends to do something. We believed that it is reasonable for any subsequent legislation which is introduced into this Parliament to date effectively from the date on which the Treasurer makes the first announcement.
That is what we said. That is what our leader has said consistently. I do not know how it could be made any clearer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the speech made by Mr Willis, who led for the Opposition in the House of Representatives, and to the excellent speech made in this chamber by Senator Evans about retrospectivity. This is an issue that deeply concerns me. I am talking about real retrospectivity; I am talking about dating legislation back to a date before a government gives a warning. The Australian Democrats are opposed to that in principle, as are all Government members and, I think, all, or most, members of the Australian Labor Party. I think every politician finds it repugnant for politicians to make illegal today something that was legal yesterday and then to make guilty of an offence people who acted within the confines of the law yesterday or last year. I think that concept is offensive to everybody in a democracy. I think that with the possible exception of one honourable senator who is a member of the Labor Party, that view would be held by members of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I go on record as saying that in long conversations that I have had with my friends and colleagues, Senator Evans, Senator Button and other members of the Labor Party-and, indeed, members of the Government-I have been persuaded that, even though we might catch up with these tax dodgers by implementing this procedure, the tax dodgers are too smart for us because they are always ahead of us. I hope that I am not doing the Treasurer, Mr Howard, an injustice-I have a personal admiration for him-but I am inclined to the view that he personally favours real retrospectivity in this area. I do not want my friends in the Liberal Party of Australia to disclose whether that is so, but I suspect that he has mooted that idea. It is well known that he is not unsympathetic to the concept-only in this area of tax dodging. I believe that the Department of the Treasury is following the lines promoted by Senator Button, Senator Evans and Mr Willis that there has to be a new look at this issue because too many people are getting away with too much money.

When we consider the history of tax avoidance it seems that no matter how clever the Treasury, the Australian Taxation Office or parliamentary counsel are , we will never find an effective way of stopping tax avoidance on the present massive scale unless we embrace a new concept. We will not achieve that new concept if people in this place accuse other people of protecting tax dodgers. I would have thought that a sensible way of doing this was to try to reach some middle ground so that the rights of the individual can be protected and, at the same time, revenue can be secured. That can be done only by a consensus being reached by all the parties represented in this place. That is why yesterday, in an interjection when my friend Senator Evans was speaking, I said that maybe in the next Parliament we will have to move to another concept in this area. We will be able to do that only when we can enter into discussions and debate with a spirit of consensus and not personal abuse and cheap, petty, pathetic point scoring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what to make of the last passage of Senator Chipp's speech unless it is that, to Senator Chipp, personal antipathy and malevolence are more important than his duty as a legislator to the people who elected him. I agree that Senator Siddons laid down a point of view which was completely clear. The confusion arises because Senator Chipp added to that two days ago by way of interjection on Senator Button and said-

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.30 p.m., under sessional order, I will leave the chair and report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That so much of the sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the further consideration of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982 forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion I seek some assurance from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) about the time limit he is now going to impose. Under the Standing Orders and according to the assurances which were given when we altered the times of the sittings on my calculation this debate should now finish at 4.15 p.m. I would like some assurance from the Minister on whether the debate will finish at 4.15 p.m. Because of the number of hours we have now sat 4.15 p.m. would be about the equivalent of 8 p.m. under the old sitting times. We should be going on to General Business at that time. When the hours were changed I sounded a warning that the Government, at the first opportunity, would break those sessional orders and would move to circumvent them because it would want to get on with its own business. I seek some assurance from the Minister about whether we will finish this debate right on the stroke of 4.15 p.m., which under the old sitting hours, would be 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -There is no intention on the part of the Government to lengthen these proceedings at all. I believe we are very close to getting to the conclusion of the Bill. It would only take a few minutes to complete it and we would then be able to get on with General Business. I understand that that has been agreed to by Whips on all sides.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I agree entirely that Senator Siddons made a clear statement about his view and, in the name of the Australian Democrats, about the Democrats' view on retrospectivity beyond the point where warning has been publicly given that legislative action will be taken. It might have remained clear if it had stopped there, but Senator Chipp, by way of interjection on Senator Evans on Tuesday, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but I may be persuaded to your point of view in the next Parliament if these provisions do not work.

That is very different because Senator Evans's point of view was that it ought to go back further than that, as these amendments seek to do, to the period when avoidance measures of the type being legislated against were first used. Senator Chipp said:
. . . I may be persuaded to your point of view in the next Parliament if these provisions do not work.
That is well removed from an unequivocal rejection under any circumstances of legislative action backdated behind the point when it was publicly stated that action would be taken.

I come to Senator Harradine's apologia that I am allegedly the friend of the tax dodgers because I and the Australian Labor Party want to make the Bond Corporation and the Bell group pay the $27m in tax that they ought to have paid. The House of Representatives is still sitting. It will be sitting after this Bill has been dealt with. There is no reason why it cannot sit the week after next, the week after that or the week after that. If these amendments are carried and the legislation fails because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) does not want to have the House of Representatives sitting, that is the responsibility of the Government and the Liberal Party of Australia and not of the Opposition. I am not surprised that Senator Harradine and the Democrats are going to vote in the way they are--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about John Kerin?

—I am coming to that; just be patient. They were all told a week before that vote on 18 November was taken that they were voting to uphold a provision which enabled the farmers with high off-farm incomes-as nearly half the Cabinet members have-to lend $10,000 for one year, borrow $15,000 for two years and pick up a $4,609 cash bonus, half of which is tax free, because it is tax permanently avoided.
—You are avoiding it.

—I am not. I am coming back to it; just be patient. The National Farmers Federation claimed that income equalisation deposits were not being used to destabilise income, the pre-requisite to achieving that objective. If that is true every farmer who uses IEDs pays more tax than he would otherwise pay. The NFF has yet to address itself to that problem. Senator Harradine and the Democrats were also told that that was so. They may have been misled by the misinformation that came from Senator Guilfoyle, which was that farmers need to retain these provisions even though there may be some anomalies because it is necessary to stabilise taxable income in order to avoid taxation penalties which would otherwise be imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that ever since the amendments of 1978 any farmer who takes a measure to stabilise taxable income will pay more tax than would otherwise have been paid. In other words, the truth was in reverse to what Senator Guilfoyle claimed it was. The Democrats and Senator Harradine were told that as well. Having been told all those things, they voted to maintain the rort. If they swallowed either of the pieces of misinformation from Senator Guilfoyle or the National Farmers Federation they were ignorant and negligent to a degree which must cast doubts upon their fitness to hold public office. If they were not culpably ignorant and negligent they consciously supported, by their votes in the Senate, the continuation of a tax dodge.

Everything I have said is applicable to Senator Harradine. He was getting impatient a while ago and I am about to deal with him. He tried to excuse his vote in favour of the preservation of that tax dodge by quoting selectively from a Press release issued by John Kerin. Senator Harradine has done that again today. John Kerin said, among other things, that it would be welcomed by farmers organisations. That is not in dispute. It was welcomed. They were lobbying for it. He added a few other things. Senator Harradine presented an interpretation of that but I am not interested in going into the details of the interpretation he put on it.

I just want to put this question: Does Senator Harradine not have free will? Does Senator Harradine do whatever John Kerin tells him to do? Does he not have a mind of his own? Does he not have a conscience of his own? Does he just blindly follow his interpretation of what John Kerin is alleged to have said? If John Kerin told him to resign from the National Civic Council, would he do that? He was told all those things. He was told the precise way in which the rort could be operated. He was told that what the National Farmers Federation said, if true, meant that the National Farmers Federation was supporting a policy which ensured that all its members who used the income equalisation deposit provisions paid more tax. He was told that what Senator Guilfoyle had said was the reverse of what was true, and Senator Guilfoyle has since admitted that, regardless of whether Senator Chipp chooses to believe it.

In one respect Senator Harradine is more reprehensible than the Democrats because he purports to wear on his sleeve a bleeding heart for the plight of the low income people, particularly the one low income family with dependent children. Resources of government are not unlimited. One of the effects of voting in the way in which Senator Harradine and the Democrats voted on 18 November and the way in which they are about to vote again now is to reduce the amount of money available to governments to pay higher family allowances or do any of the other worthy things which the Democrats and Senator Harradine normally claim governments should do. By rejecting these amendments, the Government is ensuring that $27m, which ought to have been paid in tax by the Bond Corporation and the Bell group, remains with the people who own those companies instead of being paid into Consolidated Revenue, as it ought to have been, so that it could be used to increase family allowances or for some other worthy purpose. Let there be no mistake about the effect of the Government's actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief because the outbursts of Senator Walsh do not deserve any comment by any honourable senator; they speak for themselves. I put to the Senate, and I particularly put to the Australian Labor Party, this question: Is it desirable that a senator in my situation, or indeed other senators, when considering propositions put forward in this place should have regard to the spokesman for the Labor Party in respect of those issues? If their reply is yes, that is precisely what I did in regard to the income equalisation deposits. I believe that I took my decision on that issue very seriously. Mr John Kerin, the spokesman for the Labor Party on primary industry, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there should be an automatic mechanism which raises and lowers IED interest rates at a level below market fluctuations.

If Senator Walsh says that I am quoting selectively from the media release of Mr John Kerin, I seek leave for the whole media release, which is only one and a quarter pages long, to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Media Release
SHADOW MINISTER FOR PRIMARY INDUSTRY-JOHN KERIN
22 October 1981

The decision by the Government to raise the interest rate on Income Equalisation Deposits from 7 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent was predictable given the rise in market interest rates and will be welcomed by primary producers and their organisations.

It is my view that there should be an automatic mechanism which raises and lowers IED interest rates at a level below market fluctuations. It is not satisfactory for farm organisations to have to be continually lobbying for changes in rates in keeping with the market.
The IED scheme is a policy designed to equalise farm incomes and for it to work there has to be an attraction to invest.
However, it should be realised that the interaction between the IED scheme and tax averaging needs to be re-examined as there are anomalies that need attention .
Many hypothetical cases can be put forward and it is hard to differentiate between the motives for using IED's for taxation reasons or investment reasons.
My colleague Senator Walsh has pointed to a situation where the effective interest rate is 23.75 per cent.
To calculate the effective rate of return is complex as it depends on the size of the deposit, the marginal tax rate and average income.

If one takes the specific case of an average income of $28,000 with a deposit of $4,000 the effective rate of interest at an IED rate of 7 per cent can be calculated to be 15 per cent (if used to destabilise income) or -11 per cent if used to stabilise income.

The manipulations required to gain a tax benefit by destabilising taxable income are possible, but are more hypothetical than real as it would be necessary to make IED's when income is low and withdraw them when taxable income is high.
It is most unlikely that many farmers are using IED's to destabilise their incomes because there is-
(1) a need for an adequate cash flow to operate a business.
(2) extreme difficulty in predicting future income streams.
(3) lack of knowledge of how to do it without destabilising farm activities.
Pitt Street farmers would have more opportunity to abuse the system than genuine farmers.

The Australian Rural Adjustment Unit recently examined taxation and the farm sector making comments on the complexity and anomalies in the system. It would be appropriate for the IAC to re-examine the question of taxation in the rural sector to see whether schemes such as cumulative block averaging would be more equitable.
It is my view that most farmers have stayed with the averaging system over the past years (where their incomes have been rising) in an attempt to stabilise rather than equalise their incomes.
If there is another examination of the IED scheme the question of extending it to other members of the community whose incomes fluctuate should also be examined.
Canberra
22 October 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —That media release will show that on that occasion I virtually followed the advice of the Labor Party in this matter. If Senator Walsh calls me a friend of the tax dodgers, he also accuses his Labor Party spokesman on primary industry. That is a very grave imputation indeed. Finally, as Senator Walsh well knows, it does not matter whether his amendments are carried. The Government has made it perfectly clear that the measures contained in this legislation will have effect virtually from the time of the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), or near that time, as I understand it.
—So it does not matter if the Bill is passed in the next session?
—So you would deny taxation concessions to the people who will contribute to the Help Poland Live appeal?
—That is what you said.
—Order! Senator Harradine, please address the Chair.
—I recommend that people, if they have nothing better to do, read today's Hansard. They will see that Senator Walsh is condemned out of his own mouth.

—I wish to reply briefly. Senator Harradine is trying to use the same old excuse to get himself off the hook. As he knows very well, there was an Australian Labor Party Caucus decision to oppose the regulation voted upon on 18 November-
—No, I am not advised-

—And every other member of the Labor Party in the Senate voted to do just that. I repeat: He has not responded to my question as to whether he would resign from the National Civic Council if John Kerin asked him to do so. He cannot use whatever he alleges John Kerin said as an excuse for his own actions. He presumably has a mind and a free will.
—Is he not the spokesman on primary industry?

—It is a Treasury matter, anyway. But, more importantly, a week before the vote was taken Senator Harradine and all the Australian Democrats were supplied with the precise details and the precise figures on how it was possible to manipulate that scheme as a taxation rort.
—From whom?
—Me. And nobody-you, the Government, the Treasury or anybody else- has faulted them six months later.
—I would have to have a good look at the date before I would believe that, too.
—At what date?
—Order! Senator Walsh, please address the Chair.

—I rang your ministerial officer, grade one, and said that if you wanted to discuss it with me I was willing to discuss it with you. A week before the vote was taken you were supplied with the precise details of how it operated . Perhaps Senator Harradine did not even bother to look at it. Let that be a matter between him and the electors of Tasmania. If he did not feel capable of interpreting it himself he could have telephoned the Australian Taxation Office, or asked his ministerial officer, grade one, to telephone the Taxation Office, which would have endorsed what was written in that paper. But evidently that was too much trouble for him and he came here and voted to preserve a tax rort.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether you could explain to me the relevance of the matters Senator Walsh is discussing.

—Senator Chipp, a number of interjections were made during the course of Senator Walsh's remarks and he was responding. I hope that the interjections will cease and I hope that Senator Walsh will restrict his remarks to the matter before the Chair.
—I have finished my remarks, Mr Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the Senate, being very mindful of Senator McLaren's concern. The arguments relevant to the Income Tax Assessment Bill were the ones concerning retrospectivity, and they were mentioned half an hour ago. I refer again to the fact that I stated the Government's position in that regard during the second reading debate. The Government's position has not changed. Amendments Nos (1) to (5) will be opposed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Walsh's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 38, clause 23, sub-clause (1), proposed paragraph 226 (2B) (c), lines 16 to 18, leave out 'calculated, in respect of the period commencing on the last day allowed for furnishing the return of income for the year of income and ending on the day on which the assessment is made, at the rate of 10 per cent per annum of', insert 'equal to'.
(7) Page 38, clause 23, sub-clause (1), proposed paragraph 226 (2B) (D), line 19, before 'the amount', insert 'double'.
(8) Page 38, Clause 23, sub-clause (1), proposed paragraph 226 (2B) (E), line 21, before 'the amount', insert 'double'.

I will not speak at length on these amendments. They are designed to increase the penalties which would be imposed on people or firms who attempted to use transfer pricing or income shifting-I think this is the term that has been used- across international borders. The Government seeks to impose a penalty for one class of transfer pricing and consequential tax avoidance of 10 per cent of the tax avoided. In such cases and in the other two cases we propose to increase that to an amount equal to double the tax avoided. Such penalties are compatible with those which already apply under section 226 of the Income Tax Assessment Act for other classes of tax evasion. Senator Messner said that that of course applies in conditions where the evasion is quite blatant and deliberate through misstatement, supplying false information or failing to supply information at all. The penalty provisions of section 260 are applied in circumstances where that sort of description does not strictly apply either. I will not deal at great length with that. The point I make is that in putting the case for some penalty being imposed on firms and individuals who avoid tax by transferring income overseas, the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) said :
Without that,--
that is the penalty-
taxpayers who engage in profit shifting to reduce their Australian tax liabilities would have the 'odds to nothing'- . . .

That is, of course, true. If they get away with it they avoid paying the tax; if they get caught they have to pay the tax. So obviously anyone who wanted to maximise his after tax income would have a go at it if he thought there was the slightest chance of getting away with it. The Government has imposed a penalty of 10 per cent. Instead of having odds to nothing, if the Government's original proposition stands, the odds will still be 10 to 1 on. In other words, if there is a better that one in 10 chance of getting away with the profit shifting operation the taxpayer who attempts it will, in the long term, be in front. We argue that that just is not good enough. The deterrent has to be much more severe than a 10 per cent penalty if one gets caught. If one does not get caught one evades the tax altogether. If one does get caught one has to pay the tax and a miserly 10 per cent. We do not believe that that is a sufficient deterrent.

Senator Messner has stated that the Government will review all the penalties in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Apparently the Australian Democrats are willing to accept that. It is fair to say that from a government with a record such as this Government has-this applies to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in particular-an assurance as vague as an undertaking to conduct a review of the penalties ought not to be taken too seriously. It is quite possible to review all the penalties and to decide they should all be left as they are. We do not believe that an assurance as vague as that from any government ought to be taken . Such a vague assurance from this Government certainly should not be taken. Therefore, we have moved in amendments Nos 6, 7 and 8 that the penalties should be increased to the point where they will be a significant deterrent to this practice which is, in the national sense, even worse than evasion of income tax by individuals within Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has given us an assurance that it has made a decision to review the levels of penalties provided in the Income Tax Assessment Act. It has also given us an assurance that it will bring in a Bill in the Budget session to give effect to that review. We take this as the Government's assurance that it has yielded to the criticism expressed by this chamber that the penalties of 10 per cent are too low and that it will look to see to what degree the penalties should be increased. As far as we are concerned , that is a reasonable assurance by the Government. We think that it is reasonable for the Government to have time to review carefully the whole Act and to come up with its considered position on it. We expect that to be forthcoming in the Budget session. We are now prepared to vote against the amendments proposed by the Australian Labor Party in order to give the Government time to review the position properly. We are not in the business of frustrating governments. If they give us an assurance that they will take note of the expression of opinion in this chamber we are quite happy to let them study the position and come back with their second considered views.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say that the Australian Democrats are concerned about profit shifting from Australia to any other country. By that I mean that, in addition to being concerned about shifting profits out of Australia into a tax haven such as Hong Kong by transfer pricing or by other devices, we are also concerned about, say, a United States subsidiary in Australia shifting profits from its Australian subsidiary back into the United States. So, our concern is not only with blatant tax dodgers where tax havens are being used, but also with the general principle of profit shifting from Australia to any other country. We believe that transactions betwen subsidiaries of multinational companies should be at arm's length and that that is the criterion the Government should adopt in assessing whether transactions between subsidiary companies are in the interests of the Australian people. The Government, I am sure, is aware of this. I take the comments of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to mean that these aspects will be taken into consideration in the Government's review. For these reasons, while we are still as concerned as ever that the penalty of 10 per cent is far too low to act as a sufficient deterrent in the vitally important area of profit shifting-an area that has cost Australian governments hundreds of millions of dollars, if not billions of dollars-we believe it reasonable that the Government has time to come up with its considered opinion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Committee on the matter. I wish not to reiterate the full confirmation of the arrangement in connection with penalties that I outlined earlier but merely to say that the Government will be undertaking that review as a matter of urgency. I can assure Senator Walsh that that undertaking is quite firm. As to the further matter now raised by Senator Siddons in connection with the transfer of funds between holding companies and subsidiaries--
—Shifting of profits.

—Profit shifting. I draw the honourable senator's attention to page 27 of the Bill, in particular to proposed new section 136AD which refers to the requirement that consideration equal to the arm's length consideration in respect of the supply shall be deemed to be the consideration received. I think that is the legal test of Senator Siddons's point. I hope that will satisfy him. Perhaps we could discuss that at length at another time. The Government will be opposing the amendments moved by Senator Walsh for the reasons that I outlined earlier. I commend the Bill to the Committee.

—I do not want to be offensive to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and I am sure he will take the comments in the spirit in which they are given. But I thought Senator Siddons stated our position with exquisite clarity. I think the Minister has grasped the point but I am just rising to emphasise it. The Australian Democrats are not concerned just about avoidance of tax by transfer of profits to tax havens such as Hong Kong but also about the notorious practice , which amongst other things was disclosed in the Fitzgerald report and many other reports, of a multinational with a subsidiary in Australia exporting goods to a third party. It invoices those goods not to a third party but to its parent company overseas at cost. So the Australian subsidiary in its profit and loss acount shows sales of goods X, cost of producing those goods X, profits nil, and tax nil. That exercise has been going on in this country for many years. I believe, after talking to retired taxation commissioners, that it is probably the most difficult aspect of transfer pricing or profit shifting to catch. That is the situation to which Senator Siddons was referring on behalf of the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I probably did not articulate my point clearly enough for Senator Chipp. I understand the point the Australian Democrats are making. I understand that that particular set of circumstances is covered by this legislation.
—How?

—If Senator Georges had been listening to the debate for the last three days he might have picked up a few things. The situation, as I have just said, is that the proposed new section I have just made reference to will deal, as I understand it, with any circumstance where there is an exchange of profits between any legal entities, whether in tax haven situations or between a holding company and a subsidiary, wherever located.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That amendments (Senator Walsh's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make this personal explanation so that tomorrow's Hansard record will be correct. During the debate on the previous legislation I had handed to me a copy of an answer to a question which I supposedly asked on notice of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). In fact that question was placed on notice on 16 February, not 17 February, by Senator Douglas McClelland. I make this personal explanation so that anyone looking at the Minister's answer will attribute the question to the right person. In that way the Hansard record will show that it is not my question but in fact a question asked by Senator Douglas McClelland.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to deal with the entire contents of the annual report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I wish only to make a couple of comments relating to the findings recorded in that report. Before I do so I place on record my appreciation of the work done by the Committee's secretary, research assistant and research officer. The Committee has continued to take a deep interest in the papers and reports that are put before it. I believe that the amount of time that the Committee has put into examining reports shows that the committee system, with a few adjustments, certainly will be of benefit to the Senate and the people of Australia.
—Provided you have the numbers.

—Provided we have the numbers. The Committee of which I am a member finds that it gets a fairly sound consensus of opinion. Discussions that take place are very fruitful, both for the Government and the Opposition, and the report that is presented is particularly fruitful for the people of Australia. If honourable senators take the time to read the report of the Committee they will agree with my comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I wish to make relates to the Commomwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the reduction, by the Federal Government, of moneys paid to that organisation. That is causing a number of problems both internally within the organisation and externally in the Australian community. One of the real problems is to be found in the fact that the CSIRO has said that it must set priorities in relation to the research being undertaken. It appears to have transferred a number of members of its staff from an area of non-importance, as the CSIRO terms it, to an area of some priority.

The real problem is what is happening to the research being undertaken in Australia. It is fairly obvious that by cutting back funding and setting priorities those areas of research that are probably not important at this moment but which will be important in the long term to the people of Australia will have to be cut back. Research programs in Australia will be put back something like 10 years. It has to be remembered that when the CSIRO puts together a research team it takes something like 10 years for that team to develop the necessary expertise. It takes something like 10 years for the research to be fruitful and to show some results for the amount of money expended by the Government. The cutback on funding to research groups and the cutback of staff is causing a situation in which research in Australia generally will be placed at least 10 years behind what it should be. With the increased costs that are shown fairly glaringly by the amount of money being spent to purchase in particular scientific and research material it will be put back even further than 10 years. I think my estimate of 10 years is a conservative one. This Government really needs to have a look at the research being undertaken in Australia; it needs to look at the allocation of money to the CSIRO and it needs to look at increasing the amount of money paid to the CSIRO in its Budget allocation to allow it to undertake the sort of research it was talking about prior to the cuts, prior to the decision of the razor gang to reduce moneys paid to that scientific group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse all of the remarks that have just been made by Senator Jones, particularly with regard to the staff and the work that they have done not only in producing this report but also all the reports that we are helped with on the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will know that over the last few years I have been quite worried about the amount of expenditure that is being made on research in this country. A little earlier today I pointed out that I thought that there should be more co -operation between universities and private industry and those bodies that get research grants from the Government. That is something that I think the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation could well join in. I believe that governments should encourage universities to do more research in combination with the CSIRO and the general public. It is very important in Australia that we recognise that when there are times of cutbacks, we cannot always cut back everything by the same percentage. I have always been against across the board cuts, whether they be in tariffs, in staff numbers or in expenditure by departments. There are always certain organisations-the CSIRO is certainly one of these-that deserve additional money so that they can continue their research. In the information that was given to us on the Committee the CSIRO pointed out that the costs of doing research increase more rapidly than does the consumer price index; in other words, the CSIRO contends that it should be getting at least 2 to 3 per cent more than the CPI increase just to keep up the research that it has running.

Not giving enough money to the CSIRO stops forever many new graduates getting a job in the Organisation. There is a tendency for, say, engineering graduates if they do not get a job in the engineering field in the first couple of years that they are out of the university to stay with the other jobs that they do get. It is the same with a scientist who would otherwise be employed by the CSIRO. If the CSIRO cannot accommodate a certain number of new graduates every year then those graduates are lost forever, I believe, to this country. Research that we might have otherwise had is lost forever. I reinforce and repeat one of the Committee's conclusions and recommendations with regard to the CSIRO. Paragraph 3.19 on page 19 of the report states:

The Committee is dissatisfied with the level of resources supplied to the CSIRO . The Committee RECOMMENDS that the CSIRO operating appropriation should initially be increased at the rate of the increase of the Consumer Price Index. The Government should then investigate the claims of the CSIRO that the costs of conducting scientific research increase at a rate two to three per cent greater than the increase in the CPI. If, in a wider study for years beyond 1978-79, the CSIRO claims are substantiated, the Committee RECOMMENDS that the CSIRO operating appropriation should be increased by at least that rate.

The same thing, I believe, applies to the science and engineering sections of universities. I know that it is the policy of the Government to give a certain grant to a university or college of advanced education, then let it divide that money up within the university or college of advanced education. The institutions do that themselves. I think this is something that perhaps the Government should look at to see whether we should be insisting that research in this country is supported in the way that the Government wants. Research is not a party political matter at all. It is of interest to this entire country. Without enough research I believe that Australia could very easily become an economic backwater with other countries in our near north, in South East Asia, outstripping us in standards of living in the very near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Comrade Chair, I would have thought that this very important matter would have been the subject of debate. As no one has sought the call, am I to take it that we are going to flow through General Business now without any debate on this matter whatsoever?

—I entered the chamber hoping to hear a debate on this matter but apparently there will not be a debate.

—I will test that to see what is likely to happen. I am concerned that with a change in the order of business there is a tendency for honourable senators to be caught flat-footed, to be caught out of the chamber, when matters in which they are interested come up.

—I know that it is on the red sheet. Has the honourable senator seen the size of the red sheet? It is a very complicated and very extensive red sheet. I am not going to say much more on the matter at this stage. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is laughing. What is the joke?
—We are waiting to hear.

—If there is a joke, Mr Acting Deputy President, I attract your attention to the state of the House. Let us see whether we can get a few more senators in to take an interest in General Business. (Quorum formed).

DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS RELATING TO SCIENCE AND ENVIRONMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 August 1981 on the motion:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself to item 190 , the Report of the National Health and Medical Research Council on the Health Hazards of Asbestos. When this report was presented in the chamber Senator Georges expressed very strongly his concern at the fact that the report had not been circulated. He also drew to the attention of the Senate the fact that he considered this report to be a very serious one indeed. Both Senator Georges and I have lost our colleague, Jim Roulston, who died from asbestos poisoning. When I addressed the Senate on the matter I pointed out that not only had Jim Roulston died from the effects of asbestos but also a former colleague of mine- this is recorded in Hansard-Gordon Grenville, was suffering very much from the effects of asbestosis. Since then Gordon Grenville has died. Many more people in his age group are suffering from the effects of asbestosis. Therefore we consider this report to be a very important one. On 18 March the then Minister for Health said:

SPEECH.PARA: Two advanced copies of the Report have been placed in the Parliamentary Library . Arrangements are under way for the printing of the report-therefore copies are not immediately available to the public. However, for sale copies will be obtainable from the Australian Government Publishing Service when these are printed.

That was six weeks ago. No honourable senator has been issued with a copy of that report since then. I managed to get hold of the report in the Parliamentary Library and went through it. I have some criticisms of the report. As a matter of fact the whole question of health, safety and welfare rather aggravates me. It only substantiates what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said in an address he gave in Melbourne on Saturday, 7 December. A paragraph from that address reads:

The Prime Minister and his colleagues are quick enough to collect and disseminate statistics dealing with industrial disputes. In fact, I'd like to set the record straight in this regard. In 1980, 3.3 million working days were lost because of industrial action and wages lost amounted to $152m. Industrial accidents, by contrast, resulted in more than five million working days being lost and $230m in wages. It seems extraordinary to me that so much effort is put into measuring the duration of strikes and so little into the effects of work related accidents and illnesses, which are by far the greater problem.
I think this manifests itself in the lackadaisical manner in which this report has been handled. Recommendation 1 in the Report states:
. . . exposure to asbestos should, in all phases of the asbestos industry, be reduced to the lowest practicable level by the most efficient technology currently available and enforced.

There is no mention of how this recommendation should be enforced. I suggest that strict legislative controls should be introduced, with prosecutions and heavy fines for breaches. The Federal Government should accept this responsibility. It is quick enough to pick up the statistics in regard to industrial disputes but it is not prepared to consider the time lost and the effects on the nation of industrial accidents and sickness. In Recommendation 1, various asbestos fibres are distinguished as being more hazardous than others when breathed into the lungs over varying periods of time. I see no point in making this distinction when the Asbestos ad hoc Sub-committee admits in its report that it is internationally recognised that all asbestos is hazardous. Therefore the only safe exposure is no exposure at all.

In Recommendation 2 the sub-committee recommends that appropriate legislation be introduced to ensure maximum protection of workers and the general public exposed to existing materials containing crocidolite. My question to the sub- committee is: Why should we not have appropriate legislation relating to all types of asbestos, since it is recognised that all types of asbestos are dangerous?

In recommendation 5 the sub-committee notes that available evidence indicates no significant risk to public health from the contamination of the ambient air, food or drink by asbestos. I find this difficult to believe. In fact, this was exactly the propaganda put out about occupational exposure. We should look at the horrific situation at present, with asbestosis, mesothelioma and the like. There is a terrible rate of chronic illness and death in people who have worked with asbestos. In recommendation 8 the sub-committee noted the marked influence of smoking on the incidence of lung cancer in asbestos workers and recommended that preference be given to non-smokers for employment requiring exposure to asbestos. If the problem is as serious as that, I suggest that only non-smokers be employed and that compulsory licences should be issued to employers who are slack in that regard.

In recommendation 9 the sub-committee noted the need for research into mesothelioma in Australia and supported the maintenance of a surveillance program. It recommended the program to the Government and the asbestos industry for long term support. Why did it not also recommend it to the unions? Did the Committee not consider them capable of being involved in such a program? It completely neglected the unions' role. I suggest that they are capable and morally obliged to be involved. My own union has been very much involved in health and safety issues. After all, it is the workers in that union who are being exposed to asbestos. I will give an example of the work that my union has done in this field. The Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union has issued an elaborate book on health and safety. It has gone to a lot of trouble to draw it to the attention of its workers. We always hear the AMWSU condemned in this place. No one seems to have a good word for it, especially those honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber. It is an excellent book that has been issued to the shop stewards and many other people drawing the attention of workers to the health hazards in industry. It would be impossible to have the book incorporated in Hansard, but I seek leave to have the accompanying letter to the brothers and sisters of the union incorporated in Hansard, to point out how responsible the AMWSU is, especially in that field.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AMWSU
The Amalgamated Metal Workers' and Shipwrights' Union
National Council
136-140 Chalmers Street, Surry Hills 2010. Telephone 698 9988
Telegraphic and cable address ''Amalsoyen Darlinghurst''
January, 1982 Dear Brothers and Sisters,

The AMWSU has played a leading role in the assault on poor and inadequate safety conditions for workers. At its 1978 National Conference, the Union identified major health and safety areas for immediate research and action, and backed up its concern by appointing two full-time Health and Safety Officers.

Stationed in Melbourne and Sydney, these Officers have worked tirelessly over the last two years to alert workers to the hazards in their working environment. Health and Safety Schools have been well attended by members, and every Basic Shop Stewards' School has included Occupational Health and Safety as a major topic.
Through their work, this manual has been produced. It is designed to increase awareness of the health risks members are facing every day, or could face in the future.

Used as a reference text, it can assist members to identify dangers in the workplace and to take appropriate action. The comprehensive Table of Dangerous Substances will give members instant access to the damaging effects of most chemicals encountered at work, and the maximum concentration levels set by industry: A convincing argument to use against exposure or over-exposure to certain chemicals.

The manual extensively covers the most prevalent industrial disease suffered by metalworkers, industrial deafness. In conjunction with this Manual, the Union has produced a video on the problems and possible solutions to this increasing problem. Your Organiser or State Education Officer can arrange a showing at your workplace by appointment.

The Union will continue to make occupational health and safety a priority, and hopes this manual will assist our members to assist us in our efforts to secure for all workers a safer and healthier working environment.
Yours fraternally,
GEORGE CAMPBELL
Assistant National Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the sub-committee's recommendations about bringing to the attention of Commonwealth and State authorities the disparity of provision for compensation among the States, I suggest they should also have drawn to their attention the difficulty of the individual worker who has the onus of proof forced upon him. That has been the case with very many of the workers involved in the asbestos industry. Establishing proof is a difficult and expensive job. When I listened to the garbage that was debated in this place, seeking to allow freeloaders to gain the benefits won by the unions, I wondered whether such people ever consider the amount of money that is involved in research or the amount of fighting that has to be done on behalf of people who have been affected by asbestosis. Perhaps some day they will be affected. They will sing a different song when it happens to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The crux of the report is that there is no identifiable threshold below which there is no evidence of risk. This is recognised in the report under the section headed 'The Health Hazards of Asbestos'. The sub-committee supported the view that there should be a continuing requirement to reduce the exposure to all forms of asbestos to the minimum that is reasonably practical but there was a let-out for the employers. There was nothing at all about an obligation upon them to undertake some responsibility. In this section the sub-committee also mentioned one known Australian manufacturer using amosite-brown asbestos-for the production of asbestos cement, building materials and water pipes. The manufacturer said that if a lower standard of asbestos hygiene standards were introduced the industry would be forced to consider seriously the exclusion of the use of amosite in building materials. The sub-committee was reluctant, because of the unnamed manufacturer's problem, to recommend any reductions in the hygiene standards for amosite greater than that for white asbestos. I suggest that this example is exactly why the Government should introduce strict legislative controls and reinforce existing controls.

The sub-committee also agreed that there is a continuing need for the employer to provide facilities and control measures to ensure that asbestos dust is not transported by the worker to his home. I suggest that prosecutions and heavy fines should be enforced for breaches of such standards. This report has been of great interest to me. I certainly hope that the Government will soon have enough copies for members of the Parliament to have one each and that it will also make it available to the public. I believe it should make it available to the unions which are involved in this industry. I issue a warning to the Government: Where milling and manufacture of asbestos is regulated, as in the United Kingdom and the United States of America, manufacturers simply close factories and transfer their enterprises to India, Mexico, Venezuela, and other Third World countries where there are no legislative controls or unions to protect the workers in those countries. From the way in which we go about introducing legislation today -continually mucking around with conciliation and arbitration-it is no wonder that health hazards continue amongst the workers. Unions are necessary to fight on behalf of the workers because it seems that the Government is not much interested in the health, safety and welfare of workers. We should be passing some proper laws. I refer to a report by the Senior Commissioner of the Western Australian Industrial Commission. He talked about bad laws and good laws and said that there seems to be no regulation of laws regarding, health, safety and welfare. His report concerned a matter which we dealt with recently but it is still relevant. He stated:

Legislative provisions which are the subject of frequent abuse and which experience has shown are not or cannot sensibly be enforced by the State tend to bring into disrepute the whole of the law in which those provisions are found, the courts which administer that law and, in the final analysis, the system of law in general, and should, for those reasons, be removed from the statutes in which they appear.

That statement applies to the legislation that we debated yesterday. We had the sense to set up a committee to look at it. I heard Senator Chaney talk about those who work under the legislation, those who are subject to it and those who administer it. The unions have reached the stage at which they could not care less what legislation is passed. If I were back in the workshops I would agree with them. I would fight against social injustice irrespective of the law. If the Government cannot introduce good legislation to protect the health of the workers, why should I bother about legislation that restricts and pushes the unions back into the barricades?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the report of the Asbestos ad hoc Sub-committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. We have heard so much in this place and in many other places about what smoking does to the community. I have no complaint whatsoever about the medical profession and its campaign against smoking. But I query why it has not pointed out to the general population the dangers of asbestos. In 1918 in America the Canadian insurance companies refused to insure any worker in the asbestos industries. By 1930 the scientific tests on the dangers of asbestos had been carried out. The dangers were known to the medical profession in 1930. They were documented by Professor Epstein. I ask the question: Why has the medical profession been so pure in raising the dangers of contracting cancer from tobacco when it knew, in 1930, that all people working in the asbestos industry would most certainly have their lives shortened because they would develop asbestosis?

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that not only should there be an investigation into what is causing the increase in lung cancer but also there are probably many other pollutants in industry about which the medical profession has knowledge that are a grave danger to people's health in the work place and in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are trying to say so publicly and to tell the community.

—I have always admired Senator Peter Baume when he has spoken about the tobacco industry. He wholeheartedly believes what he says. But I ask why the medical profession has not come out publicly, as it has about the dangers of tobacco, and alerted the people to the dangers of other pollutants in industry. The medical profession knew of the dangers in 1930 after medical tests had been carried out, but it did not really alert the community to the dangers. Only in the last few years have people become aware that they were causing themselves grave danger. Had the people been alerted some years ago they could at least have taken some precautions to overcome those dangers. I say again as I have said before that governments have to pick up the costs. The cost to the community must be considered; it is one of the important factors. These costs eventually become part of the social welfare bill. We have to consider not only the financial costs but also the destruction of family life and therefore the destruction of the whole of society.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we should be told about the dangers of other pollutants. Senator Baume is aware that for some time I have wanted the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare to consider the dangers of what is happening in the work place and in the community. I believe that the dangers that exist are overwhelming. It is not that we should brush these dangers off. I do not believe that the majority of industries are deliberately harming people. I do not believe that sufficient information is available. I remember that when wheat was being gassed on the waterfront to kill the weevils many people became ill. They were told that there was nothing in the gas to harm them. A poisonous gas was being used and, as a result, in the next six months in Melbourne four men died. That shows that if we had been fully aware of the problems precautions could have been taken.

We know that asbestos is a great material. It is indestructible. It can be left in the weather and will not deteriorate. Because it does not rot or decay it is of grave danger to man. It is still being used. Every time we apply the car brakes or put our foot on the clutch, microscopic asbestos fibres are put into the atmosphere. Many people are unaware of that. Every person in the community, some more than others, is affected by asbestosis. I think that is wrong. We have developed other materials over the years, but people are still using asbestos. I have seen handy people, instead of cutting asbestos sheets with a special knife devised for that purpose, use a saw unaware that asbestos fibres were entering their lungs, their wife's lungs and their children's lungs.

I believe that if grave dangers exist from smoking then the medical profession should explain the other hazards to the community. I think Senate committees should take a serious look at these problems because the costs will be astronomical. People will pay for this negligence three times over. They will pay for it through not only the suffering and misery caused by these pollutants but also higher taxes so that governments can maintain families and hospitals. People pay many times over. I think the majority of these problems can be overcome if people are made aware of them. In the toolmaking trade, which is Senator McIntosh's industry, a lot of machine cut oil is used. Cancer of the scrotum resulted because that oil was not kept away from the toolmaker by an apron. Thousands of people have probably contracted this type of cancer unnecessarily. People working with lead today are most certainly affected. I could mention many other pollutants. I believe that it is time that people were fully informed of the grave dangers that exist. I support Senator McIntosh in his plea to the Government to consider this matter. I believe that any action will benefit the whole of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the fourth annual report of the Australian Heritage Commission. Before I do, however, I refer to another document entitled 'The National Estate in 1981' which has been distributed to all honourable senators. I commend it as an excellent report both in its production and in its message. I believe it will be widely distributed throughout Australia and beyond. If anyone wishes to make our friends overseas aware of our heritage in Australia this document will do that very effectively indeed.
—Is this a commercial-

—I do not hesitate in using what time I have in supporting this document. I am giving a commercial. The officers and various groups associated with the Heritage Commission are to be commended on this report. One or two comments made in the report need to be referred to briefly. On page 194 in the chapter 'Summary and conclusion' of the document entitled 'The National Estate in 1981' the following reference appears:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has had very little money available to engage directly in research-despite comments from Parliamentary committees on the value of such research. It has, however, been able to use its influence to generate a comprehensive series of research projects through the National Estate grants program.

(Quorum formed). I will take just one or two minutes to re-emphasise the need to make research moneys available to the Heritage Commission so that it can further enhance its work and do that research which is necessary throughout Australia to protect our environment and, of course, in that way our heritage. It seems to me unreasonable that the Senate should be reminded of the lack of research moneys for the Commission. The Commission has done very well, as it says, by taking advantage of the grants that have been made to the National Estate program. Nevertheless, if the unique quality of our environment is to be protected and maintained moneys have to be made available to the Heritage Commission to carry out its work in the area of research. A whole series of instances within this chapter entitled 'Summary and conclusion' indicate much that is to the credit of the Commission. The chapter states:
It has prepared a comprehensive Register of the National Estate in a remarkably short time.
The report makes many references to the gaps in the register. It also states:

. . . these comments should not in any way be interpreted as a diminution of its status. The places currently included in the Register include the most significant natural, Aboriginal, and historic places known in Australia. The current Register will remain the core of all future listings. Other countries have taken decades to assemble a first overall list of the calibre of the current Register of the National Estate . . .

That is self-praise. I am prepared to add to that praise because the register has been very effective and most enlightening for me and for many Australians who were not aware of the depth of achievement within Australia. The document does on to state:

. . . all recognise that the full development of the National Register lists will take decades to complete. The task facing the Commission was greater than that faced by any other country, since to the Commission's knowledge there is no single national register in any country which combines such a wide range of places, both natural and cultural. The effort required to assemble the Register in the face of a great deal of hostility and misunderstanding also deserves comment.

It says 'in the face of a great deal of hostility and misunderstanding'. In no place is that more apparent than in Queensland. The National Party Government in Queensland-that is what it is because the Liberal Party is merely a shadow support of the National Party and when it comes to the test has very little impact on the decisions of the day-under the rather odd leadership of Bjelke- Petersen has caused, to my knowledge, a great deal of hostility and misunderstanding in relation to the efforts of the Heritage Commission. One could refer to the classic case-if one could use that term to describe that act of vandalism-of when the Bellevue Hotel was destroyed in the middle of the night on the instruction of the Premier of Queensland. That hotel, which was of particular character and beauty in its heyday, was progressively destroyed by the Government of the day to justify its eventual demolition. That was a very effective part of our heritage which needed to be preserved, but in Queensland that was not to be the case.
