For that reason I can understand the phrase contained within the 'Summary and conclusion' chapter which says that a great deal of hostility-that was the case in Queensland-and misunderstanding exists in relation to the work of the Heritage Commission. I would say that this document, 'The National Estate in 1981', will at least reduce or remove the misunderstanding. Whether it will remove the hostility in some places remains to be seen. The document goes on to state:

The technical development of the Register system was a huge task in itself. A major effort related to the Register has been the preparation of the material required for The Heritage of Australia, the Commission's publication on the Register. The Commission recognised that it could not on its own underwrite the cost of this publication, estimated at over $500,000. Following an initial approach to the Australian Government Publishing Service, the Commission set out its requirements and invited proposals from major private publishers in Australia. The proposal made by Macmillan Company of Australia-

This is relevant because I am leading to the point that the Heritage Commission was unable to obtain the funds necessary for it to carry out its work. The Commission had to resort to the private sector in order to get the Register established. I think it is a serious commentary on the Government of the day that a very important commission should have to depend upon private benefactors to carry out what one must consider to be a very important task, the establishment of the Register. The report further states:

The proposal made by Macmillan Company of Australia closely matched the Commission's objective. The Commission has not only devoted a vast amount of staff time over the last two years to the technical preparation of the book, it also took an active part in the search for commercial backers.

The Commission had to hawk itself across Australia in order to obtain the sum of $500,000, an amount which this Government wastes in a day by failing, in a variety of ways, to see that money is either properly expended, or, to quote Senator Walsh, that money is properly collected. If the Government acted as it should, the Heritage Commission would be able more quickly to receive the funds directly from the Parliament and would not have to search out commercial backers . The report goes on to state:

. . . thanks to the generosity of H. C. Sleigh Ltd and CRA Ltd, The Heritage of Australia has been published at a reasonable price, given its size and quality ( 1,200 pages and 8,500 photographs including many in colour).

The presentation of those photographs is excellent. The Heritage Commission, in a short time and against great difficulties, has achieved an enormous amount. It must be satisfying to Australians in general to have documents which effectively describe the character of the Australian scene, the Australian society and its development. Much that is displayed in this report, 'The National Estate in 1981 ', we take as commonplace. I noticed a plate depicting Ravenshoe in Queensland. I suppose I have passed that place on a number of occasions but I had never been attracted to its uniqueness or its character until I saw it displayed in this book.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you in it?

—No, I am not. The fact that it is here and has been commented upon means that next time I am in Ravenshoe I will be much more aware of the building depicted in the book and will give it much more attention than I have previously. This is the problem: Unless experts apply themselves to the gathering of such a register and to the protection of our heritage, our general complacency and our indifference are likely to lead to the destruction of our environment. I wish to refer to one other document. I am not certain how much time I have available under the new sessional orders. I think I have another quarter of an hour. I hope I am not taking up too much time of the Senate.
—It is a most interesting speech. I am enjoying it.
—I am not here for the Minister's enjoyment.
—I am enjoying it, nevertheless.

—I am sorry about that. I thought I was embarrassing the Government in that the Heritage Commission has to hawk itself all over Australia to find a miserable $500,000 which the Government is not prepared to give it. It is to be commended that it has achieved so much in spite of the niggardly approach of the Government of which Senator Peter Baume is a member. I am sorry that I have to retort in this way; I am just getting even with something Senator Peter Baume did to me some days ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The next report to which I refer is the fourth annual report of the Australian Heritage Commission. I may have made a rather unkind comment about the lateness of a previous report. I do not know whether I ever apologised for that remark, but now, when I see the quality of the work before us, I apologise for any remark I may have made previously which offended the executive of the Heritage Commission. Under the heading 'The present condition of the National Estate' the report states:
During the year the Commonwealth Government announced its decision to nominate Kakadu National Park for inclusion in the World Heritage List.

That was a very important decision supported by a remarkable film recently shown at Parliament House entitled The Images of Man. If I may give out commercials, let me give one out for that film. The film really penetrates ignorance on the part of many Australians. I am prepared to admit it certainly penetrated my ignorance of what has existed for many thousands of years in Australia. It showed arts which could be described only as superb. Too many of us look at Aboriginal art as gimmickry objects which we buy in curio and tourist shops. But there was a sophistication about the art shown in that film which was quite moving. It highlighted the need for the acceleration of protection. It pointed very strongly to the need to accelerate funding of the Heritage Commission and to have certain areas included in the National Estate. It is hoped that by including them in the National Estate they will be protected and suitably brought to the notice of a wide range of people. The Commission commends the Government-I suppose I also indirectly commend the Government-for the decision to nominate the Kakadu National Park for inclusion as part of the World Heritage List. The report states:

The Commission would also like to see the Great Barrier Reef Region and the balance of the area now listed on the Register of the National Estate as the Kakadu Region nominated to the World Heritage List as soon as possible.

I take this opportunity to support that. In fact, I find very little in the whole of this report which I cannot support. Practically every paragraph mentions initiatives taken or decisions made by the Heritage Commission which are worthy of support. The report states:

In an interesting initiative, Australia's four learned academies (Science, Humanities, Social Sciences, and Technological Sciences) have formed a Joint Committee on the Protection of Prehistoric Places, to 'foster studies on the prehistory of man in Australia, to encourage the protection and preservation of archaeological sites, and to advise on action that should be taken on this and related matters'.
The Commission states:
It is hoped that this encouraging collaboration will assist the cause of public education . . .

I most certainly think it will do so, and will add more strength to these organisations. I have spent some time on this matter; nevertheless I think the matter is important. The report goes on to refer to the great public concern voiced during the year about the Great Barrier Reef. It states:

The declaration of the first stage of the Marine Park was announced in October 1979. Since then there has been an active public campaign for immediate extension of the Park. During the year the Government determined a ten year moratorium on oil drilling and the Prime Minister in June 1980 announced that he hoped that the Great Barrier Reef would soon be nominated for World Heritage Listing.

That is all very fine and all very supportable. What is happening in Queensland has again come up against the barrier of what can only be described as a government of vandals. The Queensland Government has no concern about protecting the environment and no deep concern about the protecting of the Great Barrier Reef. It is astonishing that there should be so little feeling for the protection of an area which has been described many times, by both individuals and organisations, as one of great significance ecologically. It is an ecosystem of great delicate beauty and an ecosystem of sensitive balance.

It has been pointed out by many honourable senators and Senate committees that to protect the area one must protect the whole area. The sooner we establish that fact the better. In order to protect the whole of the ecosystem, the whole of the Barrier Reef must be declared a national park. There is a great danger-I think the heritage Commission appreciates this-that the Great Barrier Reef may be fragmented. In that fragmentation the whole of the Reef may be lost. The report states:
The reef remains the focus of great interest and concern to people in all parts of Australia as well as to scientists and others overseas.

The Second World Wilderness Congress was held in Cairns in June. The Congress placed considerable emphasis on conservation issues related to North Queensland and to other major wilderness areas in Australia.

The Great Barrier Reef headed the list. The report also mentions Cape York and South West Tasmania. I do not know whether I should concentrate on South West Tasmania because I may commence some sort of tribal fight in this place. I know that the Tasmanians are emotionally disturbed by attempts to destroy the wilderness areas in South West Tasmania. I will leave that to the Tasmanians. I will concentrate on my own area, the Great Barrier Reef. The report continues:
The Congress passed a series of resolutions related to these areas, including resolutions calling for the protection of Aboriginal rights in conservation areas.

The report mentions, point after point, the areas of concern. The Commission says that a further issue of concern, which has attracted considerable public attention in Queensland, is the mining in the Mount Etna area. The report states :

this remarkable mountain contains numerous caves and clefts, one of which harbours a rare bat colony. The mountain is both aesthetically beautiful and scientifically important. Mining for cement production could alter both these values.

(Quorum formed). Before the quorum was called, I was speaking to the fourth annual report of the Australian Heritage Commission. Amongst other matters I was referring to the Great Barrier Reef and the mining for limestone at Mount Etna. I was making the point that the Heritage Commission during the year has been responsible for considerable efforts in the protection of our environment and of our heritage. My time has almost expired. I would have liked to have gone on with further matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I found Senator Georges's speech interesting but I do not agree with his underlying philosophy, which seems to be that the environment is more important than people.
—The people are the environment.

—That is not the impression I got from the honourable senator. Perhaps that is what he meant, but that is not the impression I got. That philosophy is fairly popular in this community. I can well understand the honourable senator making that point clear. He seems to be backed by the law which says that it is a crime to destroy the environment and to destroy whales but it is not a crime to kill the unborn. That is the underlying philosophy of the honourable senator's thesis today. It seems to me that that thesis is backed up by the law. So he has something going for him, even if I do not approve of it . I believe that most of us in this Senate and in the community like and want clean air, clean water and pleasant surroundings. These are very useful and necessary parts of modern life and are certainly preferred to the opposite. But I believe we can achieve all of these things without the excessive efforts of the Heritage Commission, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and various other bodies that are mentioned in the science and environment papers. I believe we can achieve all of these things without them. It seems to me that all these bodies soak up huge amounts of public money for very little real benefit to the people of this country. I do not know how taxpayers on this side of the continent feel about it, but taxpayers on the side of the continent from which I come have just about had a gutful. We see these mountains of beautifully produced reports, photographs and all manner of supportive statements, and all of it achieves very little. It seems to me that in present circumstances we ought to cut out this sort of rubbish or at least cut it to the bone.
—You are the first Government senator to speak on these reports.

—I am speaking to the Science and Environment group of papers and I am speaking for myself. I am not necessarily speaking for the Government. Perhaps Senator Georges was speaking for his side, but I emphatically assure honourable senators that I am not speaking for the Government; I am speaking for myself. Honourable senators will understand why. I do not know why we as a government should have to gratify the trendies in our own party, the trendies in the honourable senator's party and the trendies in the community who seem to think that this huge soak of public money is necesary to achieve basic clean air , clean water and decent surroundings. I firmly believe we have to put a stop to this mountain of literature which does not produce one ounce of clean air nor improve the environment one iota. It seems to me that we have a whole group of people in a specific science which has emerged-environmentalism indeed!-and which, as I said, soaks up public money not to the advantage of the people in the State from which I come who have just about had enough and who, I know, will appreciate the remarks I have been making today.
—I wish to speak to--
—The question is that the motion be agreed to.
—No.

—I take a point of order. I understood that we did not have to deal with every one of those reports listed under that heading of nine and embrace the whole lot. I understood that honourable senators could speak to each one, if they so desired. If that is not the intention, I think the whole purpose of the Senate has just gone out of the window. We cannot cover everything in-
—The reports are listed as a group and the motion is that the Senate take note of the papers in that group. You have had your turn, Senator Georges.
—I have had my turn on the Heritage Commission, which is one of the reports listed, but there is another report-from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.
—I am sorry. You have spoken to group number nine.
—I insist upon my rights to speak to this particular report, otherwise I am excluded--
—You have no more nor any fewer rights than any other honourable senator in this chamber, and you have spoken once to group nine .
—No. With respect, can we search this out? There are a series of reports and papers under group nine. I have spoken to one of those papers.

—It is my understanding that we are dealing with group nine and that the motion concerns their being taken as a group. You have spoken once to that group and to that motion. You have no right, and no other honourable senator has the right, to speak twice to that motion. I put the question-
—No. I take a point of order, if I may.
—Senator Georges, you have finished. If there are no other speakers, I have to put the question.
—No. I still would like--
—He has a point of order.
—I have a point of order.
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is--
—What number? I call Senator Mason.

—Well, now. If that is the way you are going to apply the rules- admittedly I would have to search out the number of the Standing Order; it is possibly a sessional order-what I am suggesting to you is that speaking to one report should not exclude my right to speak to another report. You are suggesting to me-I would like a clear definition of it-that when I got to my feet and had 30 minutes to speak, I was required to speak to all the reports that I was interested in. Is that correct?
—Yes.

—If that is the case, I was not aware of it. I wish to speak to five reports. According to your ruling, that means that I would have had six minutes on each report. How am I to speak on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and how can I speak on the Australian Maritime College?

—Senator Georges, on 27 August a motion was agreed to in the Senate that the question in relation to each group be put in one motion. That applies to you and to every other honourable senator in this chamber. I now call Senator Mason.
—Well, I--
—If you have a point of order, would you please put it before the Chair? Otherwise allow this debate to continue.
—I am at the point of seeking the suspension of that Standing Order which would prevent me from speaking to these reports. We now have reached the moment of truth.
—The moment of truth-

—Because I have not discussed it with my party or with my party leader, I certainly cannot on my own move for the suspension of so much of the Standing Orders as would prevent me from speaking on the Australian Maritime College and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I would need to consult my leader as to whether I can proceed with the suspension.
—I call Senator Mason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into the chamber after having got in the Library an excellent new book called The Management of Sustainable Growth which I propose to recommend to Senator Martyr so that he can educate himself in modern ways of looking at things and possible solutions to some of the problems which he raised in the rather choleric outburst which I heard when I came in here and which I could not allow to pass without some kind of comment. Senator Martyr does not like environmentalists. He has made that point of view quite clear. He calls them 'trendies' and 'greenies' and all sorts of things like that . I will not be tempted to refer to him in similar but negative terms but will merely reason with him, as I have always found that in this place it is possible to reason with Senator Martyr. I will attempt to do so again.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to Senator Martyr that the real problem in this area is not that all sorts of people in all parts of Australia are interesting themselves in various causes and that he sometimes finds this exasperating, that business finds it exasperating and that many people who are not interested in those causes find it exasperating. That, I think, is not the real key to this problem. Surely the real key to this problem is that we have allowed society to go on to the extent where there is no basic consensus in the community as to what should be allowed and what should not be allowed, especially where public lands are concerned. I think this is really the basic problem. It is a planning problem, if I can mention to a good Liberal that almost unmentionable word 'planning' again. This seems to me the real point at issue. If we were now, in a substantial way, to look at land use, the use of all kinds of assets-natural and commercial-in the country, the use of rain forests, coastal land and agricultural land and try to work out between us what was acceptable and what was not acceptable to the community at large, what was in the best interests of the community at large and what was not, I suggest that we would have overcome this problem.

This is the answer to it. I say this because I think it is abundantly clear that we will go on having more and more environmental groups, community groups and citizen groups protesting about more and more things and because, as the world gets more and more crowded and as assets and natural resources are generally run down, the pressures on those things become greater. The situation which Senator Martyr abhors will not get any better. It will not be remedied by the Government saying: 'Let us tear up all this paper. Let us get rid of all these people who persistently raise these matters'. The Government simply will not be able to do that. I think the answer lies in seeking the reason for all these things.

I agree with Senator Martyr that it is thoroughly messy and untidy for the community to organise itself regularly every year into perhaps hundreds of small interest groups to take up a particular issue. These groups work hard at the issue and engage constantly in controversy about it and battle with other interest groups for months and sometimes years on end at great cost to themselves and the community. All of this could be sorted out by a reasonable and rational look at what should be done in that general area. I think our society should be capable of that. It should not be a task which is beyond it. Often in this world it is more a matter of identifying problems than solving them. Once the problem is identified we often find that it is solved. The difficulty lies in trying to identify it.

Much of the environmental movement is concerned with what is happening on public land. It is all very well for people who want to exploit rain forests in public lands-which, I think Senator Martyr would agree, are the property of the people-to say: 'We should be allowed to do this without being fettered. Environmentalists who come along to try to stop us are nuisances'. I cannot accept that or see it as a reasonable point of view. I do not think it is reasonable for people to come and say that merely because they can provide or maintain employment. I could provide immediately employment for a large number of people by taking over large sections of the botanical gardens in Melbourne, Sydney or anywhere else, ploughing them up and planting them out to potatoes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, why don't you?

—Is Senator Martyr seriously suggesting that that would be an acceptable area of entrepreneurship? If that is what he is suggesting I would be disappointed in him. I am saying that that is analogous. I think we get a reductio ad absurdum by bringing the debate to that level. I am sure Senator Martyr would not go on record as saying that it would be a good idea that he and I should form a company and make money by employing people to plough up all of the Melbourne Botanical Gardens and plant potatoes or any other thing. We would probably do a lot better by planting it out to marihuana or to heroin. In that way we would make a lot more money and we would certainly employ people. But those are not socially acceptable objectives. It is a socially accepted objective that the Melbourne Botanical Gardens and the Sydney Botanical Gardens should be kept in their present state. Honourable senators might ask why. This is at the core of our argument. These gardens are things of recreational, aesthetic and great value. So those huge areas in those cities which are probably worth billions of dollars just in land value alone are kept as they are because of public consensus. It is not good enough for the Government to say that that is acceptable and then not to accept the principle that other public lands, simply because they are more remote, simply because they have had some sort of history of exploitation, will be treated any differently.

SPEECH.PARA: Exploitation of beachfronts, forests or any public land must become a matter of community debate. That community debate is always valid. We are supposed to be guardians of a proper democracy and of public feeling. I suppose we would be failing in our duty if we did not support that to the hilt. I have some criticism of the Government because of its undoubtedly ambivalent view towards the environmental movements. I have said before in this place and I will say again that these are not people trying to preserve something for their own benefit; they get nothing out of it. There is nothing in it for them except hard work and the spending of their own money. They are looking quite honestly and quite definitely towards the future. They say that something like a rain forest has the same aesthetic and recreational value-perhaps an even greater value-as the Melbourne Botanical Gardens and it should be preserved in the same way. I seek Senator Martyr's assistance and co-operation in furthering this great cause as I see his point of view as being substantially one with which a large number of people sympathise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should we give them government money?
—I thought that the honourable senator had already made his speech . What was his interjection?
—Why should we give them government money? I don't mind their existing, but let them do it on their own money-not ours.

—I go back again to my analogy. The honourable senator comes from Western Australia. The beautiful city of Perth has a large number of public gardens. Surely public revenue is devoted to the upkeep of those gardens. Would the honourable senator say that only those people who think the gardens are of value should be levied to pay for their upkeep? Of course not. If the honourable senator were charged with that responsibility naturally he would say that it is a matter for the public purse to look after. This applies to historical matters as well as environmental matters. If people do not preserve rainforests or stop them from being cut down or destroyed completely, in a period of 10 years no rainforests will be left. It is not good enough to have mere regrowth of a rainforest. That is not an adequate replacement for the real thing? Surely those environmentalists have a right to say these things? Surely they have a right to write reports and to demand things? Just as surely they have a right to all the support from the community that they can be given including support from the Government.
—Most of them don't know what they are talking about.

—We have a situation, Senator Martyr, where the Acting Deputy President has said, very properly I am sure and I am not again canvassing that issue, that we can speak only once in this debate. It seems rather unfair for me to be putting these things to the honourable senator when he will not have an opportunity to reply in this debate. But I hope that at some future time when the honourable senator and I cross swords on this matter again-which undoubtedly will happen-he will take into account what I have said. I would very much like to hear his considered philosophical views in that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak also to the annual report of the Official Establishments Trust. I say at the outset that it would be impossible for a person interested in these many reports, ridiculed as they are by Senator Martyr, to discuss them all. There are 18 reports before the Senate. If any honourable senator wanted to devote his half hour speaking time to even six of those reports he would have five minutes to speak on each. How can anyone link one report with another? It is just an impossibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I made such remarks when the new Standing Orders were agreed to in this place. Eventually we will prove that it will not work. Under the old system on a Thursday night honourable senators had two hours within which to get together their thoughts on the matters on which they wished to speak. But today we sit in this chamber from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. without a break. If an honourable senator has an interest in a certain item which is to be debated he or she cannot leave the place until it has gone through. If one leaves the Senate chamber and tries to do some work one might miss one's opportunity to speak. One cannot devote all of one's time to sitting in the chamber.

My colleague, Senator Georges, was certainly caught short, as he has been on other occasions in the Senate. He devoted the whole of his half an hour to speaking to the report of the Australian Heritage Commission. He has previously shown a great interest in the Great Barrier Reef. I suppose that he has spoken more in this place on the Great Barrier Reef than has any other honourable senator. But because of this stupid Standing Order he is prevented from discussing these papers. After this matter has been concluded this evening it disappears completely from the Notice Paper and will not come back again.

It was not my intention to speak to any of these reports. I just wanted to reply to Senator Martyr's statement that hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money are wasted on environmental reports. He ought to get himself out into the country areas of Western Australia. He should have a look at the rape of that country and at the amount of land which has been cleared. He ought to come to my State. I will take him into the Murray mallee scrub and see how hungry farmers in years gone by have cleared every tree from the land. Under normal rainfall the ground starts to blow and covers fences, houses, roads and railway lines. Then there is the enormous cost to the taxpayer in trying to clear those roads and railways so that people have access from one town to another.

I do not think that, when Senator Martyr spoke tonight, he gave due thought to what he was saying otherwise he would not have said what he did. He said that he was speaking on his own behalf. I am pleased that he was. If he were speaking on behalf of the Government I am sure that he would get the Government into serious problems. These reports are not rubbish. They are Government reports; many are prepared by the Government departments that instituted these inquiries. Some have been prepared by Senate committees with which we will deal a little later. Of course, Senator Martyr serves on some of those Senate committees. I hope that when those reports are dealt with he will not say that they are rubbish. If he does he should not be a member on those committees. I rebut everything that he said about the reports being rubbish. Once they are tabled in the Parliament I receive many requests from interested parties and persons who want copies of the reports so that they can read their content. Over the years some of these reports have had a very great effect on and have been of great benefit to the citizens of Australia. We are now waking up to the fact that we have to have environmental protection. We have to have it because the people, such as Senator Martyr and many of the members of his party, are interested only in raping the country to get a dollar out of it. Never mind what is left behind; leave a great hole in the ground! Just leave it there for our children and our children's children. What will they say about the honourable senator in the years to come? Some of the honourable senator's children and grandchildren, when they read the honourable senator's remarks which were made in the Senate today, will think back and say: 'Well, what sort of a grandfather did I have? Look at the conditions that I live under now. He said that it was only rubbish, that it was a waste of public money'.

I want to make a few remarks on the next group of reports. I think I have said enough on this group. I hope, as I said before, that the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders will have another look at the bind that we have got ourselves into with these changed hours and changed methods of dealing not only with legislation but also with reports such as those that we are dealing with tonight and will come down on the side of common sense. Let us get back to the system that we used to have in this Parliament when, on the day that these reports were presented any honourable senator who was interested could speak on them if he wanted to. Now honourable senators cannot do this. There is a time limit of 90 minutes for debate. The reports are then shoved off. Some of the reports that are listed now were tabled in the Parliament in 1978. We are now debating them here in May 1982. They are all lumped together. Of course, we are told that we have to speak on all of these reports, more or less in the one breath. It is impossible to do that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1979-80

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate again take note of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority annual report 1979-80.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like a little information on why Senator Georges seeks leave to move such a motion.

—Unless I am granted leave to move that motion, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority annual report 1979-80 will disappear from the Notice Paper. It will no longer be before the Senate. We resolved to take the papers in toto. What happened was that there was not sufficient time-even if I had been aware of the new sessional order-to speak on the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australia Maritime College annual report and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority annual report. I am now seeking leave to move a motion to take note of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Authority annual report 1979-80 so that the report stays on the Notice Paper.
—Why don't you do it by way of a notice of motion in the normal way?

—I am doing it now by this device to save our going through that procedure. I do not intend to debate the matter now; all that I wish to do is move a motion that the Senate again take note of the paper and seek leave to continue my remarks. That means that this paper will appear as part of a group on a subsequent occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:

That the following orders of the day be taken together-Primary Industry group Nos 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 29, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 49, 50, 51, 54, 63, 71, 76, 85, 109, 154, 161, 162, 186, 199, 200 and 201-and that the questions in relation to this group be put in one motion.

Senator Jones-I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I know that there is before us a motion in relation to grouping the Orders of the Day. But I think it is worthwhile to point out that on the Notice Paper we have Order of the Day No. 8, Trade and Commerce Group of Papers-that is correct-and Order of the Day No. 9, Science and Environment Group of Papers. At the bottom of that there are Orders of the Day Nos 148 and 190. There was no motion to include those Orders of the Day, although the Chair allowed Senator McIntosh to debate an Order of the Day and refused permission for Senator Georges to debate an Order of the Day. I notice that in Order of the Day No. 10, Primary Industry Group of Papers, there is one paper on the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and we then have Orders of the Day Nos 11, 12,, 13, 14, 15, 16, 29, 38, 39 and so on. We now have a motion to group them together. It seems to me that the Chair's refusal to allow Senator Georges to debate the matter was incorrect because of the way in which this list is set out.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Georges-I wish to speak to the point of order. What emerges out of this , of course, is that we have almost 30 papers before us-I am just guessing now; I just took the first group encountered and assumed that we had about 30 papers before us. The time given to an honourable senator to speak is just one half hour. For the sake of my argument, if I wanted to speak on every one of those matters I would have one minute to speak on each. Surely that was not the intention when we agreed on a procedure, for debating papers.
Senator Grimes-No. You would not have wanted to speak to that many.

Senator Georges-Previously I wanted to speak to three reports. As it turned out it took me 30 minutes to speak on the first one, so I had no time left for the other two. In this case I notice that Senator McLaren indicated his intention to speak to every one of these. Senator McLaren is to continue his remarks on practically every one of those reports-at least 20 of them. He has a right to speak on every one of them. The Senate, by this motion, will rob him of that right. There is something wrong with the system that has emerged in this place. I raise that objection now because I think that we will have to take another look at the relevant sessional order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges, that is something for another place and another time. You will recall that there has always been a problem in dealing with this matter. This is one method which the Standing Orders Committee has come up with. The Senate has agreed to the Committee's recommendation and we have operated under the present sessional order since August last year. As I said, that matter can be debated at another time. The motion before the Chair is quite in order under the sessional orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion, not to the papers. The motion now before the Chair is that we deal cognately with all the papers that are listed. If the motion is carried I will have 30 minutes in which to speak to 20 of those papers. As I pointed out in relation to the previous list, it is physically impossible to do that. Some of the papers that have been dragged up for debate tonight- those at the top of the list, starting with Order of the Day No. 10-are nearly two years old. Yet the last couple of papers on the list came in only last week. I ask the Minister when he speaks to the motion to state how I can possibly tie in a debate on the dried fruits industry with the poultry industry, the dairying industry, the meat research industry, the pig industry, the chicken industry, the Forestry Council, the Meat and Livestock Corporation, the Wool Corporation, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Wheat Board, the Honey Board, the Egg Board, the fishing industry , the Rural Research and Extension Council-of course, that organisation no longer exists; it has gone out of existence because of a determination of the razor gang-and the Industries Assistance Commission report on fruit and fruit products.

SPEECH.PARA: How in the world can any person, however capable he may be, speak to all of those papers in one speech? It is just physically impossible to do so. That is why I objected when you, Mr Acting Deputy President, stopped Senator Georges from speaking in the debate on the previous group of papers. It was not possible for him to make a comprehensive contribution to the debate which bore any sense at all while trying to deal with all the papers together. If he had not entered the debate the papers would have disappeared from the Notice Paper.

I am opposed to the motion which the Minister has moved. I know that it will cause some havoc but I will be speaking again at 6.15 because again we are to depart from the Standing Orders of the Senate and I think, by agreement, even from the present sessional orders. They are again to be thrown out the window as I said they would last week. Because some member of the Government wants to have some legislation passed, arrangements can be made and the sessional orders do not mean a thing to the Senate. In years gone by I have always supported my former Senate colleague, Jim Cavanagh, in opposing any removal of the rights of honourable senators to speak on General Business. I am now informed that there is a move afoot to take away 45 minutes of the time set down for General Business to allow the Senate to deal with Government Business. I have warned over the years that these things would happen when we started tinkering with the Standing Orders. Honourable senators' rights are taken away from them. It is physically impossible for me to speak to all of the reports listed under my name on the Notice Paper-20 in all. I cannot do it. I am opposed to the motion moved by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister may reply if he wishes to do so. I draw Senator McLaren's attention to the fact that the Minister has moved a motion under the sessional orders under which the Senate operates. It was not a Government decision that he should move that motion. As I said to Senator Georges, we have always had difficulty with honourable senators wishing to speak to papers. The method we are presently following has been agreed to by the Standing Orders Committee. It was debated in this chamber and agreed to by the Senate. Until such time as the sessional order is changed, that is the system under which we will operate.

—I agree completely with what Senator McLaren has said. The present system is unsatisfactory. We have been dealing with papers in this way under the sessional order for some time now. I know that there has been quite a deal of debate today from honourable senators on this side of the chamber, who have complained about the way in which the business is run on a Thursday. It is not the fault of the Minister. The Whips, of course, met earlier today. We knew that under the sessional order the trade and commerce papers would be treated as one group and that the science and environment papers would be dealt with in another group. The Minister has moved that the primary industry papers be dealt with in a group. I agree with what Senator McLaren has said. It is virtually impossible for anybody to deal with more than one or two reports in the time that is available. This a matter that the Senate, the Whips and the Standing Orders Committee will have to look at. We realise why the motion before the Senate has been moved at this time.

—I think the fault lies in the fact that too many papers are grouped. The original intention was to group three to four, or perhaps half a dozen, similar items for debate and to allow half an hour to each honourable senator, in which time he could move from one paper to another paper within a particular group. If there were half a dozen items in a group and the choice had been more selective, we may have managed. We could go through these 30-odd items and break them down--
—There are not 30.

—Well, whatever number there is. There are 25. When we get more than 10 the mind starts to boggle. There are matters relating to the egg industry which could be brought together, but how do we combine the very important report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the Bovine Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign with other items? That is a very important subject which needs a full debate. At least honourable senators need the facilities to enter in depth into a debate on that matter because the beef industry has problems. There are problems in the Northern Territory which, if not solved, may seriously affect our meat export industry. We cannot just brush this matter aside in a short debate in which some 25 other items are dealt with. I suggest that we could debate item No. 11, which relates to the poultry industry, together with the paper relating to pigs. Can we include pigs with poultry?
—No, you cannot, because it brings about tuberculosis if you do.

—We could combine the poultry, dairying and pig industries for the purposes of debate. Then all the items relating to dried fruits could be brought together. Items relating to fisheries could all be brought together. The reports of the Apple and Pear Corporation and the Dried Fruits Corporation could be grouped together. But to bundle all those items into a single list and to give honourable senators half an hour in which to cover the whole ambit, I think is ridiculous. It is an absurdity which has emerged because those who are organising the program intend to brush aside as many of these reports as possible and to take them off the Notice Paper as quickly as possible. Senator Martyr agrees with that, of course. I have a feeling that he does not want anything serious to be debated in this place. His levity in referring to my comments on the environment seems to indicate that he thinks that anything that is important to the environment, or anything that is important to debate in this place, should be quickly brushed to one side and that he should concentrate on his own particular problem and concern. I just point out that if we cannot quickly change the sessional order that now is part of our proceedings, at least the lists should not be as lengthy as those before us tonight. I suggest that when items are being grouped the grouping be more selective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The procedure that we are discussing has been in operation for quite a long time. It was brought in to enable honourable senators to debate the various subjects that are listed under General Business Orders of the Day. Before any arrangement was made, when a report was tabled in the Senate, debate on the report was adjourned and the matter was listed on the Notice Paper. The Notice Paper got longer and longer. The matter never came up for people to be able to have a say on it. There was no debate because it was never brought forward. Some time last year, in an effort to give honourable senators an opportunity of debating these matters-many had expressed their disappointment that they were not able to speak on the reports when they were actually tabled-a system was devised so that on each Thursday, under General Business, a group of reports could be brought forward under particular headings. Honourable senators then would have a chance to debate them . This system, by and large, has worked very well. There have been very few upsets. It was not introduced as a result of the new hours or the new Standing Orders that have been brought in during the last week or two. The practice has been with us for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: The arrangement was not made by the Government, a Minister, or the Whips. It was an arrangement that met general agreement in the party rooms. It came to a Whips' meeting and the Whips carried out the instructions given in the party rooms. That is how this procedure was brought in. Today, we debated trade and commerce matters under General Business Order of the Day No. 8 and we have science and environment matters under General Business Order of the Day No. 9. This was arranged by a prior motion. It was thought then that there would be very little debate on the papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—There was an indication that people did not want to speak. The Whips went around but people took very little interest in these matters. Senator Georges must admit that that is fairly accurate because now we have nearly finished discussing the science and environment group. In order to give honourable senators the opportunity to continue to debate these various papers, General Business Order of the Day No. 9, the primary industry group of papers, was added to enable honourable senators to have until 7 o'clock. Of course, all we are doing now is discussing this arrangement and we are losing time. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) moved a motion in order to group the primary industry matters in a manner similar to General Business Orders of the Day Nos 8 and 9.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to honourable senators that after tonight they should sit down and review the situation. I am sure we will do so. I suggest that everyone look at the system to see how it has been working. Honourable senators will see that over the months it has given them the advantage of being able to bring papers forward and discuss them. If any honourable senator finds a better system than this, then by all means he should bring it in. But if we start bringing in little groups of papers here and there the system will not work because honourable senators will have insufficient time to debate them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply -I do not wish to prolong this matter but it seems to me quite clear that there is some major difficulty amongst honourable senators in dealing with papers in this manner. I wonder whether the Whips should confer with honourable senators in their party rooms and decide whether there is a consensus of view and what further action should be taken. It seems to me that there is no point in further debating the issue. As Senator Sibraa has clearly pointed out, this is the arrangement for the moment and it seems that it is best settled in the party rooms.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not call for a division, but I would like my objection to be recorded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 April 1981 on the motion:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out previously-I do not want to repeat it in detail-it is impossible for me to debate all 20 papers listed under my name so I will confine my remarks to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Report. But I again make the plea that the Whips, as has been suggested, confer with their various party members to see that many of these reports are voluntarily taken off the Notice Paper before we again get into such a bind as we are in now.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about the Apple and Pear Corporation Report 1980. Yet on the list of papers to be tabled today-we did not discuss it because of the time limit imposed upon us-was the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Report for 1981 which we now have in our offices. That was brought into the Parliament today. It was probably tabled in the other place yesterday. The Senate now is faced with the position where we have to debate the Corporation's report for last year. It is 12 months old. Surely there can be some consultation so that we can be told about the reports that are coming in before the list of papers is compiled each second Thursday-we only debate them once a fortnight when the Parliament is sitting-with the aim of striking from the Notice Paper some of the papers which are out of date. Some are listed in the group now before the Senate . The General Business Orders of the Day to No. 85 are all 1979-80 reports. The 1980-81 group is still to come. As I pointed out, if I had had the opportunity I would have spoken today when the 1981 report was presented.

Looking at both of the reports jointly, I would like to make a suggestion to the powers that be in the Apple and Pear Corporation. The reports list, under the heading 'Composition of the Corporation', the respective names of the members of the Corporation. I suggest that the States which members represent should be listed beside their names. That is what I shall confine my remarks to, in the main, in speaking on the reports.

In debating the apple and pear legislation in this chamber in times gone by, I pleaded with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) that recognition be given to my State of South Australia and to the State of Queensland and that they should have representatives on the Corporation. I am very pleased that that was agreed to at last. The Minister issued a Press release on 14 April 1982 which is headed: 'Appointment of Two Additional Members to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation'. It stated:

The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Peter Nixon, today announced the appointment of Mr Douglas Bishop of South Australia and Mr Stanly Halloran of Queensland as members of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation to represent the interests of apple and pear growers. The appointments increase the number of members on the Corporation representing the growers from four to six, in line with changes to the legislation last year. Both Mr Bishop and Mr Halloran have wide experience in the apple and pear industry. Mr Bishop is a past President of the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association while Mr Halloran has been a member of the Excutive Committee of the Queensland Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing since 1973. Mr Nixon said the new appointment would ensure that the membership of the Corporation was sufficiently broad to allow adequate consideration of all individual State industry concerns and problems. They would also improve industry-wide understanding and support of Corporation initiatives, especially in regard to domestic market promotion. The new appointments are until 31 August 1983 when all other member's appointments terminate.

I place on record my appreciation to the Minister for having appointed representatives from South Australia and Queensland to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. That can only be for the better. Before this, the growers from both of those States were denied a voice on the Corporation which, in the main, is concerned with the marketing of the product that they produce. They now have that voice and can take part in the deliberations of the Corporation. I hope that that will bring about a better understanding of the growers' needs and will be of great benefit to the apple and pear industries.

The Minister said in his statement that having two other people on the Board would improve industry-wide understanding and the support of Corporation initiatives, especially in regard to domestic market promotion. There is a great potential in Australia for the promotion and sale of apple cider. At one time in South Australia non-alcoholic apple cider could be bought in steel 10-gallon kegs. It is no longer available. We are very concerned about the carnage on the roads and people drinking alcohol at various functions. At one time we were able to get a keg of apple cider for people to drink at functions. It was a very good product, but it is not now produced; we cannot get it in South Australia.

I make the plea to the Corporation that in its promotion campaign it should see whether it can attract the interest of some manufacturers in again producing non -alcoholic cider in kegs. I know we can get plenty of it in bottles. I recall that Gil Duthie, the member for Wilmot in the other place for a record number of years, was also secretary of the Labor Party parliamentary resources committee for a number of years. For years before I came here-and since I have been a senator-that committee held dinner meetings on a Tuesday night. It was left to Gil Duthie to arrange the meal and the drinks. All we would get on the table to drink was apple cider. It came from the Huon Valley in Tasmania. It became known as Duthie vodka.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new member for Lowe likes apple cider.

—I am very pleased that Mr Maher does. I think most people enjoyed Duthie vodka. Now that Gil is no longer here we have a range of various drinks. I make the plea to the Apple and Pear Corporation that it take some steps to see that non-alcoholic apple cider is sold in bulk again. I have asked for it to be provided in the parliamentary dining room. Sometimes I can get it and sometimes I cannot. I think we should make efforts to see that it is always available because it is a delightful drink. If the industry suggests that it is not profitable to make apple cider available in kegs some approach ought to be made to the Government for some financial assistance to see that it is placed on the market. I know that in South Australia one can get still apple juice. Other forms are available in flagons. But those products do not have the fizziness of the apple cider that we used to get in the kegs. Also, it is not as palatable to many people, although I drink it.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make reference to another matter. In looking at that report I find that South Australia, the State which I represent, has the lowest production of apples of any State or Territory except the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, those of us who know the apples which are produced in the Australian Capital Territory know that they are of very high quality. Mr Hawkman, who is very well known to me, produces very high quality apples near the Canberra Airport. He grows them with organic fertiliser. I recommend those apples to anybody who may care to partake of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of fertiliser?
—Organic.
—Yes, but what sort?

—Natural fertilisers. If Senator Georges talks to me after I will tell him all about it. It might be a bit different from that which he was using here this afternoon. I noticed also in that report that Tasmania, in the 10 years to which this report refers, has always been the highest producer of apples. In contrast, my State has always produced the lowest number. But we do produce a very good apple. We make the apple cider about which I was speaking. Senator Tate said 'Hear, hear!' when I mentioned the Tasmanian apples. They are good apples too. Of course Tasmanian producers are finding it very hard to market the apples that they produce. If the Corporation were to take some notice of the plea that I have made here today, to look at the by-products of apples such as apple juice and apple cider, we might not have the problems that we have at present in getting rid of that great apple surplus which exists. I noticed in the report that in 1973 Tasmania had a record crop of 7,024,000 boxes of apples. That figure has been reduced considerably; the estimate for this year 1982 is down to four million boxes. So the figure has reduced by three million boxes in a short span of about eight years. I do not know whether the apple producers in Tasmania are going out of business or the trees are not producing as much as they did; they are getting older.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter on the list to be discussed this evening is the 1979-80 annual report of the Australian Wool Corporation. We know from the announcement with which we have been acquainted that the razor gang decided in its wisdom-it has not proved very great wisdom now that we have looked at it-that the Australian Wool Testing Authority would be sold. Legislation has been introduced in the other place regarding this matter. It has not come into the Senate yet so I am quite in order in talking about it. The Government was not able to sell the Wool Testing Authority. It was to be sold to try to assist the Government with its deficit. The Government was trying to sell the other authorities through which it put its axe for the same purpose. I spoke on the Australian Wool Testing Authority when legislation on the matter was being considered by the Senate. I spoke on behalf of many woolgrowers who had approached me. I expressed their grave concern about what the Government was doing to the Authority.

It is obvious with the Australian Wool Testing Authority, as with many other authorities, that the Government recommended abolishing that the government had not done its homework. It had not consulted anybody about taking over these instrumentalities. The proof of the pudding is now in the eating with the Australian Wool Testing Authority. The Government could not sell it. Now it has to turn it into a tax-free organisation. I believe that there have been great ructions among some of the people on the Government back benches about what the government is now doing. Of course, what the Government did was second best. I will have more to say about that when the legislation comes into the Parliament. I do not think I need to take the time of the Senate in talking about it tonight except to conclude by saying that the conclusive proof of the Government's lack of wisdom is now becoming obvious in pieces of legislation and in select committees that have been set up to consider some of these things which the razor gang recommended in haste. The Government will now repent its decisions at leisure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later. I do that because I believe certain legislation needs to be brought on.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take long on this matter but I want to put on record that despite the promises that were given to us when the Standing Orders were altered the Government has now moved for General Business to be superseded by Government Business so that we can deal with Government legislation. I place on record my objections to this. It transgresses the Standing Orders. We were given solemn promises when the Senate debated the alterations to the Standing Orders not so long ago that the time for the debate on General Business would not be altered. it did not take very long for my predictions to come true. Senator Messner has proved those predictions true by moving the motion that consideration of items of General Business be postponed to allow Government Business to take precedence. I again place on record my objections to that action.
