STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981 [No. 2 ] (1982)
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
Second Readings
Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating these education Bills together and the Opposition will oppose them. These three Bills have a common purpose, that of reintroducing tertiary fees for second and higher degree students throughout Australia. As honourable senators will be aware, this is not the Government's first attempt to reintroduce tertiary fees. In numerous debates in the Senate and in other places the Australian Labor Party has put forward reasons for its steadfast opposition to this measure. However, despite the defeat of this measure in the Senate some time ago, the Government has seen fit to bring the legislation into the Senate again. So I will take this opportunity to reiterate the reasons for the Labor Party's opposition to the reintroduction of tertiary fees. I do so knowing that the defeat of this legislation this evening or when the Senate resumes will provide the Government with a Bill which will be one of the grounds for a double dissolution. All I can say about that is that the Labor Party is ready to face the Liberal Party of Australia at a Federal election at any time.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose the reintroduction of fees because of our belief that access to education at all levels should be a right of all Australians. The proposed reintroduction of fees, especially if it is extended by the Government to a wide range of students, will reduce access to education. There is no way that that will not happen. That is fundamentally the reason why we oppose these measures. The introduction of fees will mean, eventually, that once again, as in the pre- Whitlam era, education will become a privilege restricted to those who can afford to pay for it. We regard that as a fundamentally undemocratic development .

Many people will be disadvantaged by the imposition of higher and second degree fees but I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the disadvantage that this measure will cause for Australian women seeking higher education. Women's incomes are, on the average, much lower than their male counterparts' and women are, therefore, less able to pay fees. Women who normally interrupt their careers to have and raise a family are, for that reason, more likely to require retraining in an appropriate area and, therefore, more likely than their male peers to need a second or higher degree. The majority of those people who will be unable to pay for second and higher degrees, if this legislation were to be successful, would be women. Monash University research shows that 57.6 per cent of women students currently studying would defer or not enrol if fees were reintroduced.

Hand in hand with the Government's proposal to reintroduce fees is the proposal to introduce a student loans scheme. The Government claims that this is the way in which it will continue to provide access to higher education. But the Labor Party is highly sceptical of this claim and, in fact, we reject a loans scheme for the same reason as we reject the imposition of fees. A loans scheme will again restrict access to higher education, or to whichever level of education the loans are to be made available, to those who can pay or to those whose families can support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't worked in the United States.

—Exactly; as my colleague Senator Tate interjects, it has been tried in the United States of America and it has not worked. If one looks at the pattern of access to education in the United States one can see a decrease in access to higher education in the lower socio-economic groups and an increasing monopoly of access to higher education amongst the wealthy classes. That is the experience we should have learnt from. That is one of the main arguments-learnt from experience-against the proposals the Government is now attempting to foist upon us. It is clear that a loans scheme will restrict educational opportunity to those able to pay off loans. Of course, it will further undermine the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme which has already been substantially eroded through government neglect.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Government senators will say that once a person has his first degree he should be in a position to pay for a second degree. They will ask why the taxpayer should subsidise people in order for them to do higher degrees and so on. I want to make it clear at this stage that if we in this country are interested-certainly the Labor Party is interested-in increasing the skills and expertise available to the community and available for the improvement of the economy, we should encourage, not discourage, able students to pursue higher degrees and second degrees in order to increase their qualifications. If we create a situation in which one's access to higher education depends on one's ability to pay we will be ruling out people of merit. It has always been the case that when fees are required there are people with merit who are unable to secure scholarships.

It is no use the Government pretending that existing post-graduate scholarships accommodate all the people who have ability but who are in financial need. It is now a very sparse scheme. Certainly I do not believe any academic in the country would claim that all able, talented and higher degree students can be accommodated under the existing post-graduate scholarship award scheme. Indeed, that scheme has had its value seriously eroded in recent years and the opportunity for higher degree students to supplement or earn their income by tutoring has declined alarmingly. It used to be the case some years ago that higher education students and, indeed, undergraduate students could work as tutors in their own institutions and supplement their income. That situation- again as a result of Fraser Government education strategies-no longer prevails.

We have people sitting in tutors' jobs because staff ceilings and cutbacks in universities have meant that the tenure jobs are totally tied up with people who got tenure maybe 10 years ago, who have many years of their working lives to go and who certainly will not resign from their tenure jobs because there are no jobs elsewhere. There are highly qualified people with Ph.Ds, with many years tertiary teaching experience and with many publications to their credit occupying the tutoring jobs because no other academic position is available to them. In a situation like that the post-graduate student has virtually no chance of getting some part time tutoring to supplement his or her income. So I hope we will not have Government speakers suggesting that it is the case that higher degree students can supplement their income through teaching; nor, as I have said, can all of them be accommodated by the post-graduate scholarship schemes.

The other point to be made about loans is that people enter into loans only if they know they will be in a position to pay them off. People from middle class backgrounds who have affluent families and who expect to inherit some wealth and property of course are in a position to take out a loan while they are doing a law or medical degree. Of course, while they are doing a higher degree in one of those areas they are increasing their ability to earn their own income. But what is the situation for students from a poor background, of whom there is an increasing number today? How can they take out a loan not knowing what their responsibilities to their own families will be, knowing that there is no financial back up from their own families and, of course, in many cases, not being assured of highly remunerative employment? It is all very well for Government senators to talk about-as they may well do in the course of this debate-the incomes of doctors or lawyers. The Opposition is certainly concerned about the high level of incomes in those areas. I remind honourable senators that not everybody who takes a higher degree will go into one of those highly remunerative areas.

We want and expect people to work in the community for voluntary agencies or for organisations such as the Aboriginal Legal Service or the Aboriginal Medical Service which pay very low salaries indeed. There are still people in our community who take higher degrees and then want to work for charitable and voluntary organisations. Those people are needed. If we insist on a loans scheme we will be depriving a whole lot of community activities of the skills and experience of people who have higher qualifications. Because those people have the burden of a loan they will say: 'I would like to go and work for the Aboriginal Legal Service for 10 years but I cannot because I have to pay back my loan, so I will go and work in a suburban solicitor's office'. That is the sort of concern we have about the overall effects of insisting on a loans scheme as a means of financing higher education.

Of course, there is still the threat of unemployment. I am very well aware of the fact that graduates, and certainly graduates with higher degrees, have a much lower rate of unemployment than the rest of the community; nonetheless there is still a measure of unemployment even amongst people with doctorates and masters degrees and so on. Again, if one comes from a low income family, a poor family, one simply cannot take the risk of taking out a loan, secure in the knowledge that one will get a job and pay it back, because one could become one of those unemployed doctors of philosophy that we have heard about quite frequently. Mr Paul Carrick, President of the Australian Union of Students, in a recent Press release stated:

Student loan schemes are notoriously inequitable and have been a disaster in many overseas countries. The scheme proposed by the Federal Government is worse and effectively means banks would be able to dictate to students what courses they take.
Students could face a debt of up to $10,000 upon graduation with uncertain employment prospects.

Of course, a loans scheme would restrict the educational opportunities of women in particular. Many financial institutions still regard women as a greater credit risk than men. Women suffer higher unemployment rates than men and, when in employment, on average they receive lower salaries. All these factors would work against female students obtaining, let alone repaying, loans. A survey carried out by the Monash Association of Students indicated recently that up to 48.5 per cent of current female students do not think they would be able to repay a student loan. Quite obviously, the introduction of both fees and student loans would be a serious restriction on women's access to education.

The Senate should also consider the Government's motives in this limited-to use the Government's term-reintroduction of fees. The amount of money saved in the education budget would be extremely small. Therefore this Government measure is not a budgetary measure at all; it is not an economy measure or a measure designed to reduce public expenditure because it will not do any of those things to any significant degree. it is clear that this limited reintroduction of fees makes sense only as the first step in a general reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees which would again mean that higher education, even at undergraduate level, would be available only to the rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second step after the overseas students.

—There has been further erosion of access to education by the Government's quite unreasonable policy of imposing fees rather selectively on overseas students. Again, that is not a serious revenue-raising measure but a measure which simply excludes people from access to tertiary education, people for whom access to tertiary education is probably what they most need from a developed country.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation we are debating would allow the Government to set up a fee collecting mechanism so that the level of fees imposed on students could be fairly easily increased at a later date. The Australian Labor Party believes that the reimposition of tuition fees for second and higher degrees would unfairly penalise post-graduate students and, as I suggested before, would handicap important research work carried out in tertiary institutions. Post- graduate students make a major contribution to Australia's research effort. Indeed that is the case not only because of the calibre of the work carried out by post-graduate students in our research institutions but also because of the Government's meanness in funding other forms of research and development in this country. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, for example, is desperately underfunded. That lack of funding has been adverted to in a number of debates in the Senate in the last couple of days. This country is desperate for some good research and development. We need to find new productive industries and new technologies to make those industries efficient. There are a number of areas, particularly those in which the CSIRO has been involved, in which we have a great deal of expertise. We have some good experience in the field of agricultural science. Medical science is another area in which we have a great deal of talent and experience. But the Government simply will not fund research and development.

The private sector expects research and development to be carried out by public institutions so that it can come along and skim some profitable technology or expertise. The private sector in this country has been scandalously unprepared to assist in the research and development effort in a way that would benefit the entire economy. The burden has fallen on post-graduate students, and post- graduate research programs carried out within tertiary institutions in this country have been a major contributor to successful research and development- what little the Government has permitted-in recent years. If the Government, through the reintroduction of fees, prevents graduates taking up post-graduate studies, much of this important research work will simply not be done. The supply of trained researchers for education, industry and government will dwindle and Australia's development effort will suffer. It is certainly nonsensical of the Government to promote research on the one hand, through the establishment of Commonwealth research centres of excellence, yet handicap research on the other hand by penalising post-graduate students. The majority of post-graduate students are already struggling to maintain themselves on the inadequate financial assistance currently provided by the Government. How are they expected to manage with the added burden of fees?

Finally-this is a very serious consideration-the reintroduction of fees of any kind for higher education represents a breach of faith by the Government. In a pre-election undertaking the Government assured the people of this country that it had no intention of reintroducing tertiary tuition fees. Its actions in bringing forward this legislation are a violation of that pre-election undertaking. I urge the Senate to remain firm in its opposition to these three Bills so as to preserve educational opportunity in this country and to keep the Government to its word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are discussing in a cognate debate tonight three Bills dealing with the fundamental issue of the imposition of fees on second and higher degrees. Senator Teague, during a debate on education yesterday, alluded to the fact that this issue of education has been discussed in the Senate regularly. Not only has education been discussed on many occasions , but also the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and cognate Bills have been discussed ad nauseam. The obvious reason that the time of the Senate has been taken up again tonight is simply the device of constitutional propriety; to make sure that there is at least, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), a trigger for a double dissolution. The fact that the trigger already exists raises the point that the Government, presumably, is looking to use these Bills to call a double dissolution. If that be the case, the Australian Democrats will be very happy to have the opportunity to fight an election on such an issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for our opposition resides not so much in the notion of education or institutional organisation as in our concern for the economic ramifications of such a move. I shall refer the Senate yet again to the chain of argument that we believe has not been refuted by the Government or even addressed by the Government. It is beyond doubt that we are moving in a world of rapid change. We need to seek as rapidly as possible long term plans for our economic future. It is also beyond doubt that a very large proportion of the industries which Australia can expect to develop in the coming decades, and upon which it will ultimately come to rely for a major proportion of its gross national product, will be industries of a technological kind, a communications kind, or the emerging industries of bio-technology. It is also beyond doubt that those industries around the world are based upon a highly educated community. Those communities which have spent and continue to spend high amounts of their budgetary allocations on education have also been those countries which have developed, are developing and are in the lead in relation to that range of industries.

I pointed out in my previous speech that our economy relies most heavily on a single item; that is, the service sector. It does not rely on manufacturing, primary industry, or mining as the largest single item. The largest single contribution to the gross national product is service industries. That is indicative of the type of economy that we have and the type of economy that we share with countries such as Sweden, West Germany, Japan, the United States of America and Canada. That is characteristic of those types of economies. It is also characteristic of those types of economies that they not only have that particular expenditure on primary and secondary education but also spend heavily on tertiary education.

We must look at what Australia will provide for its tertiary education sector. In some of the countries that I have mentioned, the expenditure comes not only from government but also from industry and from private endowments. The United States of America is the prime example of continuing and large support from the private sector for tertiary institutions. Recent developments in funding for universities is quite intriguing. In the United States of America one of the growing areas for funds is the area of industries based on communications. I predict that in the next 10 to 15 years that will be easily overtaken by the industries of biotechnology. Rather than take a superficial view, which happened in the last debate, by saying: 'Look, the United States of America Government does not spend all that money, industry spends some money', I believe one is obliged to delve further into why that is occurring and what are the ramifications of that occurrence.

If one looks at what is occurring, one will notice that there is a very close relationship between the development of those industries and higher education. It has been pointed out on innumerable occasions that there is even a physical proximity; for example, the Silicon Valley in the United States is in close proximity to three of the largest university campuses in the United States. That particular development is something that the United States, in its own historical development, has been able to foster and expand. It is not something that has occurred in this country. It is all very well to wave one's arms around and say: 'Look, the industry ought to be picking this up', or 'If government cuts back industry we will make up for the lack of funding from government'. It is only possible to do that if we have firm assurances from industry that it will provide those funds that the government does not provide. In other words, if the Government speakers wish to use that argument again in this debate, I ask them to table firm assurances from industry that it will pick that funding up. If not, it is an arm waving exercise, a flag waving exercise, and it will be to the detriment of this country. We cannot gamble our tertiary education on the possibility that somebody will pick up the funds the Government does not spend. It is not a gamble in the United States of America, it is an historical occurrence. That is the way in which it occurs in the United States and has occurred since the development of universities in that country.

It is important to look at what happens in the United States with the industries I have mentioned. Many of the tertiary institutions in the United States have developed close links with various industries-links which share staff, and knowledge which has been gained in research by both sides. Indeed, industry pays for many of the faculty positions in universities in the United States not because it wants control over their output but because they know that the long term benefits to it will easily outweigh the minute cost of a faculty member at a particular university. Many of our universities in Australia have attempted that in the past. In almost every case, unfortunately, it has been a failure. Currently in Australia a number of such experiments are under way. Some of these I believe have good prospects of continuing.

I will point to a rather ludicrous situation that has arisen. At the University of Queensland it had been the intention of the computer science department to attempt to develop over three to five years a consultancy operation. This consultancy operation would require input from government to get going. After all, the major funders of universities in this country are governments. The small amount of funds which would have been necessary to generate that computer consulting facility would have had a twofold effect on industry not only in Queensland but also in other parts of the country. It would have developed at the university increasing skills which could be passed on to students and it would have enabled the skills of faculty members to be made available to industry in general.

It had been confidently predicted on the basis of the detailed work that had been done on the submission that in a space of three to five years that facility within the university would have become self-financing. In other words, it would have been a good exercise in co-operation between a government funded institution and private enterprise. These are the types of things which have occurred so successfully in the United States. What happened? A free enterprise government, such as the one we have in place in this country, vetoed the small amount of funds which would have been necessary to generate, in one of our major universities, a facility which would have become self-financing. That is how far this Government has any intention of fostering co-operation between those two arms. So why throw out the United States as an example? At the very time the universities in this country attempt to do that, this Government pulls away. That type of argument must be backed up, not by fine words in this chamber or any other place, but by detailed finances and moneys going to the universities to enable them to provide those types of facilities. I believe it is the last time that this Government ought to talk about free enterprise fostering in any shape or form. Time and again it finds itself incapable of following its own basic philosophy.

I turn now to another suggestion which has arisen in this debate, and which has about it the same tinge of absurdity; that is, that students ought to be, in some way, morally uplifted by paying for part of their education, that somehow or other we will have a spin-off of better people. Senator Teague looks rather puzzled. I point to some of the interjections he made in the last debate in relation to the moral uplifting tones of paying for fees. This rather odd notion is a very interesting proposition. Unfortunately I will not be able to develop it at this point. I hope I will be able to develop it at a future date in more detail. I will be able then to point out to Senator Teague the absurdities of that argument.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ansett Air Services-Incident in South Australian School-Australian Atomic Energy Commission

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ansett Air Services-Incident in South Australian School-Australian Atomic Energy Commission

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question :

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today I received a number of complaints about Ansett Airlines of Australia's air services from Cairns to Weipa and return. My information is that Ansett is cancelling services at short notice and not providing sufficient services to carry freight. When I attempted to determine from Ansett today what its flights were between Cairns and Weipa and return, I understood how Weipa residents had become confused about the flights available to that centre. The actual timetable bears little relationship, if any , to the published timetable. I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to ask the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to examine the availability of flights from Cairns to Weipa, what cancellations have occurred in the last month and whether Ansett is fulfilling its obligations to this part of north Queensland. I realise, of course, that the Minister cannot provide this type of information tonight but I would appreciate early advice from him.

SPEECH.PARA: I actually wish to raise two matters tonight. The second matter is one that I alluded to last week. In the adjournment debate on Thursday of last week I raised a matter relating to an incident in a South Australian school. I outlined on that occasion how a Press report suggested that a secondary school student suffered burns when a teacher allegedly poured methylated spirits on one of the student's hands and set it alight. I said last Thursday that many people would take a grave view of the incident but I withheld any further comment until the South Australian Education Department made any findings available in relation to investigation of this incident. Last Thursday I did not seek a response from the Minister; neither do I do so tonight. Even though I did not seek a response from the Minister, Senator Messner replied that he would see if any further information was available.

Today I was appalled to read that this violent episode has been given a classical bureaucratic whitewash. I would like to read an article that appeared in today's Courier-Mail. It is headed: 'Teacher is fined and transferred'. It states:
ADELAIDE.-A teacher who set alight a boy's hand at an Adelaide high school would be fined and transferred to another school, the South Australian Education Minister, Mr Allison said yesterday.
Shaun Riley, 12, said last month his hand was burnt when the teacher used methylated spirits to set it alight because he had not done his homework.
The teacher, who has not been named, declined to be interviewed but Education Department officials said the action was intended more as a practical joke than as a punishment.
Mr Allison said he was satisfied the matter had been dealt with in an appropriate way and he considered it closed.

In the Adelaide Advertiser today there is an article which is almost word for word with the article which was in the Courier-Mail. I happened to see an Australian Associated Press article which was shorter than those two articles; but it contained some additional information, so I will read what the AAP article mentioned. It said:
An Adelaide teacher had been fined a week's wages and transferred over an incident in which a pupil had his hand burned, State Education Minister Harold Allison said today.
Mr Allison said no police charges would be laid over the incident, in which the teacher poured methylated spirits over the hand of a 12-year-old pupil and lit it.

I would like to go over some of the points mentioned in the article in the Courier-Mail. That article was almost word for word with the article in the Adelaide Advertiser. It said that the teacher would be fined. That is an indication that someone in authority regarded the matter quite seriously. The AAP article mentioned that he would be fined a week's wages. This teacher apparently will be transferred. I ask: Why will he be transferred? Why was he not suspended from duty on a permanent basis? Why were his services not terminated? If he is not suitable to teach at one school because he pours methylated spirits over the hand of a student and lights it, why send him to another school? Is it that there is no methylated spirits in the stores of the school to which he is to be transferred? It seems to me that if he is not a suitable teacher at one school he should not be transferred to another school to perhaps act in a similar way.

It is also stated in the article in the Courier-Mail that Education Department officials said that the action was intended more as a practical joke than as punishment. A practical joke? Is this what students will be subjected to when they go to South Australian government schools? Are they to have a practical joke perpetrated on them? Are their hands to be burnt with methylated spirits? If it was a practical joke, it is an absolute disgrace. But even if it was a punishment, it is an absolute disgrace. I wonder whether it was a punishment. If it was not a punishment why should the Education Department official mention that it was more a practical joke than a punishment?

I must admit that I have some harsh words to say about Mr Allison. I do not know the man personally. I have made some inquiries about him today but I cannot mention the comments because what certain people said to me about Mr Allison is just hearsay. Taking just this incident by itself, and noting that Mr Allison said that the matter had been dealt with in an appropriate way and he considered it closed, in my opinion the matter has not been dealt with appropriately. There should be a full disclosure of the investigation that was made by the South Australian Education Department. It should be made public so that people know whether this sort of action will continue and whether this teacher, who has apparently been transferred to another school, will act in a similar way again. If Mr Allison can do no better than to say that it has been dealt with in an appropriate way and that he considers the matter closed he should resign his portfolio. I do not say that lightly because a student has had his hand burnt when methylated spirits was poured over it and it was set alight. How many parents will now trust the administration of Mr Allison when students are treated like this, either for punishment or as a practical joke? I call upon the Premier of South Australia to demand that Mr Allison make a full disclosure of all the facts of this case. If Mr Allison will not offer his resignation, he should have his commission terminated by the Premier of South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour not to try your endurance, Mr President, more than is absolutely necessary to put on the record a matter which is, I believe, of some seriousness and demands a reply from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). Having registered a strong protest last week about the Attorney's rather shameless rule-worship in insisting on a criminal record check when the Commonwealth employee in question had good grounds in principle for refusing such a check, I now raise a matter of a rather different kind, though still concerned with security. This concerns not the strict adherence to rules but, on the contrary, an apparent irregularity. I refer to the appointment of a Mr John Gerrard to fill, initially on a temporary basis, the position of Director, Security, of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The Attorney is, I am informed, already aware of this case through correspondence he has received from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. It is, nonetheless, I think, important to sketch out the facts very briefly in order that it may be understood why I publicly now raise the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed that the need to fill the position of Director, Security, on a temporary basis from 1 January 1982 arose because the permanent appointee, Mr Alan George, was absent from that date on a long term sick leave pending retirement. On 29 August 1981, some four months prior, Mr Gerrard was transferred to a temporary position of Security Officer (Clerk Class 8) under the supervision of the Director, Security. A number of aspects of the promotion- transfer of Mr Gerrard through various positions in the period 29 August 1981 to 1 January 1982 appear to be highly irregular given that it is standard practice at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to advertise all temporary and permanent vacancies and to interview applicants prior to filling a position. Firstly there was no advertising prior to the filling of Mr Gerrard's transfer from clerk class 7 to security officer clerk class 8 in August 1981. Secondly, in a subsequent filling of the Director, Security position, again by Mr Gerrard, on 1 January 1982 the vacancy was not advertised. Thirdly, senior management of the AAEC have actively discouraged appeals by staff against the transfers, and ultimately promotion, of Mr Gerrard stating: 'No one else could possibly win'. These are quite unusual steps and have given rise to serious speculation that Mr Gerrard's nomination for the position was done by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and that this occurred well in advance of the vacancy formally occurring on 1 January 1982.

The Attorney-General will recall that the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association made this allegation to him directly. The allegation is not based on idle speculation but on information which I understand was provided to ACOA by one of its members. As I said, the allegation is given credence by the irregular procedures undoubtedly associated with the filling of the position. I am not of course in a position to confirm or deny that allegation. However, I believe it is a serious allegation and I raise the matter here to give the Attorney-General an opportunity to answer it in due course.

It is beyond doubt the statutory function and the duty of the Commission itself to choose the best qualified person for the position subject I readily acknowledge, to whatever security check is appropriate having regard to the obvious sensitivity of the position. I am not denying that ASIO will have had and should have had an input at that level of checking but it is quite another thing altogether for ASIO to be allowed to interfere, as it has been suggested, to the extent of actually determining the ultimate nomination to this position in breach or ordinary, proper procedures.

The question has also been raised as to whether the United States Central Intelligence Agency-the CIA-has been at all involved in this appointment; an involvement which the Government may of course seek to justify because of international arrangements involving the AAEC. I simply endorse in that respect the sentiments of the ACOA that it would seem quite objectionable if an Australian appointment were indeed made in any way subject to foreign approval or scrutiny. The ACOA believes-I support it in its belief-that the problems highlighted by events in the AAEC to which I have referred are not isolated.

As a result of this incident, and I understand some previous incidents, it has called for proper arrangements to be implemented immediately taking into account the explicit statutory provisions of the Atomic Energy Act and the current ASIO legislation and that those procedures should include in this case: Firstly, the advertising of the vacancy again within the Commission; secondly, if deemed necessary, the advertising of the position outside the Commission; and, thirdly, the vetting of the preferred candidates, but in doing so taking fully into account and consideration the checks and safeguards that are laid down in the Australian Security Intelligence Agency Act 1979. The proposals that are here being suggested amount to no more than the regularisation of this apointment in accordance with established law and procedure. I ask the Attorney to indicate his response. The functions of ASIO in relation to security assessments are fully set out in Part IV of the ASIO Act 1979, in particular in section 37 (i), which states:
The functions of the Organization referred to in paragraph 17 (1) (c) include the furnishing to Commonwealth agencies of security assessments relevant to their functions and responsibilities.

That function is clearly described in the Act. It is a limited one. I believe that here, as in all other matters involving this Organisation, we must be constantly and continually vigilant to ensure that ASIO does not exceed its functions in this or in any other respect.

I conclude by simply saying that the issue of security assessments and the procedure that ought to be followed in relation to them was dealt with quite extensively by Mr Justice Hope in his second report on intelligence and security tabled in 1977. I commend the various relevant passages in that report to the Attorney, both in respect of this case that I have now mentioned and in respect of the case that I referred to last week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer firstly to Senator Colston's remarks concerning air transport problems between Cairns and Weipa. As properly acknowledged, I do not have any immediate information. I will convey his concern to the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and obtain a reply for him. With regard to the matter at the Adelaide high school, Senator Colston must clearly recognise this as being in the State area of concern and administration. It is not a matter which the Federal Government can approach in any meaningful way. When Senator Colston first raised this matter some 10 days ago I made inquiries of the Education Department in Adelaide to see whether I could obtain any further information for him. I have not been able to obtain any further details concerning the way in which the State Education Department formed its judgment in regard to this matter. Now that the matter has been concluded I will personally speak to Mr Allison to obtain some explanation of the conclusions reached in this matter. I will speak to Senator Colston, perhaps privately, about that matter on a later occasion. Generally speaking, this is not a matter in which the Federal Government would involve itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter raised by Senator Evans is detailed and complicated. I know that he has referred on other occasions to matters of this kind. I will refer the matter to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and bring it to his attention. No doubt the Attorney-General will reply appropriately.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.17 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Australian Government seek to ban fuel air explosives (FAEs) at the Geneva disarmament talks; if not what is Australia's position on the use of FAEs in combat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The issue of fuel air explosives (FAEs) was the subject of a draft resolution introduced in 1978 by Sweden and Mexico at the 'First Preparatory Committee meeting of the United Nations Conference on Prohibitions or Restrictions of Use of Certain Conventional Weapons Which May be Deemed to be Excessively injurious or to Have Indiscriminate Effects' which was held in Geneva in 1978. The draft Resolution called for the banning of FAEs for anti- personnel use. Because of time constraints the question of FAEs was not discussed in any depth at either the Preparatory Committee meetings or at the Conference itself and accordingly was not covered in the Convention and Protocols adopted by the Conference.
(b) The Australian Defence Force has no present requirement for fuel air explosive weapons.
(c) Fuel air explosives are not inherently indiscriminate. The area of effect of fuel air explosives is limited by the size of the fuel air cloud which can be precisely controlled.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian policy has been consistently directed towards realising the goal of world wide disarmament. The Government devotes considerable resources to arms control activities thus reflecting the importance we attach to disarmament. The Government's budget allocations for the Department of Foreign Affairs include provision for Australia's active participation in the relevant international disarmament forums, notably the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva, the United Nations Disarmament Commission and the First Committee of the United Nations General Assembly itself, particularly the First Committee in which disarmament matters are considered.

The contribution which a government makes to the goal of disarmament depends on the quality and content of its policies on disarmament and related issues. The Australian Government's record is of the highest order and it has reservations about the establishment of a specific and fixed percentage budgetary target for expenditure on arms control and disarmement activities. Those activities are being adequately undertaken and financed in accordance with Government policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much revenue has been lost to the Government through the operation of tax avoidance schemes similar to those outlined in the Bulletin article of 9 March 1981, entitled 'Treasury Loses Millions in Sales Tax Fiddle'.

(2) What are the reasons for the continued operation of such schemes in the automotive and import industries; and why has there been a lack of action in combating these examples of gross tax avoidance.

(3) What action has the Government taken in response to the February 1982 letter from the New South Wales Chamber of Automotive Industries to the Treasurer, in which the industry itself testified that the schemes have operated for over twelve months.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No revenue can be said to have been lost to the Government at this stage. The Commissioner of Taxation advises that he does not concede that the schemes effectively circumvent the sales tax laws.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation advises that it is necessary to conduct investigations into the attempted tax avoidance arrangements before assessments can be raised. It is not uncommon for taxpayers to continue to participate in the schemes until their assessments are confirmed by an appropriate appellate tribunal. The schemes have been under investigation by the Commissioner for some time, but he has found it difficult to obtain vital information particularly where there has been a lack of co-operation from promoters of the schemes. I am advised that, in the light of this lack of co-operation, administrative activity has been intensified to bring matters to a head as quickly as possible and that this activity is proving successful.
(3) I have replied to the letter from the Chamber of Automotive Industries of New South Wales on the matters raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Social Security have an Equal Employment Opportunities Program.
(2) How long has the program been in existence.
(3) What are the aims of the program.

(9) Has the program changed in its priority rating within the Department since its introduction.
(10) If there is no program, on what basis was this decision reached.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is any signatory to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty able to accumulate nuclear material and enrich that material to weapons grade under accepted international safeguard procedures and then abrogate that Treaty at any time.
(2) Has the Vietnamese Government revived the experimental nuclear reactor supplied to the previous government of South Vietnam by the United States of America.

(3) Has the Government of Iran revived an experimental nuclear reactor in Teheran that the United States of America supplied to the pre-revolutionary government of the former Shah, who had planned a major nuclear program for that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) obliges each non-nuclear weapon State party to the Treaty not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices and not to seek or receive any assistance in the manufacture of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. The Treaty also imposes the obligation on each non-nuclear weapon State Party to the Treaty to accept International Atomic Energy Agency ( IAEA) safeguards for the exclusive purpose of verification of the fulfilment of its obligations assumed under the Treaty with a view to preventing diversion of nuclear energy from peaceful uses to nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices.

Article X of the NPT provides that any State Party has the right to withdraw from the Treaty if it decides that extraordinary events related to the subject matter of the Treaty have jeopardised its supreme interests. Such a Party would have to give three months notice to all other States Parties and the United Nations Security Council which notice must include a statement of the extraordinary events it regards as having jeopardised its supreme interests.

The NPT is the principal international instrument aimed at preventing the spread of nuclear weapons. It is a persuasive symbol of a broad-based international consensus and an important deterrent to proliferation. The strength of this consensus is demonstrated by the fact that 113 States have already adhered to the NPT. Abrogation of the Treaty by any State Party would have serious political and economic consequences. Such a State would forfeit its access to supplies of nuclear material and expertise. No State Party has ever withdrawn from the Treaty.

(2) No. However, in June 1981 the Board of Governors of the IAEA approved a nuclear safeguards agreement between the IAEA and Vietnam covering the Dalat reactor in connection with the supply of nuclear fuel for it from the USSR. This suggests that Vietnam proposes to recommence operation of the reactor.
(3) The Teheran reactor was shut down following the outbreak of hostilities with Iraq in 1980. As far as can be ascertained, it has not been reactivated.

(2) Has the Minister for Social Security made a decision as to whether such an agency within the Department of Social Security or outside the Department is more appropriate; if not, when will a decision be taken as to the establishment of such an agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I did have discussions with the Chairman of the Family Law Council concerning the question of a National Maintenance Collection Agency in June 1981 . Since then I have had a number of discussions on the matter with welfare groups, State Welfare Ministers, officers involved in the establishment of the Liable Parent Contribution Scheme in New Zealand and the New Zealand Minister for Social Welfare.

(2) No final decision has yet been made regarding the establishment of such an agency. The decision will be for the Government to make. My colleague the Attorney-General and I are currently examining the matter in the broader context of our consideration of recommendations 23, 24 and 30 of the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

(2) Why is every effort not being made to ensure that the shelter is able to continue its important work, as Nambour has a special need for short-term and emergency accommodation, and the assistance given at this shelter to people and families in crisis, helping them to rehabilitate themselves, saves the community purse far greater expenditure on welfare services.
(3) Will the Minister for Social Security give an assurance that it is not intended to withdraw funding from this shelter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) The Nambour Lions Family Emergency Accommodation Centre was funded from 25 July 1979 to 31 March 1982 under the pilot Family Support Services Scheme component of the Children's Services Program. Funding from this source ceased because the project was ineligible for funding under the guidelines for the extended Family Support Services Scheme, which commenced operating on 1 January 1982.

I have approved projects for inclusion in the Scheme on the basis of recommendations by the State Minister for Welfare Services, acting on the advice of the Commonwealth/State Management Committee. On the advice of the Queensland Minister, I agreed that the funding of the Nambour Lions Family Emergency Accommodation Centre would continue until 31 March 1982. The project is predominantly operated as a women's refuge and is therefore specifically excluded from funding under the Family Support Services Scheme guidelines. The centre is more appropriate for support under the Queensland Government's program of assistance to women's refuges, and I have raised the question of assistance under that program with the Queensland Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a report published in the Sydney Morning Herald dated 24 March 1982, which stated that the United States Navy proposed to tow ageing Polaris submarines 260 kilometres off the coast of California, scuttle the submarines and settle them at 4,270 metres in the Pacific Ocean.

(2) Have two physicists identified two dangerous isotopes, nickel-59 and niobium-90, which it is claimed could be present in the metal of the submarine's reactors; if so, and if the Minister for Foreign Affairs is aware of the report, will the Government protest to the United States Government in an attempt to halt this dumping of waste in international waters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I am aware of an article in a recent edition of the journal Science, published by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which referred to the identification by two physicists of two long lived isotopes, nickel-59 and niobium-94, which could be present in the metal of the reactors of nuclear-powered submarines.

In January of this year the United States Government drew to the Government's attention the publication by the United States Navy of a Statement of Intent to prepare an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) on Alternative Methods for Permanent Disposal of Nuclear Reactor Plants from Decommissioned, Defuelled Nuclear-Powered Submarines. The Statement of Intent indicated that the EIS would cover both land and sea disposal methods.

In response Australia reminded the United States of its opposition to the dumping of radioactive waste in the Pacific. The United States was informed that Australia believed it essential that the EIS should represent a balanced and thorough evaluation of land and sea disposal options, with appropriate attention to long term environmental considerations. The Government will be examining the EIS in detail when it is issued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 27 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What procedures are followed by the Merino Ram Export Review Committee when 'inspecting progeny from merino rams exported from Australia and local sheep in importing countries'. (see Department of Primary Industry, Additional Estimates 1982, page 29).
(2) Are objective or subjective criteria used by Committee members to assess the genetic impact of Australian rams on overseas flocks.
(3) What value, if any, does the Minister attribute to a subjective assessment.
(4) Has advice been sought from the CSIRO Division of Animal Genetics on the value, if any, of a subjective assessment, if not, why not.
(5) Has advice been sought from the CSIRO Division of Animal Genetics about possible objective means of assessing genetic impact, if not, why not.

(6) If no advice was sought from the CSIRO and subjective criteria only used in the assessment, will not the assessment be worthless, and the $83,000 spent on it so far be a culpable waste of taxpayers money.
(7) Can Senator Walsh have a reply to this question before the Additional Estimates are dealt with by the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Committee has not been directed as to how it must pursue its task. However, it is anticipated that comparative information from controlled studies will be available in the USSR and South Africa, two countries which already possess large flocks of merino sheep on which there is considerable recorded, objective data. Some objective performance data is also expected to be available from India and Romania. The Committee will need to endeavour to form opinions about the intentions and the capabilities of overseas flock owners to breed merion sheep and produce merino type wool in the future. For this purpose, they may have to rely on direct observation and questioning and on extrapolation from past experience in the countries concerned.
(2) The Committee has not been restricted to use solely either subjective or objective data.
(3) I cannot comment on this question without knowledge of particular judgements made and the circumstances surrounding them.

(4 and 5) Doctor Helen Newton Turner, a distinguished associate of the CSIRO Division of Animal Genetics, was one of the people with relevant experience contracted in advance for advice to assist the Committee in making the assessments called for by its terms of reference.
(6) See responses to (3), (4) and (5) above.
(7) As is my normal policy, this reply has been provided with maximum practicable expedition.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February 1982 (Hansard, page 142) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As it is now 11 years since Australia signed the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances, why has the Federal Government not ratified that Agreement?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Amendments to both State and Territory Laws were required before Australia could ratify the Convention. These amendments have now been made and steps are currently being taken to enable Australia's formal ratification.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Sponsorship of Programs

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 574) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has a senior executive of the Australian Broadcasting Commission been inviting large corporations to sponsor ABC programs? Do the corporations approached include an American oil company and a Japanese electronics manufacturer? Is it true that the Government on the other hand, has not yet made any announcement about its reaction to a recommendation in the Dix Committee report proposing corporate sponsorship for the ABC? If that is so, why have executives of the ABC-if they have-undertaken this course? Has this action been taken at the behest of senior management of the ABC or at the behest of the Commission? Can the Minister provide a list of companies so far canvassed? Have any firm commitments been given by any companies in response to that canvass?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Government has not as yet made any announcement concerning its reaction to the recommendation of the Dix Committee about the introduction of corporate sponsorship for the ABC.

The ABC has not sought sponsorship of either radio or television programs from any commercial operations. Discussions have taken place however between ABC officers and National Panasonic and Amoco Australia in regard to projects such as the provision of scholarships for the ABC Sinfonia or the underwriting of costs of a future tour by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. These arrangements have not as yet been finalised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1089) Senator Gietzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister will be aware that the Australian Electoral Office is required by the Commonwealth Electoral Act to carry out periodic reviews of the electors enrolled in Federal electorates for the purpose of maintaining an up to date electoral roll. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that, as a result of restrictions placed upon staff and funds, the Chief Australian Electoral Officer is unable to carry out the regular habitation review procedures in most States of the Commonwealth? Does that mean that the electoral rolls will not be brought up to date?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Because of the limits to which available funds could be spread over the various operations in which the Australian Electoral Office is engaged, habitation review activities were reduced in this current financial year. As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs suggested in his reply to the honourable senator on 24 March 1982, this curtailment however did not flow from staff restrictions.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 places on officers of the Australian Electoral Office the responsibility for the maintenance of the electoral rolls. The Australian Electoral Office does all that it can, within the limits of resources, to help all eligible electors become and remain correctly enrolled and, as the honourable senator is aware, habitation reviews assist the Electoral Office in obtaining elector information for the preparation, maintenance and revision of the rolls. Nevertheless, it must not be lost sight of that with a system of compulsory enrolment such as we have in Australia, the responsibility for being correctly enrolled rests in the end on each individual elector.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1579) Senator Gietzelt asked me a question without notice concerning a secret talk allegedly given by the Australian Electoral Officer for Queensland, Mr Frank Coleman, to the State Executive of the National Party in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following information in relation to that question:

The direction to Australian Electoral Office staff in relation to public discussion about electoral matters is that any discussion should not be party politically oriented, should not express views in relation to government policy in respect of electoral matters, and should not seek to have the official position of the officer cited as an authority for statements on matters not related to his own duties. Within these limits and in the interests of electoral information and education, Electoral Office staff are certainly not discouraged from assisting inquirers about general electoral procedures.

Mr Coleman has informed me that in accordance with these principles and particularly in the run-up to the 1980 elections he answered many questions relating to electoral procedures and talked to groups of people, usually on an ad hoc basis, from various political parties, including the National Party, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. Mr Coleman informs me that the honourable member for Brisbane, Mr Manfred Cross and Senator Gerry Jones will no doubt be pleased to confirm this in respect of the Australian Labor Party since both of them were at discussions in Mr Coleman's office prior to the election.

As for the particular meeting to which Senator Gietzelt refers Mr Coleman informs me that it was not a secret meeting of the National Party Executive. The meeting which was arranged by the Queensland Branch of the National Party consisted of a group of 100 or more persons to whom Mr Coleman was asked at very short notice to give an address with questions and answers outlining the electoral procedures relating to the Senate.
